Hot take - I actually wasn't a massive fan of Judgment. The story wasn't super gripping (entertaining for sure, just not quite my speed) and, while I loved Crane Style, Tiger Style didn't feel very good to use in my opinion, so the combat didn't have quite as much variety as I was hoping for

That being said, THIS is one of the best RGG games without a doubt! The story is absolutely incredible with great pacing from start to end, the characters are deep and impactful, and every single combat style is so much fun - Tiger Style was actually my favourite in this one!!

I also found myself really enjoying the School Stories side content. Each minigame was a lot of fun (except for the early stages of the Robotics minigame, but once you get the speed upgrades it starts to feel a lot nicer to control)

I even ended up really enjoying the Kaito Files side-story. It was nothing life-changing, just a very engaging story with some really touching emotional beats. I've always really enjoyed Kaito's character so seeing his story explored in a bit more depth was very interesting to me

Overall, this is one of the best experiences that this studio has to offer right now. If you're a fan of the Yakuza games, make sure you don't miss this

Of all the Yakuza games and their spinoffs, I'd place Lost Judgement in the top 3.
The combat is tight and exciting. The characters are well-developed (many thanks to the previous title, although even the new characters are very well made), and the action is intense. Unlike a lot of the Yakuza titles, the plot makes sense and is relatively easy to follow, even down to the minor details.
In plot context, this takes place following the events of Yakuza 7/Like a Dragon and Judgement, so the former to avoid spoiling that game, and the latter to properly appreciate this one.

[i]The way I see this, Tak, both of you have your reasons.
Something to consider - but between the both of you... is there really a right answer?[/i]

The game is set in the Yakuza franchise, but it is more or less a soft reboot. There are slight callbacks to earlier games in the franchise, but you don't need to have played all the Yakuza games or even the first Judgment to enjoy and understand Lost Judgment.

[h1]Lost Judgment, shortly[/h1]
Lost Judgment is, not in particular contrast to other Yakuza games, a beat em up, but this time with detective elements such as tailing and observation to pick out as evidence later on.

[h1]Pros & Cons[/h1]

[b]Pros[/b]
-Excellent soundtrack. It feels modern and fitting to the game's period.
-Graphics. The Dragon engine looks good, even if combat physics might leave a bit to be desired. However, performance might be an issue even on lower settings due to how demanding the game is.
-Recycled as Kamurocho may be, it is still well updated.
-New bigger city to roam around in. However, at times it might feel empty or less alive than Kamurocho. Still refreshing, especially having played through all mainline Yakuza games.
-Combat is refreshingly done and felt nice, especially after the heavier combat of the earlier games. Way faster and encourages style-switch comboing.
-The story is actually relatable, yet still manages to even at times feel like well-written horror.
-Characters in the story feel like real characters. A clear antagonist who is obviously a sociopath and almost clearly in the wrong, can still feel like he has ground to stand on to justify his actions and as if he has a heart, haunted by his past who still owns up to his mistakes.
>Two characters simply talking to eachother in a room could never have been better.
-Availability and amount of side content.

[b]Cons[/b]
-May be a bit long-winded if you're not feeling patient. The game takes its' time with introductions to side content.
-The detective-spot portions want you to spot everything. Boring and annoying.
-Difficulty spikes at random. Some enemies do ridiculous damage - more damage than the level's actual boss.
-Unlike previous Yakuza games, dying twice and lowering difficulty is [i]permanent[/i] for your savefile.
-Clich√©s and tropes as with previous Yakuza games.
-At times plain unrealistic, taking leaps of faith (and logic) for the story to proceed as planned. I was purposefully picking the wrong, outlandish or otherwise stupid options in the "present your evidence" sections, and I accidentally picked the correct option. It's... a strange twist, to say the least.
-AI allies, which you actually have in this game as opposed to every Yakuza game, are downright useless.

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
Hand-to-hand combat based with detective aspects. Leveling system grants points per mobs killed / bosses beaten. However, you get barely anything unless you farm mobs or otherwise grind harder stuff for skill points.

[h1]Graphics[/h1]
Very power-consuming and can make your computer a space heater if tuned too high. Far more realistic graphics with more detailing.
Animations or poses can be clunky, though.

[h1]Soundtrack[/h1]
One of the best I've heard in a game.
It is grandstanding, but it succeeds at it.
The game's main villain has, at first, a dark synth-esque fight track that lets you know there's something more lurking underneath, and the finale track for him is... something you should play the game for.
Bosses in general have fitting tracks. A knife psycho has a track with Psycho (1960) callbacks and an elegant piano to fit his personality. A scrappy brawn-based boss has a suiting electronic track to go along with a Scarface-like personality and upbringing.

[h1]Conclusion[/h1]
Lost Judgment is a wonderful game and an excellent step away from the heavy-to-fill shoes of Yakuza's earlier protagonists. Despite it's story and gameplay shortcomings, it remains a very enjoyable experience you'll want to see through to the end and to see it's contributions to important societal questions as much as be able to do ridiculous heat actions on random Kamurocho inhabitants.

Pros & Cons compared to recent Yakuza & Like a Dragon series
-------------------------------------------------------------------

PROS
- 4 Different types of Martial arts ( including one from School Side Quest )
- School Stories (Different From Side Quests) around 8 different to Master and will provide the best type of fun Challenge such as the best imho :- 
Boxing ( its like a totally awesome game of its own where you can spar to upgrade boxing stats to take up like 15 different class of challengers , learn moves from your boxing coach and even can used to apply to one of your fighting style outside the boxing ring) this is much more interesting compared to yakuza series underground fight.

Dancing - Rhythm game but its not as easy at it sounds compared to yakuza karaoke series. you need master the game in order to help your students win national championship.

Racing - again like crash bandicoot where you enter the underground street racing world where you take on around 12 different racing crews while they use weapons like molotov cocktails like fireworks, weapons and such in the same time need to keep up to speed to race the boss

Skateboarding - kinda mini tony pro skater type of game, easier but equally challenging in later levels

Photography - this is kinda lame but whatever

Robot Fighting - kinda like nintendo japanese robot fighting game, while you control robots along with two AI controlled allies battle with other schools in order get more parts to build stronger robots to further advance to harder robots

Drinking - this one is kinda lame unless you like dating sim conversation mini games where you answer bar girls question while getting drunker and drunker and your English have to be at least decent to score. 
------------------------------
- Mahjong - is much easier compared to among 5-6 different yakuza games i played.. you tend you draw better tiles in my honest opinion. definitely easiest way to earn money if you are well versed with the rules. 

- Stories & Side quests - Totally made more sense and interesting storylines and cases compared to like a dragon series mini games. Yakuza series have some good ones but plenty of bad ones like chasing a person in order to get back a toy for a kid. Some of the side quests in Lost judgement are so smartly crafted that you kinda learn something in real life that you can brag with your non gaming friends such as the quest ( mask of the Chaos author)

- Story is even darker than Yakuza series ( meaning you might even see innocent NPCs you cared for DIE ) compared to Yakuza series where you know that guy should die, he dies, or even when you think he should die but never dies no matter how many times you think he is going to die. Making it even more important to invest in the game to bring justice to bad guys.

- traveling is awesome as you can unlock the fastest skateboard to glide around town in a very fast fashion.

CONS
- stealth quests are kinda lame and one sided sometimes it made no sense. definitely the main factor making the game looks dumb.

- moves have no to very few explanation, such as EX surrender, when you upgrade skills you sometimes don't know what they do because they are meant to enhance a skill that you don't even know how to do at the first place.

- No karaoke, no Pool table

- No load game function, need to go return to title if you wanted to load ( they fixed this in Like a Dragon:Infinite Wealth )

- No fast travel system like Like a Dragon:Infinite Wealth

- No weapon customization

This game is absolutely incredible. 

Honestly, this was my first venture into a proper JRPG since Final Fantasy 7 in my teens‚Ä¶I‚Äôm 36 now and had hit an age where I was finding it hard to get anywhere near the levels of immersion from games as I did as a child. 

My God this game had me as immersed as I possibly could be. 

Every night once the wife and I put our kid down to sleep, I got to go and live my life as Tak in this game. I wasn't a dad in my mid thirties anymore, I was a lean, mean crime fighting machine with former triads as friends and such combat ability I feel like I could kick Donnie Yen's ass.

I wanted to take part in every school club, complete every side quest, and explore every inch of the city and then there‚Äôs the combat. 

Holy hell it‚Äôs the most satisfying combat system I‚Äôve ever come across. The graphics, the realism, in some cases the difficulty - it‚Äôs SO satisfying. 

But most of all, this game had me feeling like I was the living character in one of the all time great films - the storyline, the character progression, the surprised, the intelligence in the script and crime solving side, the gang vibes - this finally gave me the feeling I‚Äôd longed for, for a long time. 

That feeling when as you play, in the moment, almost from the get go, you tell yourself ‚Äúthis is one of those experiences that once I‚Äôve completed it I wish I could erase my memory and do it again, so I‚Äôm going to make the most of this and savour every second‚Äù. And boy did I. 

And yes, you will too. I cannot think of a single flaw in this game, I got to enjoy - 

Skateboarding. 

Building and fighting robots. 

Detective/mystery club. 

Dance club (yup, even this had me completely hooked) 

Motorcycle racing 

Drone racing 

And so much more. 

I have this game right up with the heaviest of my nostalgia rankings - 

FF7, Mass Effect Trilogy, Red Dead 2, Skyrim, Fallout 3/New Vegas, Half Life 2 when it first came out. 

Don‚Äôt live your life counting yourself as any sort of gamer, until you‚Äôve played this, at least try it, you won't regret it!

Judgment/Lost Judgment have very easily found themselves sitting comfortably in my top 10 games of all time, just astounding games from top to bottom that give me genuine laughs, genuine tears and gods honest enjoyment from the moment I picked them up to the moment I finished them. I feel like I could go off on an absolute tangent at just how much I feel that games like this can shine such a positive and impactful light on gaming as a whole...amazing story telling, crazy fun combat (that improved considerably from the first title), deep characters that connect everything together in a perfect unforgettable package...and the side stories are just so funny, they even slipped a "these nuts" line in there that took me completely by surprise and had me cackling for a while. All I will say beyond that though is, if you're considering buying it just get it, you won't regret it.

Like all the Ryu ga Gotoku games, Lost Judgment is good, and worth playing, but I'm sad to say that I think Lost Judgment is the first game in the extended series to really disappoint me.  

I often put up with rough mechanics to watch an interesting story, or allow fun combat to carry me through a plodding arc, but Lost Judgment is the first of these games to just feel clumsy on all counts, and I hope it is not indicative of the direction of future games.  

Compared to the games on either side of this one, Judgment and Like a Dragon: Ishin!, both of which I enjoyed, this one feels like a misstep,  Certainly, Like a Dragon: Gaiden is incredible, so hopefully they bring those developments to bear on the Judgment series as well.

The story requires suspension of disbelief at essentially every turn.  I felt the same way about Judgment, but I chalked that up to my experience with the pharmaceutical industry, which most people wouldn't be expected to share.  That's fair.

By comparison, I'm not an expert on Japanese jurisprudence -- maybe they really don't have clear laws against overt contempt of court or blatant criminal conspiracy in Japan -- but I found Lost Judgment's insistence upon the untouchability of its linchpin antagonist very hard to swallow.  

Every chapter makes at least one substantial leap of logic, sometimes even contradicting an assumption that needed to be true for a previous leap to be accepted.

It's also depressing.  Making a video game about bullying is a tough sell to begin with, but when your ethical dilemma is whether or not it is acceptable to /torture and murder/ bullies who drive others to suicide, you have to be real careful that your protagonists don't lose sight of the fact that IT IS NOT OKAY, and start treating the villains like they are worthy of admiration, which totally happens here.  By the end of this thing, I didn't want to be on /anybody's/ side.

The combat just feels... incomplete.  They introduce the new Snake stance very early as a way to engage high school delinquents without injuring them, but it quickly becomes apparent that it is far superior to either Tiger or Crane stance in the vast majority of circumstances, at least without upgrades.  It deflects attacks from behind, disarms basic combatants with a free QTE, and turns enemies into projectile weapons at the end of almost every combo.  

It is GREAT FUN, but it is so effective that I finished 90% of the game on Normal or Hard without ever spending a single point on a skill.  Eventually, I was getting one-shotted often enough by bosses that some health upgrades were a must.

Street combat is always trivial, even on Hard, but boss combat is dangerously unpredictable on Easy, full of staggering interrupts, unblockable stun combos, and even instant-kill QTEs.  You can have a boss down to their magic pixel after a long fight, only for them to lock you into an unblockable that eats half your health and downs you, starting you over.  This happened to me often enough that I started to use extracts (magic potions) to cheese my way through boss fights on the second attempt, simply because I wasn't willing to put in the time again.

You encounter bosses with four and five health bars quite early on.  It feels like the combat engine designers took this one off, and their B team throws the kitchen sink at you to keep you from realizing.  None of the big fights in this game feel challenging, they are just over-long and full of cheats and damage sponges.  The game pulls shenanigans like three back-to-back corridor fights against a boss with a hard counter against frontal assault, not to mention his regenerating entourage.  It just feels like punishment.

The game also misuses its detective game mechanics; instead of having you find one thing in a room or choose one piece of evidence to reveal, on a number of occasions the game forces you to find all six elements of a parkour course in first-person before you can attempt it, or forces you to cycle through eight of the ten articles of evidence in your possession to have the plot re-explained to you so you can progress, but still laughs at you if you choose one of the remaining two equally irrelevant pieces of evidence.

At one point, the game takes away your smartphone, and when combat starts you realize it really has, removing your character's ability to access your inventory, equipment, crafting, and settings menus.  That's not clever design, it's desperation.  To add insult to injury, pausing the game in this circumstance informs you, "You don't have a smartphone right now!" and upon unpausing, your character does a little pocket-patting dance that causes him to drop anything in his hands and become uncontrollable. 

Even considering all of this, there is still a fun game in Lost Judgment, but the one thing I really can't forgive is how often the game goes back to the well of snatching defeat from the jaws of victory -- on many, many occasions, you spend a ton of time and effort defeating a boss only for them to win anyway.  

I understand that sometimes it is necessary to have an incomplete victory to progress the plot, but I mean, these are literal cases of the boss you just brought to zero health sucker punching you in a cutscene, and then utilizing that advantage to get one over on you, whether that means stealing a plot device, hurting you, or hurting someone you care about.  There are better ways to handle this.  I've played ten RGG games that handle it better.

If the player wins, let them win.  If you can't afford to let the player win, don't let them fight.

On a final point, I really enjoyed the high school framing of the major minigames and subplots, but choosing to organize it as an unlocking progress tree was a mistake.  You can still make progress on the side story if you are not good at the minigames, but man is it slow, and if you don't like one of the minigames, you're forced to do it over and over again anyway to get to the next one, which might also suck.

The dance club rhythm game is fun.  Virtua Fighter 5 is Virtua Fighter 5.  The robotics club... 1990s edutainment... thing... is unthinkably terrible, in a game that also includes drone customization and real live third-person camera drone racing.

Contrast Like a Dragon: Gaiden's Akame Network, which is there when you want it and completely unobtrusive otherwise.  I understand folks thinking that was too simplistic -- it probably was -- but I appreciated being able to do substories on my time and at my speed.

A lot of development resources went into Seiryo High School, to the point that it is almost a third city destination, and I think I would have rathered a less anemic Kamurocho or Ijincho, both of which feel empty in comparison to earlier games.

Bleh, I dunno.  It's fine, honestly; I was just led to expect better by this studio's track record.

Amazing how what is essentially yet another entry in the Yakuza franchise can tell a complex, nuanced and mildly depressing crime story
- without resorting to fantastical gang wars and crimeworld politics
- skipping all the wild plot twists and turns
- remaining grounded in societal and legal realities of Japan.
The writing doesn't get much better than this in all of Yakuza games, proving the studio is capable of mature storylines beyond just Kyriu and the gang.

Solid improvement over previous entry.
If you liked the previous game, or Ryu Ga Gotoku studio (RGG) games in general this is not a miss.

To speak in broad terms, this game, much like its predecessor is RGG's attempt at making a detective protagonist.
Keyword is attempt, as at the end of the day this is still an RGG game, and as with all RGG games, the protagonist defeats a small army by the end of it.
Final chapter in particular has him (along with 3 basically useless AIs) going against around 100 enemies + 2 tanky bosses.
That's not to say that the story sucks, there is no mystery, or there is no sleuthing taking place.
All of that is definitely present, and is at a more than acceptable level.
There is a well-presented mystery, and what I found an interesting story.
What I am trying to complain about is that this is not so much a "detective" game as it is an action brawler.
At the end of the day, it is not the evidence you gather that brings you closer to the truth, but rather beating basically everyone into submission.
It works as far as RGG games go, but if you are looking for a more "mystery solving" game, this is not it.

I would say that I liked the story of this game more than its predecessor.
As with previous title, I think that the protagonist does not deliver his point across strongly enough.
Once again, I find that the antagonist is very relatable, even more so than Yagami (the protagonist) himself.
Antagonist makes a clear point as to why he does what he does, and why he sees it as necessary.
He has collaborators who agree with him, and the antagonist does his damn hardest to not compromise them.
This is to the point where he stays steadfast in his conviction to not harm his (in his opinion most important) collaborator after being betrayed by them, and even crying when they decide to take Yagami's side and give themselves to the police.
Meanwhile, Yagami's main argument seemed to have revolved around one bystander dying, which kinda begs the question if that's the only problem he had with the antagonist's actions.

I do not have much to say about graphics and gameplay of this title.
It runs on the modern RGG engine, and has gotten the same treatment as all RGG games.
There are a lot of side activities to be had, definitely more than is necessary.
Graphics look nice, game runs smoothly (even on linux).
Compared to previous game, I would say there have been massive improvements.
Combat got better compared to previous title.
There is a new style (technically two), and it is an absolute pleasure to use.
For once, I start to feel that the combat is not just a DPS race slugfest, but actually skill based.
There were still a few annoyances that left it feeling like the dumb slugfest, but overall, an improvement.
SP is much easier to procure in this game, I felt like there was barely enough for anything in previous game, whereas in this one I was swimming in it, and got basically all upgrades I wanted half-way in (though I did grind for a few hours out of personal volition).
This entry also does away with the annoying "mortal wounds" mechanic of the previous game, there is no longer a need to deal with annoying health limitations.
This is also probably the first game since Yakuza 0 that actually got me somewhat interested in its side content.
"School stories" is an interesting take, but ultimately I gave up because I could not be bothered to go through the dancing segments that you are forced to take.

To summarize, this is a solid entry in RGG's lineup.
People who are familiar with RGG's games can expect more of the same goodness.
People who are unfamiliar are in for a pleasant trip to Kamurocho and Ijincho (though, perhaps grab and do the first game beforehand. It is not required, but would provide context)

[b]plot:[/b] never have i been so captivated with an rgg game‚Äôs plot, so much so that i kept creating theories on how every plot line somehow weaved together, even in my free time when i definitely should‚Äôve been not thinking about this goddamn game ‚Äî truly one of the most refreshing, complex and nuanced takes on the grey zones that arise from the law, and the differences between justice vs punishment. the mystery surrounding the story is easy to grasp and so fun to try to make of every clue that pops up. at times, i felt there were some sequences that felt a little out of place or not necessary to the plot at large, but i ended up having a blast going through the motions with them anyways, regardless of their purpose. i also (as always) really appreciate how rgg tackles grey issues, and how the solution is never just black or white. this game explicitly touched on that sentiment and it was executed so well that even i felt myself switching sides every other chapter and rooting for characters i didn‚Äôt think i should‚Äôve been rooting for. the ending left me with a truly hollowed, empty gut feeling that i haven‚Äôt experienced since i finished yakuza: like a dragon, and i wouldn‚Äôt trade it for the world. i‚Äôm so glad this game exists. [b]9.8/10[/b]

[b]characters:[/b] i mean cmon what‚Äôs not to love?!? i admit i might be a little biased with my love of the found family trope but this ragtag team of losers won over my heart last game, but this just solidified it tenfold. the characters introduced this game were absolutely fascinating to watch whether they were a poor school teacher or an absolute terrifying almost psychopath seeking what he thinks is justice. each character was given time to be explored (except maybe koda, sadly) and their motivations, feelings, and actions all made sense in their own contexts. this game introduces my favorite yakuza antagonist of all time, and some of my favorite protagonists too. yagami is never not a joy to play and his crew is just so heartwarming to watch pal around. i need a beach filler episode. [b]10/10[/b]

[b]side content:[/b] oh jesus christ where do i even start man‚Ä¶ there is SO much side content. so much. i don‚Äôt think it‚Äôs as much as other yakuza games but my god it feels like a dauntingly large amount of side content to get through, especially the school stories. not that it‚Äôs necessarily a bad thing, i‚Äôve had so much fun with every minigame this game has thrown at me with it seemingly getting more goofy as time goes on. i imagine when i go on to 100% this eventually i‚Äôll grow tired of filling squares with robots or boxing the shit out of people but for now i‚Äôm having a blast. seriously, there has to be at least one minigame in this game that you‚Äôll become obsessed with and complete the kamurogo in one sitting. OH YEAH SUBSTORIES ‚Äî they introduced a new way of finding side cases through chatter, where you then find the source of the sub story by either observing, sound amping, dog smelling, or frequency detecting. this has been such a fun mechanic to play around with and hasn‚Äôt felt tedious at all as of typing this (could change at the drop of a hat who knows). yagami is so funny in his straight man humor that each side case is a blast to play through. [b]9.8/10[/b]

[b]voice acting (jp):[/b] fucking. incredible. not a moment went by where i felt taken out of the moment by distracting voice acting and everybody just knocks it out of the park. we got TWO!!! screams this game and both were heart breaking in their raw emotion and delivery that i had to pause and take it in. each voice perfectly fits the character and it‚Äôs just such a treat to listen to. [b]10/10[/b]

[b]ost:[/b] just listen to viper brah. dig in your heels. unwavering belief. there wasn‚Äôt a single track that i wasn‚Äôt bopping my head to. even the substory chase music (as goofy as it is) was so endearingly stupid that i swung back around to loving it. the jazz mixed with techno works surprisingly well and perfectly encapsulates how this game feels. will be listening to the ost on repeat until the end of time. [b]10/10[/b]

[b]gameplay:[/b] okay i don‚Äôt think anybody likes the tailing missions i‚Äôll be honest BUT they majorly improved how shitty it was from judgment. they even introduced a stealth mechanic which i honestly felt was coming down the pipe at some point and i‚Äôm so glad they implemented it. yagami is such an athletic person that the parkour mechanic was so in character i barely even blinked twice, plus it's so fun to climb buildings to find vantage points on your foes and stuff. i didn‚Äôt have any massive complaints about the gameplay, except maybe how frequently they make you go back and forth to sleep at the office and take a taxi and shit when they could just let me get on with the story, although i understand why they implemented that. ALSO SKATEBOARDING HELLO??? [b]9/10[/b]

[b]combat:[/b] the best i‚Äôve played from any rgg game, beating out ishin. it just felt so fluid, and we get four styles. each punch and kick had an impact and the sound design associated with each style is so mesmerizingly unique and a treat to my ears and eyes. i couldn‚Äôt even express to you how much i‚Äôve happy laughed at some EX moves, with how stupidly cool they look and how much pain i‚Äôd be in if i were on the other end of yagami‚Äôs shoe. tag team moves were a pleasure to watch as always!!! one thing they changed (at least in hard mode?? i think) was adding more difficult qtes and i fucking love it. the stakes have never been higher in these fights cause if you mess up some of these qtes, you either insta die or have to redo the qte while your foe reheals. it‚Äôs just such a nice change of pace from other rgg games where i felt the qtes were almost too easy and i never felt challenged enough in boss fights. speaking of boss fights oh my god these dynamic intros are hands down the best i‚Äôve seen period. like we‚Äôve peaked here i don‚Äôt need to see any more it‚Äôs truly insane. It is infuriating to me that RGG studios goes on to make one of the best combat systems ever and then does everything it possibly can to divert player's attention and total playtime from that.

Lost Judgment is a game full of varied content to do and it is what this game suffers from the most. It is obvious that this is the product of cultivation of both years of preceding RGG games and a great effort. There are more than 30 minigames in this game and tons of other things to do. 
So, what is the problem then?

1- Minigames are hardly play-tested or ever balanced. In any minigame with AI opponents, from classics like Mahjong or Poker to new minigames like drone racing or motorcycle races, AI will cheat %100 of the time and you have to use specific anti-AI tactics to win. It does not matter how good you play the minigames, if you don't specifically play around AI's cheats, you are going to lose.

2- Even if you don't wish to complete everything and it's just that you want to see every cutscene instead, you are going to play a good chunk of those 30 minigames. Now, look, let's say that they were all perfectly made minigames (They are not); no one is going to like every single one of them. If you lock certain content behind those minigames, you have to make sure that every single one of them are as enjoyable as rest of the game. Unfortunately, they are not and although there were some of them I liked to play as much as the base game, there were an equal amount of, perhaps even more, minigames I absolutely detested playing. And that will be the case for a lot of people. You can't expect people to like all of those minigames.

3- After all those complaining about abundance of minigames, this might sound ironic but: Lost Judgment needed another minigame, or I should say, a content where you actually can play the game's brilliantly made fun combat system. RGG studios, in their infinite wisdom, decided to remove Arena from Judgment series albeit it was present in its predecessors. Hell, Like a Dragon: Gaiden has just came out and Arena plays a major role in that game. Why wouldn't they just let us play the game in an environment tailored to test our skills? Currently, if you wish to play the game itself after finishing the main story, there are only 2 options: You either have to go around streets, beating up laughably weak punks or you have to go into Gauntlet mode from main menu, in which you are limited in all aspects (Which items you may use, which combat styles you may use etc.). Ironically, in this game that is full of content to do, there is no content to fight against strong enemies, using everything we have farmed for so far.

I know the first 2 points are present in all RGG studios' games but I have not written a review for them so I'm mentioning them here, since they also apply to Lost Judgment. As for third point, it's truly unfortunate that they withhold such content from us in the game that's considered to have the best combat of the entire series by majority of the RGG fanbase. And rightfully so, Lost Judgment has 4 vastly differing combat styles, all fleshed out and fun-to-play with. Although they could have done a better job with style-switching buttons. It was far better in Yakuza 0 whereas styles were assigned to all different buttons rather than a single button to switch to them in-order, one-by-one.

That all being said, I wrote all these because I truly like this game and I would have loved it if they had added the missing pieces because all the potential was there. Lost Judgment is a great game and worth both your time and money. In case you may want to skip all the side content, you still have 35 hours of main story to play to your heart's content.

Lost Judgment is a thrilling detective game that combines a gripping story, engaging characters, and diverse gameplay. You play as Takayuki Yagami, a former lawyer who now works as a private investigator in Tokyo. You are hired to solve a mysterious murder case that involves a high school bullying scandal, deepfake technology, and a powerful criminal organization. Along the way, you will explore the vibrant city of Yokohama, fight against various enemies using three different combat styles, and participate in a variety of side activities, such as skateboarding, dancing, and more.

Lost Judgment excels at creating a realistic and immersive world that draws you in with its rich details, dynamic events, and lively NPCs. The main story is well-written and full of twists and turns that keep you hooked until the end. The characters are memorable and have their own personalities, motivations, and backgrounds. The voice acting and facial animations are superb and convey the emotions and expressions of the characters. The gameplay is varied and fun, offering you a lot of freedom and choice in how you approach each situation. You can stealthily infiltrate a building, chase down a suspect on foot or by car, brawl with thugs using martial arts, or use your detective skills to find clues and evidence. You can also enjoy the many side quests and mini-games that add humor, depth, and challenge to the game.

Lost Judgment is a game that will appeal to fans of detective stories, action games, and Japanese culture. It is a game that will make you feel like a real detective, a badass fighter, and a curious explorer. It is a game that will make you laugh, cry, and think. It is a game that you will not regret playing.

When I played the first Judgment, I thought that it couldn't be topped. The first game compared to the other Yakuza games within the new flashy dragon engine (Kiwami 2, and Yakuza 6) looked like a tech demo compared to Judgment. But I am shocked and astonished to admit that the sequel not only expands on the gameplay in the first game but also makes Judgment look like a demo.

Gameplay - Even without the new and technique heavy snake style which straight up slaps, the two previous styles have been massively fine tuned. Tiger is still bursty as ever, and crane is no longer complete garbage. They gave crane that juicy attack speed buff when you evade that the whole style desperately needed, along with a new mechanic called "Crane Dance" which flips Yagami in the air to either evade or pull off special combos or EX actions. Where in the previous game I would be permanently in tiger style, here you really do have to switch to crane at least once in a fight to get some nice damage in. But onto the snake style, just whoever came up with the combos, and system for snake holy shit i love them. If you time your guard just right you can just completely parry an enemies attacks and fear them into a 1 shot EX action just like that. Hell, they even re-did previous reused EX actions in the last game and gave it a brand new fresh coat of paint and im all for it, helps keeps things exciting! Im happy to also see that toned down trailing missions which really wore their welcome in the previous game after the first few, but also reworked it a bit to where you can now hide just about anywhere and you dont have to go to scripted areas to shelter yourself from the enemies site. They also added two new sections you can run into being stealth and parkour. Now stealth is an amazing idea for Yagami on paper. It makes more sense for a detective to sneak around enemy locations than the typical long fight brawl and bashing your way into enemy territory like a yakuza. Dont get me wrong the long fights are still spectacular, but from a logic standpoint its like the fuck. But actually doing stealth is really janky, sometimes enemies just decide they have a sixth sense and can look behind them at random while you're crossing from them and when they spot you, thats it you're toast, and sometimes there are just kill barriers that instantly get you spotted whenever going to a specific spot, and its just overall janky. The parkour segments on the other hand, are handled quite nicely and have different mechanics like wall running and pipe swinging to keep things spiced up. Overall, great gameplay switch ups aside from a few hickups.

Setting - You travel between two cities in this game, Kamurocho which was the main location of the last game, and Isezaki Ijincho of Yokohama! Its great to see the funny rpg game map from Yakuza: Like a Dragon shown to us in real time combat, and im also happy to see both cities get equal enough game time to keep you entertained. Isezaki Ijincho was a little weird tho, with some places like the bottom half of the redlight district, and commercial district being cut off by objects and sometimes invisible walls that was accessible in Yakuza: Like a dragon, but in turn adding a brand new area being the Seriyo School acting as a sort of hub for a bit of the side content of the game.

Mini games - I am was anticipating this game's side content quite a bit because i've heard that there were quite a bit of different things to do within Yokohama, but wow I was just blown away at how much that was just thrown at me. Not talking about the elephant in the room being the "Side Content" which ill explain below this point, the normal mini games we have are still quite a blast. VR paradise and drone racing return from Judgment with a new fresh coat of paint with new coarses or a complete new overhaul to how the game works. Arcelios is brand new and is found within the VR paradise location where you blast different enemy types as fast as you can while surviving with different abilities, and wow was it surprisingly addicting, I swear its always the mini games that im least excited for that catch me off guard and gets me wanting more.

Side Content - Usually these games give you a side content story cultivating with usually a big mini game, like business mini game in Yakuza 7, and 0, or cabaret mini game in Yakuza Kiwami 2, and 0, but this game really took it to the next level and gave us a whole bunch of mini games connected to each other through a story that progresses the more and more you complete different mini games. Going back to the Seriyo School hub that they added to the game, reason I said hub is because this is where most of the mini games to this side story take place, if not start here. Mini games ranging from different school activities like robotics (which was super addicting customizing a robot team and then heading into pve combat arenas) or dance club (with a complete banger ost and dancing combos that hit you with straight dopamine), or to boxing (which the more you progress through the boxing story and more skills you learn within the boxing mini game, the more those moves can be applied into outdoors combat in a whole new 4th style just called "boxer"), and thats just half of it. None of the different mini games within the side story felt like filler or bloat, I found everything enjoyable whether it was instantly or took some growing on to.

Extras - Im happy to see the return of the proving grounds or ultimate battles renamed as "The Gauntlet" in the brand new dragon engine and yep its def. a challenge giving you spins on fights, focusing on a specific technique, or showing off a gameplay switchup like that 10 minute stealth section that can go fuck itself. A new cool thing with the gauntlet is that you can get items from first time completions like either extraction potions to help buff you, gear, or completely cosmetically items, and collectibles such as records. Honestly was just really cool to look forward to after completing a chapter, and acted as a sort of break from the story and tear fest.

This game not only improves on its predecessor in every way possible, but also is the best title in the Ryu Ga Gotoku series, if you're looking for beat em up combat.

[h1] Strong combat, weak story [/h1]

The combat is undoubtedly one of the best RGGS has to offer, but as fan of yakuza/judgment stories which IMO is still so much more important I have to say Lost Judgment's story is the absolute weakest I've experienced so far. 
Whereas in the first game Judgment it was incredibly interesting to learn about the "fallen" lawyer Yagami, his backstory and motivation, and experience his character growth, 
the sequel offers nowhere near as much character development time: Yagami stays the same from beginning to the end, his character story incredibly bland, frustratingly boring to watch.
There are some major moments, where the game could have used them to make him more interesting, but no, after some tiny emotional outbursts or occasional brain fogs he returns back to the same old calm, wise character.
The school setting of the main story is refreshing, the horrible problems of school bullying are handled well (shout out to Sawa-Sensei) but it just doesn't help when the protagonist remains so bland for the majority of the game.
So what about the other returning characters? 

I liked... Kaito and Shirosaki, I guess, but what about the rest?
You could delete Sugiura and replace his tiny parts with Kaito, absolutely nothing of value would be lost.
Tsukumo aka "Hackerman", the typical boring plot device, to make some occasional discoveries.
Hoshino? Laughable, I don't even want to talk about him.
What they did to Genda hurt me, I liked the old mentor in judgment who never gave up on Yagami, influencing his character growth. Here? Nearly invisible. 
Mafuyu, fan favorite, the same treatment.
Lost Judgment massacred so many cool characters from the first game, that I wonder if the writers were suffering from burnouts or were just simply replaced by worse ones.

Oh, and don't get me started with the antagonists.
There are so many repetitive, redundant moments in the story where Yagami and one of the main antagonists meet up, bicker about their motives, over and over again. 
Maybe trying to overcompensate for the lack of depths of the other antagonists?

So what about the side stories?
Oh boy. Ignoring the disgusting fact that SEGA or RGGS hid some of the better ones behind locked DLCs, the majority of the stories are a boring mess. 
I just finished the game, and for the love of God, I seriously can't remember most of them (besides the school side stuff) because how utterly bland they were.
I liked the mystery club, boxing, and some others, one of the highlights of the side stories. But when you compare them to the rest, it's just... sad. 

Ryu Ga Gotoku can do so much better, they showed it over and over again.
But maybe they should take a step back, and invest more time?

Solid game, lots of stuff to do, but unfortunately even this second game can't keep me engaged at all when the law is involved, just because of how utterly horrifyingly awful its workings are.

It's probably for someone, but absolutely not for me, the styles and general flow of fights just doesn't work for me, nor does the story as it loses emotional investment the instant it goes towards the detective side of things, and generally I just don't like Yagami as a main character whatsoever, and I'm not sure whether it's because he has no charm, or I've been spoiled by the charm and depth of... well, all the Yakuza games and characters, every single one.

I am going to recommend this game for the portrayal of bullying and the consequences it has. I was bullied during my school years a lot and it let me a lot of scars and trauma for me to battle them. That aspect of the game was done wonderfully and accurately. I believe that in the rest of the game that it lacks good writing (or at least on-par with the first one).
Gameplay-wise, this is really incredible. Very few slow tailing missions, almost none lockpicking (which is made easier) and more gadgets to play with. The combat is a big step up from Judgement. On the final chapters, when I unlocked many of his abilities, Yagami feels really good to control to. He may not be as powerful as Kiryu or Saejima, but I think he reached the level of fun that Akiyama had in Y4. I really liked how they nerfed Tiger and buffed Crane, as well as the new style Turtle. This is the only game in the whole Yakuza/LAD franchise that I used every style the same and I didn't prefer one.  
Story-wise, in the early chapters and the school stories are really good. I didn't really like any of the side-cases, which is a bummer because I play this games to have some laugh with the sub-stories as much as to get sad with the main story. The latter chapters have a lot of bad pacing and a lot of stuff are repeated. I think I read the same dialogue up to five times in one hour. Some story-bits are even taken directly from the first game like [spoiler] Saori infiltrating the cabaret club  [/spoiler]. Some characters from the first game that returned didn't have the same charm they had, like Siguira and even Yagami. Yagami's whole character arc from the first game is almost forgotten in this one.
That being said, I really enjoyed my time and I may have said that it's the series best brawler if I hadn't played The Man Who Erased His Name mid-way through my play through of this one. I haven't played Kaito's File as of the time of writing this review, but I will write a separate review there.

A fantastic sequel to a fantastic game part of a fantastic world.

Your role is detective and former Lawyer Takayuki Yagami. Called to Ijincho to investigate a suicide at Seijo High School your case quickly begins to tangle itself with a few other plotlines which I won;t talk about for spoilers.

Lost Judgment is an absolutely gorgeous game. I don't know how RGG does it but they are on top of it in the graphics department. It's easy to see the beautifully crafted world around you but small details such as pants wrinkling as you move creates a highly detailed world.

The combat is excellent and fluid. You are given 2 fighting styles and unlock 2 more for a total of 4 fighting styles. Crane and Tiger return giving hefty upgrades and REAL utility to the crane style while nerfing Tiger so it's not busted easy to beat foes (seriously, that 1-inch punch-like move made the game a cake walk). Snake is a style that has you focusing only effectively catching attacks and and swiftly striking back although most of this is done through heat button prompts. Boxing is a style borrowing moves from the later unlockable boxing side quest. The fact that you can juggle most bosses makes this style head and shoulders above the rest. All are fun to play and have their utility throughout the game.

I won't talk a lot about the story but it's well crafted, detailed and puts you through a rollercoaster of emotions.

As of now I have not completed Kaito Files, will update my review when completed.

A great sequel to the first game - Judgment.  Really enjoy the unique high school elements in the detective mystery plot as well as the many returning characters both in the main story and side cases as well.

Combat wise, it was welcoming to see a new snake style being incorporated as well as reworking crane style to be a more effective way for crowd control.  It was also interesting to see more varied gameplay elements such as the stealth and parkour missions being mixed in to add flavor.

Another aspect that I thoroughly enjoyed was the school stories which had a nice plot (twist) that tied everything together as well as brought back the prior side content villains from previous game to evoke some recognition and nostalgia.

In addition, the Kaito files expansion was also an interesting extension as you get to play Kaito as the main character and experience his unique fighting styles as well as learn more about his past background.  Really delighted to see that they gave him a happy ending for this expansion as well.

Overall, Lost Judgment has been such a fun game to play and I really enjoyed exploring/skating around the new backdrop of Ijincho to solve all the cases.  Very much looking forward to the next Yagami installment when it is released.

This is a really good fucking game. I've been a fan of RGG's work ever since I played Yakuza 0 back in 2021, which prompted me to chew through the remainder of the Yakuza series over the months thereafter. I had always heard about the Judgment games, being as much of a fan as I am, but I hadn't been able to get at them for a while, being a PC-only gamer. Having them come to Steam some time ago was really exciting, and I picked them up immediately. Both of these games are worthwhile for any Yakuza fan, and I'd really recommend them to just about anyone. They do the beat 'em up style combat better than most of the entries in the Yakuza franchise and with the series being so new, there isn't a lot of games to chew through, making the barrier of entry much lower. This is the second game of the series, and is seriously worth every penny. The story is immaculate, the combat is some of the best I've experienced in a game (aside from my precious Sekiro), and there is just so much to do in this game, as well as all the Yakuza games. I first beat this game some time ago. But recently I decided to take it upon myself to get this game to 100% completion, both for in-game and for Steam. This was the first time I had ever done this for a Yakuza game (aside from Gaiden, which was fairly easy, and I did most of Yakuza 7's trophies; but I had never done a 100% of the in-game completion list before). Safe to say, this is probably the last time I will ever do that. It took me almost 100 hours to get the job done. Going through the main story again, through the entirety of the school stories, the side cases, some of the gauntlets, and all of the different minigames as well as the challenges set forth in the TownGo completion list. All of it. I did all of it. Was it worth it? Yeah, kinda. But I will never do that again. The sheer agony of having to do the school stories (I'm looking at you, biker gang) for twelve hours back-to-back was a pain I never thought I'd experience. Having to learn koi-koi, mahjong, and all the arcade games I suck at was absolute miserable (except koi-koi, that was really fun). This game truly is a gem, alongside all the rest of RGG's games. Please, play this game's predecessor first then come back to this one, even if you've never played Yakuza. It really is that good. But, I will warn you now: only dare to 100% a Yakuza game if you have days upon days of disposable time on your hands. Only dare to do it if you are prepared to do all the worst challenges and minigames in these games because, I promise you, you will have to do them. It is a challenge not for the greatest of gamers, but for the most dedicated of them. That is my warning to you.

Let me start with the good. 
The story was interesting. It certainly was the main reason to keep playing, even if it were just the first half (after which I thought the game was over but it just kept going forever). 
Another good thing is that something about the environment, the atmosphere or whatever it was had some sort of appeal, which had me launch the game time after time despite the many times I got annoyed. 

Now, one of the main reasons I didn't like the game: The constant combat encounters. You know in Pokemon, how, when you walk through bushes, there is a good chance you encounter a pokemon? 
Often you don't want to fight, but it just keeps happening. Luckily, you can avoid these bushes and walk out. 

Well. Here it is kinda like that except you can't leave these bushes. There is encounter after encounter after encounter. You wanna go to building X? Oh, here is a random group of thugs. What, you dealt with them? Well here you go, a bunch of aggressive high schoolers. Done? Well there ya go, the next group is coming your way. 

It really was a choir for me. I just wanted to see the story and move through the main missions, but these constant fights forced me to use the taxi to go everywhere. Which is quite expensive, and still had you move to locations. 

Another really bothersome thing was the lack of a challenge. The game held your hand all the way til the very end. Combat was so simple, on the highest difficulty I couldn't be bothered trying to understand it remotely. You have different buttons, combos, stances... well I don't know what the stances were for, what they did, how to get them. I just mashed buttons and I won everything easily. There are many ways to grow stronger... well. I left that all aside. Button mashing and done. 

It wasn't just combat. You are a detective. Except you, as a player, do none of that. There is no thinking involved. Trying to find evidence just meant clicking on stuff in a room. A stealth mission was literally: Walk to a square, get a pop up with the button to press, press it, wait, and then walk to the next square. It felt insulting. 

The main reason why I wouldn't recommend the game: So the button mashing thing in combat was something I did in the first four hours or so. At that point, I finally encountered an opponent where I'd have to try a little. I died. And then I died again. So, I was like... okay. Not bad, I may have to try to understand the game a little now. And then came the pop up 'do you want to change the difficulty to normal'? 

Every time I'd die, the game would ask me that. I got annoyed so much that I just accepted in hopes it'd stop, but no. It did not. It'd then ask to change to simple and during simple it still asks that....

This game is better than most of the Yakuza mainline games. It had refined the Dragon Engine's Combat into a masterpiece.

[h3] The Combat [/h3]

Lost Judgement's combat is godly. They improved many things, like the combat, from the Judgement series. Yagami has 4 styles now, and they are the: Tiger, Crane (These 2 are in the original judgement), and the new Snake, and Boxer Style. Tiger style is still an extremely good style against a foe; however, they nerfed flux fissure obviously. Crane style got an extremely helpful buff from Judgement since every style has their own "skill chart", making the once rather universal crane (Most of the skills are universal skills), to a better crane with actual style specific moves. Crane also had received the holy power to juggle enemies by countering, and getting a very BIG speed boost (This speed boost is needed for combos) if you perfect dodge. The Newest Style, Snake Style, is a defensive style focusing on grabbing, disarming, and agony. The other new style is Boxer, and Boxer is obtained by uhh the Boxing Minigame in Lost Judgement. I do not use boxer that much; however, its an actual balanced style. These styles symbolically go along with Chinese Shao-Lin Kung fu, Crane, Tiger, Snake, Leopard (probably boxing), and Dragon (Kiryu). Now for the actual combat, Yagami has the ability to do a [b] Tekken [/b] on enemies and [b] Juggle [/b] them. Juggling is VERY easy in Lost Judgement, and because of that the RGG devs have added a damage resistance mechanic the longer you juggle them making you do less damage. The particle effects are very exaggerated; however, it looks so look good. Overall, Lost Judgement's Combat is an absolute masterpiece

[h3] The Prologue (Spoiler-Free, until the last paragraph) [/h3]

My personal opinion on Lost Judgement's Story is that it is less good compared to Judgement, but then again Lost Judgement has a giant web. The game starts off with a standard scam case that Yagami, and his partner, Kaito, are working on. The prologue just introduces you to mechanics that are like ditched right afterwards. Yagami tails a man named Kosuke, who is the person who is scamming your cilent, and this Tailing mission is like the only tailing mission in the main story. During the tailing of Kosuke, Yagami gets caught up in trouble by some gangster, and has to fight them in which Yagami wins but loses sight of Kosuke. Yagami does eventually find Kosuke, and tails him into a convenience store where you take your first and only photo ops mission. Afterwards, Kosuke goes into a building with many guards, so Yagami has to do parkour in order to get in the building without being detected. After Yagami gets into the building, he must sneak around avoiding guards, introducing the stealth mechanic to some main story missions. Eventually Yagami reaches the top floor where Kosuke is located, and turns out he was gambling away the Cilent's money. Yagami waits for Kosuke to leave to have a chat with him, which quickly turns into an altercation with Kosuke using Mine's moveset from Yakuza 3... Yagami beats Kosuke up, and Kosuke runs away introducing the chasing mechanic. Eventually Yagami catches Kosuke, and they go meet the boss of Kosuke where they don't have a civil discussion. Once Yagami beats up the crooks, and finishes the scam case the actual story of this game picks up. 

Yagami is soon brought back to the dangerous cases, and he is embroiled with a case with so many strands that it had created a web. [spoiler] Kuwana, a former teacher turned handyman, [/spoiler] had created this convoluted spider's web, and his story is one of vengeance against [spoiler] the Japanese Justice System [/spoiler] since they had [spoiler] let bullies walk free after they pushed student's to suicide [/spoiler]. Yagami, and [spoiler] Kuwana [/spoiler] are basically like mirrors of each other, one of them seeks justice through the means of the justice system; whilst, the other seeks their own justice through murder. They both rival each other's power with their own techniques. The spider of the web, [spoiler] Kuwana [/spoiler], had entrapped many former [spoiler] bullies [/spoiler] to helping him commit murder as a twisted view of revenge... Lost Judgement has one of the best stories in the Yakuza series; however, I still prefer the mysteries, red herrings, and the gruesome case of the Mole in Judgement.

Lost Judgement is seriously one of the best games that RGG had made, and I cant wait to see more of the Dragon Engine combat in Like A Dragon: Gaiden. The story is very good; however, I still do prefer Judgement's story over it since its more life threatening to Yagami though Lost Judgement's story is still really good compared to all the other RGG Games.

A strong contender to be the best RGG title so far. Like literally, this game took everything from first Judgment and made it better.

Keihin Gang is now a major part for a School Stories - a completly optional giant side quest that could be a standalone game in all fairness. The combat and gameplay is perfected in this game. We got 2 new styles - Snake and Boxer(i believe Boxer was a part of DLC earlier but we got it for free in PC version) Each of the four is reliable and you can mix them up for nice combos. 
The graphics is still the good old Dragon Engine. Yeah, it's been 7 years since Yakuza 6 and it's debut. The game looks okay, but I think it's finally time to give up on it. 
I didn't noticed any major bugs and the game is fairly stable, it ran well too on my not-so-great PC.
Overall I place Lost Judgment in the same place as Yakuza 5 and Yakuza 0, being now my third contender to claim my personal TOP 1 in the series.

Lost Judgment is another masterpiece in a string of them by RGG Studio. It's the absolute pinnacle of brawler combat, the story is unbelievably engaging, the side content is deep, varied, and almost always incredibly fun, and the total package the game offers is basically unparalleled by anything else the studio has ever made. It's good.

The combat is probably the biggest, brightest selling point - Yagami's three base styles mesh together extremely well, and you can find situations to maximize them all throughout the game. Tiger is as good as ever with the addition of charged moves, Crane is actually very useful now in its intended crowd setting, and Snake is maybe the most satisfying combat style RGG has ever put together. Even with Tiger and Crane being great, I had to force myself to use them from time to time and not just sit in Snake from the moment I unlocked it. The flow of it is just amazing, and you're given fantastic combat situations throughout, too - powerful, tricky bosses that make you feel accomplished for figuring out how to get around them, while you can simply smoke regular encounters on demand, and with mortal wounds gone (thank God), you don't have to worry about putting the game on hold to go restore your full health bar after getting randomly shot by some asshole on the street. Perfect!

The story...easily one of the best, of course, with a great deal of nuance and grey areas for the player to mull over as the story progresses. I'd say it's not quite as satisfying or viscerally gripping as Judgment's, but it's hard to live up to the strongest, most focused story RGG Studio's ever made, and even then, Lost Judgment does an admirable job in keeping me engaged. The returning characters develop, the new characters fascinate, and there are plenty of amazing twists and moments of absolute satisfaction that kept me locked in for hours and hours. The primary antagonist has a ton of layers, and the supplementary antagonists all spiral outwards from them in myriad ways that conveyed a strong, clear message about the story RGG Studio was telling here. Even if I personally find the antagonist a lot more reprehensible than others do, they were written astoundingly well, and the game hinges on that success.

I LOVE the side content this time around - most of it is centered on the School Stories, which basically functions as a second campaign meant to be played through alongside the main story. Amasawa is such a sweet girl, and the stories told through each of the clubs you explore tie pretty well into the game's core themes of the price of bullying and who gets to pass judgment on wrongdoers. Each club has its own minigame associated with it, and while most of these are fun and well-developed, a couple of them were significantly more frustrating and needed better balance. This is about the Robotics Club. It should have been deleted. There's no salvaging it. The rest of the clubs, though? Great. Skateboarding, love it. Boxing, AMAZING. Dancing that's mechanically similar to Haruka's idol minigame? Fantastic. Cooking the CPU in Virtua Fighter? Perfect.

Honestly, there's just SO MUCH to love about Lost Judgment, and its highs are so high that I can barely even remember the lows. I think the way Yagami is written can get a little one-note sometimes, especially in comparison to the antagonist, and as previously mentioned there are minigames necessary for School Stories progression that are absolute torture to get through. Stealth missions suck ass, the parkour segments are interesting but ultimately tedious, tailing is still horrendous even though it was downplayed significantly, and, frustratingly, the female characters get pigeonholed into passive roles more than I'd like (as usual). Even with all that, though? Lost Judgment is one of the best games I've ever played. No qualifiers. Play it.

Lost Judgment is a fantastic game with one of the best combat out of any game I've play. Mix that in with the story which is well written (it can be slow at times) as well as the yakuza style side cases, it provides an amazing experience.

While a holistically giant leap in quality from Judgment, the game still has that clunky, grindy AA-budget charm that RGG is known for, despite being a very well-renowned and established studio at this point. While I don't necessarily consider this a negative‚Äîenough to leave a negative review alone‚Äîit feels like this spin-off really exposes just how buggy and unfun RGG's games can actually be, and how much they don't want to deviate from the main series. It also feels as though this series suffers from a lower budget and expectations.

Lost Judgment starts off with a strong story that quickly becomes predictable and boring, and loses its edge due to RGG's ever-present desire to keep everything tethered to the Yakuza story experience. The supporting cast that helps in Yagami's journey barely develop at all as characters and feel hollow and incomplete in the presence of the main character's bland and neutral existence, especially in the presence of Kaito. This series was better off being a single game.

Right from the get-go, you can tell you're in for one heck of a ride. The story's as solid as a concrete bunker, and they've thrown in school stories that'll make you feel like you're back in your high school drama days ‚Äì minus the acne, of course. You'll be hooked for days, thanks to more side quests than you can shake a stick at.

Now, let's talk about our main man, Yagami. This dude's got more personality switches than a light bulb factory. Sometimes he's channeling Batman, all dark and broody, and then, out of nowhere, he's as Zen as Buddha under the Bodhi tree. I mean, seriously, at times, it feels like as if he's on the verge of imparting profound wisdom to the adversaries he faces.

But hold on to your gaming chairs, 'cause the combat in this game is smoother than a gravure idol's bottom. It's like they took the combat from the last game and gave it a steroid injection. And don't get me started on Ijincho, the new location ‚Äì it's like they doubled the size of the game overnight. (Okay, fine, they might have borrowed a page -or the whole map- from Yakuza: Like a Dragon, but hey, why reinvent the wheel, right?)

In summary, Lost Judgment is not just a game; it's an immersive journey that transcends the realm of pixels and screens. The narrative is so gripping it could inspire a bestselling novel and the combat mechanics are so finely tuned they allow you to temporarily forget the outside world. If you haven't embarked on this odyssey yet, I implore you to do so.

Lost Judgement is an incredible game and it might just be the most significant sign of RGG‚Äôs growth as a studio so far. While I really liked Judgement, Lost Judgement blows it out of the water in nearly every way. The graphics and presentation are improved, the combat is the best it has ever been in the series, the side content is engrossing and could qualify as a standalone game, the soundtrack is chill-inducing, the story is bold and thought-provoking, and the characters are iconic. Lost Judgment is up there with the best in the series and gives me a lot of hope for the future of the franchise. 

COMBAT

Lost Judgement‚Äôs combat is better paced and more liberating than Judgement‚Äôs. Yagami has three combat styles now, Tiger, Crane, and Snake. Unlike Judgement, these styles don‚Äôt overshadow each other. They all have a near-equal amount of utility. Switching between them is near instantaneous, encouraging constant style switching to meld style-specific buffs together. With all three of these buffs activated, Yagami is fast, strong, and unable to be knocked down, making him incredibly satisfying to play as. The EX actions in this game are better than ever. They are brutal, mesmerizing, hilarious, and sometimes all three. Overall, the combat in Lost Judgement is a massive improvement over its predecessor and it's some of the best I‚Äôve seen from the series.

SCHOOL STORIES

The side content in Lost Judgement is among the best I‚Äôve seen from an RGG game. Most of the side content can be found in the school stories where Yagami works as a school counselor to solve a string of crimes caused by students in order to find the mastermind behind it all. Nearly all of the school stories are fun and rewarding. The dance club was a hilarious rhythm game where Yagami did a bunch of crazy dance moves to catchy music. The robotics club was the most complicated and frustrating to me but that made it the most satisfying to complete. The boxing gym has a very fleshed-out boxing minigame which has a decent amount of depth and challenge to it. The motorcycle gang was my favorite for being the most funny, endearing, yet intense out of all of the school stories. The skateboarding minigame was very satisfying and addicting to play. Skateboarding is one of the most important additions to this game, and possibly to the series because it is a faster and more fun way of exploration throughout Yokohama. The rest of the school stories are a lot less remarkable. However, they all are worth playing because the final sequence that reveals the person behind it all is a great experience. What‚Äôs better is that everyone from all of the school stories come together and help you close the case. Most of the school stories have great character work attached to them and seeing their arcs climax in the finale is incredibly satisfying. Despite their flaws, the school stories might just be the best side content RGG has ever made and it gives me hope they can do even better in the future. 

SIDE CASES

Because of how much time the school stories take up, there aren‚Äôt nearly as many side cases as there were in Judgement, nor were they as long, but I see that as a good thing. The game also vastly improved its tailing sequences by making them less linear. I am going to name some of my favorite side cases. Dueling Dojos, The Body Model Walks At Night, and My First Errand were hilarious and sit alongside the best side content in the series. At this point, it is tradition for me to do all of the side cases (or substories) in every RGG game so I can face Amon. I‚Äôm normally pretty satisfied by the Amon fights in the series, but despite Lost Judgement's amazing combat, its Amon fight rubbed me the wrong way.

SOUNDTRACK

I think the most iconic part of Lost Judgment is its soundtrack. I initially bought Judgement and Lost Judgement because of Lost Judgement's music alone. I‚Äôm going to list my favorite tracks, starting with Lost In The Rain, the music that plays on the title screen, which is one of my favorite title screens because of its dour mood being flushed away by an optimistic white kitten. Some other great tracks are Vorarephilia, Fog, K.O.G., ÊÅ©Âøµ, Viper, Final Destination, GIRLS, and the two songs that deserve credit for putting Lost Judgement on the map, Dig In Your Heels and Unwavering Belief. Dig In Your Heels is perfect workout music that sounds like the world is at stake, despite the setting it‚Äôs played in. While Dig In Your Heels came out of nowhere, Unwavering Belief perfectly portrays the rising tension up to the beginning of the final fight and it feels as though the song represents a clashing of ideals. 

STORY

Finally, we can talk about this game‚Äôs story. I‚Äôm just going to talk about my favorite parts of the story instead of summarizing the whole thing. In comparison with Judgement, Lost Judgement‚Äôs detective story feels like I can actually follow along and make theories instead of just waiting for a twist that explains everything. It feels like a natural progression of RGG‚Äôs story structure. I really appreciate how this game went out of its way to criticize Japanese law through the lens of bullying. I‚Äôve never seen another game jab at its government‚Äôs weaknesses while treating it with respect at the same time. That brings me to my favorite part of Lost Judgement‚Äôs story, the dynamic between Yagami and Kuwana. I can‚Äôt think of another piece of media whose protagonist and antagonist were equally wrong and right. Kuwana‚Äôs pessimistic outlook on justice proclaims that since the justice system is broken, he has to punish those who are deserving, no matter the damage it causes to innocent bystanders. As a lawyer, Yagami‚Äôs optimistic view of the law makes him believe no form of self-served justice should take precedence over the law, especially if it affects innocent people. He can only hope that the law can get better if enough trust and care are put into it. RGG took a big risk in making Yagami‚Äôs character seem rationally flawed because of his morals, but I think it pays off beautifully. No one has the right answer here and I love that. In the end, it‚Äôs about actions, not just ideals, and Kuwana did some horrible things to achieve his version of justice. Yagami just wants the world to be propelled by the truth, which is the fairest thing someone in his position can do. The only loose end is how the law will enact justice based on the truth, still giving strength to Kuwana‚Äôs argument against Japan‚Äôs imbalanced justice system. I find it pretty bold that Kuwana is let go in the end. Sure, there is no proof to stick him to his crimes, but it also leaves a major crack in Yagami‚Äôs optimism for the justice system. If a guilty man can never be punished for his crimes in a legal manner, then would self-imposed justice be the next best thing? Kuwana is easily the best antagonist in the Yakuza series. As an antagonist, he asks more out of the protagonist and the player than any other villain has and it‚Äôs difficult not to root for him despite his actions. I really appreciate Lost Judgement‚Äôs story. The characters were easy to love or hate, the discussions about bullying and the justice system were fascinating, and it felt like a real detective story by breaking away from the usual Yakuza story structure. It doesn‚Äôt have nearly as much emotional weight as Judgement had, but it traded that for being a lot more thought-provoking to the point of being divisive, which only the best stories can accomplish.

CONCLUSION

Lost Judgement is a fantastic sequel to its predecessor. The combat is at its peak in the series, the side content is the most fleshed out it has ever been, the soundtrack is more iconic than the game itself, and its incredibly unique story boasts some of the best characters and themes in the series. This is one of the few games I will definitely come back to. I would love to see Yagami in a future release, but I would also find it fitting for this to be his last hurrah.
