My goal in every Yakuza game, and I've played all of them (mostly on PS4, and except for Dead Souls) as of right now, is to fight the secret boss Amon. This game's Amon fight was more funny than he was difficult. He is not the easiest Amon fight, that honor goes to Ishin, but I did beat him in the Gauntlet on my first try. Also, lately, I've been playing on hard mode.

Speaking of, I think the gauntlet in this game is my favorite it's ever been throughout the series and I don't say that lightly. It was adequately challenging and fun without leaving me thinking "oh please, you shouldn't have" at the prospect of the "challenge" it presented. For example, in Yakuza 4, one "challenge" was to beat someone without hitting them with Tanimura, so you needed to put your back to a wall, parry them into the wall so they take damage and spend the next 5 minutes repeating that bored bored bored bored bored until you win. This was as stupid and as boring as it sounds. Also, the difficulty in the gauntlet seems to be averaged for "normal" difficulty, so playing on hard mode made the gauntlet easier to complete even with the constraints.

As for the combat, massive improvements from Judgement. In Judgement, Crane was kinda there. All the upgrades were for Tiger and Tiger did tons of damage and did enough of a job to dominate the entire game. Amon in Judgement was supposed to remind me that Crane exists with his gimmick but I beat him without it anyway because Crane is... just kinda there. 
So what does Lost Judgement do? It adds a third combat style and boy howdy how did they do it, I don't know but now we got an amazing balance where each fighting style specializes in something different. It reminds me of Yakuza 0 and it is great all for it. Also, the SP system, which is perhaps the best it has ever been, rewards you for varying your fighting style. 
Note: it's a shame that the fourth fighting style does NOT have any unique SP awards so I ended up disabling it until late game (which is also fitting as upgrading it requires you do a side-quest thing). Sure, it was a DLC thing (that comes with the base purchase of this game, I don't own the Kaito Files DLC but I still had it) but come on! Put some SP awards for it!

Late game, I ran around fighting random dudes on the street for around 3,000 SP per fight (around 1,400 from SP gained via the reward system and 1,600 SP for winning the fight. It is incredibly easy and not very grindy to get all skills before you beat the game. Though, if you taxi all over town instead of running around town, then you're probably not the target audience for this game, and also you will feel the grind to get all the skills.

Sure, each style has its unique attacks, finishers, tiger drops, heat actions, and even dodging, but in my opinion, one of the biggest accomplishments is the "secret" of each style. Dodging with Crane increases movement speed while parrying with Snake prevents you from being knocked down (from attacks) and landing a charged finisher (has to be charged despite the game not specifying, I checked) with Tiger increases your damage. All these effects are temporary and until you get an upgrade for each style, they go away if you style switch. When you unlocked these skills to keep the style switch, not only do you get to keep it, but activating the "secret" on another style resets the timer for the secret(s) from the previous style(s) so if you play well, you can be a faster-attacking, stronger-hitting and un-knock-down-able Yagami that tears through the enemies. 
Boxing style has this too where if you land a counter hit (like Tiger drop, which I think is a mistake because you may as well Tiger drop late game), the secret ability is your EX gain is increased (more counters = even faster charging). 

Even with all this, Tiger is still obscenely strong, so the strongest thing you can do is get crane and snake secrets, swap to tiger, EX Boost and just go ham. My personal favorite is two squares into fully charged triangle attacks. Also, they got rid of the "strong hits break max HP" gimmick from Judgement, that good too. If I have a complaint, it would be why do we swap between the styles with one button instead of using the full D-Pad like in Yakuza 0? Shortcut? I'm aware but I'd delete the thing while delegating the healing to the pause menu, like it has always been and everyone continues to do, and just let us enjoy Y0's style swapping. Someone made a mod for that please and thank you.

While the combat is the center, take a look aside for the side stuff... which I had finished the lion's share of all the side stuff by chapter 4. Every possible thing I could do at that point, I did until it was completed or locked. This is how I enjoy these games and make sure I fight Amon. Arriving to the start of the final chapter, I only had one last side quest to do and Amon. Overall, the humor I like is when funny things happen to characters and they play along. Something that I really do not like it is when these characters, that we've learned about and grown to like, suddenly start acting as if there's a gas leak in the room. Thankfully, the instance where this does happen is fairly brief and works as a contrast to how heavy the plot gets when you first access this side quest, so I'll let it slide.

With characters mentioned, Yagami is better fleshed out compared to how he was in Judgement. Then again, I used to be a teacher so putting him in that context and not screwing up went a long way to making me like him. Still... I'm quite mehhhhhhh on him but what I did early on was mod Mine (read: Mi-Ne, not "mine") from Yakuza 3 via Nexus to replace Yagami and that somehow made me enjoy the game quite a lot more. The only flaw with the mod occurs in Chapter 7 but not in any meaningful way. Also, no "in school shoes" texture of sorts, so invisible feet when in school... which is funny but not impactful.
Trying to avoid any spoilers (except for Amon), I'll just say that the other characters also have their time in the spotlight adequately that I overall enjoyed the story. Watching them play rock paper scissors while the credits rolled was amusing.

Finally, the extract system... It's there and I seldom remember its existence. I imagine it would've made any particular combat section a cake walk, based on the effects I read; like "get the ability to shoot energy balls" or "get a thunder sword that you can use to smite your foes" or whatever; and also the "DLC" that automatically comes with the game gives you a sample to use (a free one for most of them) but still... I never really used them. Even in the gauntlets, I only used one where it is *required* to win. 

Overall, amazing entry by RGG that I recommend. I sure hope they don't only make turn-based combat games now and I also hope they never use the Unreal Engine like Ishin. Cheers.

Summary:

Better more fluid and faster combat compared to most game made by RGG studios, but the game suffers from too much of a focus on quantity instead of quality, with a story that has terrible pacing and an unsatisfying ending.

Upgrading skills:

1. Too big and drawn out, forcing you to grind a lot to become stronger and to unlock quality of life features.

Combat problems:

1. Getting stunned and knocked to the ground takes the player to gain control.
2. Grabbing an enemy while they're attacking makes it so your grab goes through them. A problem that happened in Yakuza 3 and Yakuza 4.
3. Hitboxes of enemies sometimes would hit you from far away, even hitting you when you're behind them.
4. Badly balanced fighting styles, with Crane being very overpowered, Tiger being pretty good, Snake being alright and Boxing being pretty bad.
5. They literally locked a fighting style (Boxing) behind a DLC.

Characters:

1. Yagami felt more of a stereotypical detective thant an actual character with depth to him like in Judgment.
2. Most of the characters too me felt too uninteresting and bland.
3. They ramble on for too long before finally mentioning information relevant to the story. They also love to bring back past events from the same game or from Judgment multiple times.

Story:

1. Too much expository dialogue.
2. Pacing was too slow, a lot of the interesting parts of the story where just spoon fed to you via dialogue making the whole waiting unrewarding.
3. The main mystery of the story was too obvious.
4. A lot of the reveals revolve around someone giving you paragraphs of them admitting to the truth, while not showing you what happened through the use of cutscenes or flashbacks.
5. Plot and conflict drags on for too long.
6. Constantly being forced to go from point A to point B to progress the story and substories. A lot of the time it just revolves around talking to someone in person instead of through the phone, just to be forced to travel to another location again.

Sub stories:

1. Too serious and it has less of that iconic silly humor.

Mechanics from Judgment:

1. They brought back those unfun and extremely tedious mechanics, like lockpicking, chase, trailing missions, finding clues in first person (Revolves around moving your camera around until you spot something), 
parkour (Where it sends you back to the beginning EVERY time you fall, and it's very difficult to not accidentally fall off) 
and sneaking where the AI is either too stupid and slow, or they can spot you while having their backs to you.

Robotics:

1. It's just a rat race to on who can connect and place their blocks on the opponent's territory first.
2. Being forced to grind to obtain materials that can only be obtained by specific levels from the robotics minigame.
3. A lot of unskippable cutscenes. Building ONE part? unskippable cutscene. Starting the same level for the 10th+ time to obtain materials? unskippable cutscene.
4. It mostly revolves around building your way as fast as you can into the opponent's territory, which get stale after doing the same thing more than 20 times.
5. Near the end you start running out of funds to upgrade since it only gives you 30k yen every 5 games, which forces you to play the same levesl over and over just so you can finally upgrade after also grinding to obtain the materials.
6. In the final fight, the game forces you to use a robot that is inferior to the ones you can build at that point of the game.
7. Whenever you're tackled by a fortress robot you literally can't do anything until it stops pushing you.

Dancing:

Mini-games:

School stories mini-games:

1. To unlock more you have to play the horrible ones like Robotics and Boxing.

4. 

Dating:

RGG has been known for making games that range from bangers to absolute classics. 

So when I say this is the best thing they have ever made and it's not even close, that's all the review you need. Every issue I had with the first game was fixed and enhanced. Very impressive.

Kaito Files is pretty good too, but getting it for $30 is a bit of a stretch. It's about 8 hours long if you plan on doing everything. Even shorter if you only do main story. Especially since there are no substories here.

Main game is about 67 hours when you do most of the side content. Takes just about the same amount of time to 100% the game and do the Kaito Files.

Judgment was a pretty good game, but wow, this is such a massive improvement over the first that I can't see myself going back to it after playing this. Other than having a story that is slightly better paced, there is nothing JE does that LJ doesn't do a 100x better.

The biggest improvement, by far, is the combat system. After years of playing through the Yakuza series, I can finally say there is a Yakuza game whose combat system has surpassed Yakuza 0's. So much more fluid, so many options, no more mortal blows, the returning styles got major tweaks and the new styles are fantastic in their own rights, and being able to mix them up and juggle enemies like it was Tekken is exhilarating. From this point forward, every beat-em-up style Yakuza title should strive to reach this level. If you can't juggle enemies in newer titles, it's immediately inferior to this game.

The story is also fantastic, and while it's not quite as compelling as JE's story was, LJ more than makes up for it with who is probably the best antagonist in the entire series. Yakuza games have always had a tendency to adopt a very black and white moral view throughout their storyline, and this is the first time we've gotten such a morally gray character and dilemma in the series, I loved it. All the new characters and antagonists introduced are so memorable.

Technical aspects are also vastly improved. This is, without question, the best looking any game in the Yakuza series has ever been. The Dragon Engine has been perfected so that the prerendered cutscenes look worse than actual in-game cutscenes, and the lighting has also been improved drastically (especially from Y7's awful lighting). The soundtrack is great, and the new QOL improvements are welcome. I can't believe it took this long to be able to fast travel from anywhere.

If I had to point out some flaws in the game though, it would definitely be the school subplot with the MRC, because some of the minigames are definitely better than others. Boxing, robot club, dancing, girl's bar, they were fun and interesting. The others, not so much, and some of them, especially the biker race, just got really repetitive and frustrating. The substories were also pretty lacking for the most part although there were still some wacky and hilarious ones. However, I'm really glad they removed the text messages about the Neo Keihin Gang, that was one of the worst parts of the original JE because it was so annoying. 

The flaws overall are minor however, and this is easily one of the best games that RGG has ever put out, and I genuinely hope a third game is in the works somewhere down the line. Powerful story, memorable and interesting characters, a fantastic antagonist that acts as a dark mirror to the protagonist, an extremely fluid combat system that makes me want to engage in random battles instead of running away, and some great minigames, this game has almost everything I could ever want in an RGG title.

One of the best games that RGG made. They improved the game's combat by reworking the Crane style and refining the juggling system from the first Judgment game and in addition with the two new styles: Snake and Boxer. Boxer is more of an optional style since it's part of the School Stories Expansion DLC and it's toggleable in the options. Nevertheless, it's still a pretty good style for initiating juggle combos.

Compared to Judgment the game is way larger, it has a new city region Ijincho, a separate side story named "School Stories" which consists 10 different clubs with each having their own unique story. The lowlights for School Stories are Biker Gang and Photography Club. Completing Photography Club forces you to be Stealth mode to get to the designated destination before taking a photo and it's not a one time occurrence. Biker Gang takes too much time to complete it and the camera placement in the minigame is such a weird choice. 
Speaking of minigames, there are plenty of them that you can do here and it's much easier to get cheat items while completing achievements.

The story overall is not as great as Judgment's but it's still decent compared to other Yakuza games' [spoiler] looking at you 2, 4 and 5 [/spoiler]. As mentioned previously, the stealth sections ruin the flow progressing through the story and you can still fail them pretty easily. The boss fights and long battles here are awesome with the game's improved combat. On top of that, dynamic intros and themes for selected fights are memorable and phenomenal.

To summarize, if you liked the previous game or enjoy beat-em up Yakuza, you're going to love this and I recommend you to buy it with a discount or, if you have enough, the Judgment collection.

A very good game and one of the best in the "extended" series (Yakuza+Judgment).

First I am so happy to see the Dragon Engine finally deliver : the game is really beautiful and the fights finally both enjoyable and fair (Y3 to Kiwami system was enjoyable only but broken).
Activities are generally of good quality and I appreciate the gameplay additions to make the game more modern and less clunky (the parkour for instance...yes it feels dated compared to real action/adventure games but this is a step in the right direction).  

As always, you need like 2-4 hours to be drawn in the game and after that you cannot stop playing until the end. The story is a bit weak if you look at it coldly (as many Yakuza games to be fair), but they half succeeded to deliver their message with strong characters and emotionnal momentum. I cannot spoil but I would rate this part B, A being the best stories in the series. I cannot put the finger on the reason behind this feeling, maybe because Yagami looped over one event and used it every time in his discussions so that he locked the game instead of developping the numerous interesting characters and leads (the school for instance is abandoned quickly by the plot). To sum up, maybe Yagami and his single argument were too dominating in the plot (compared to other characters, story branches, etc.) and that is why the Kaito files DLC felt like a deliverance.

Aside from that, the game has a huge content, to the point that in almost 40 hours I have never ecountered some. This is certainly here of the best points : we cannot feel bored in this game and the step in modernity for all these old minigames feels good even if the side quests by themselves are not really memorable.

Now I have a huge gripe with this port and I'm tormented to leave a negative review for this alone : the DLC button in the smartophone makes you leave the game (as intended) and then, when you come back to it, the game is FROZEN. So if you did not save, you can lose a lot of playtime. This is even more frustrating when you have already purchased the DLC, so the button is absolutely useless. 

Considering the content for the price, the usual free additions and the quality, I will keep my positive review but I hoped that this matter would be fixed.

========

KAITO FILES DLC

In a way, this DLC had the (genuine) humanity lacking in main game which felt colder (despite the forced scenes, because the game was too centered around Yagami and his view).

The stories are interesting and varied and the side missions are as goofy as ever. Seeing Yagami and the gang take on more serious and constantly escalating situations is thrilling in a way the other yakuza games arent especially considering your playing on the side of the law and not against it.

Theres so much to do as well, the side missions in the school are plentiful to a point where its almost a problem (I spent a whole two to three hours doing nothing but side quest specifically at the school (that wasnt even ten percent of what the game offers regarding side missions) This brings up one of my major issues with the game in which a whole fighting style is locked behind a few hours worth of side missions which the side missions themselves arent available till you get a hour or two into the game. This means you have to wait after a hour or two to get to the side missions to even get to start to unlock all the combat this game has to offer. It seems rather unnecessary and could've just had the ability to go to the gym to learn these techniques available from the start instead of winding it so tightly around side missions which some players might not even bother with at all to begin with.

Other then that the character of Yagami himself is a good blend between Ichibans sheer optimism/positivity and Kiryus sterness and and bluntness, the side characters are also something truly great (Kaito in particular is a goofy but loyal partner and brings his own charm and flair while still standing on his own as a great character)

All in all this game is a solid 9/10 from what ive played

This isn't as good as Judgment, story-wise, but mostly an improvement gameplay-wise, which seems to be the general consensus (the climbing and parkour elements they added are tedious at best and detract from the flow of the game, I think).

Bullying as a backdrop and motivation point for the story just makes me roll my eyes. It's far less interesting than what we got in Judgment. But it still has great characters, a hallmark of RGG. I liked [spoiler] Soma [/spoiler] in particular as a villain. Really creepy with a cool soundtrack for your fights with him. There were some other standout music pieces here (love the Snake Style battle music); RGG has really stepped it up in that department in their recent games!

My biggest complaint is that this game feels bloated in a bad way. RGG games give you a lot to do if you wish, but here a lot of it feels like a slog. Most of that slog comes from the School Stories. Ugh. They tried to do too many mini games at once; RGG should have cut out half of that "content".

Completionists will feel discouraged by trying to do too much in the beginning at once, like I did. Even without the side stuff, this game starts too slowly. I was thinking this might be the first Yakuza franchise game I give a negative review... But RGG's charm shines through so that I can still recommend it!

This game is fun. The gameplay, combat especially, is more refined than before. Beating enemies in the city never felt better. The past game, Judgment, felt sluggish now because of this game. The combat here is more balanced and fun, rather than just using Tiger Style only in Judgment since Crane Style felt useless. Other than Tiger Style and Crane Style being more balanced and just fun, theres Snake Style that is a much more defensive that is also just fun to use. Changing styles during combo is the bread and butter of combat. Thats my earlier impressions of this game since I'm not really going into this game for the story.

Lost Judgment is kinda spin-off of the Yakuza games but kinda not since the world of Yakuza, which is Kamurocho, always plays a role in the story. But it is a spinoff seeing how the story tells a different group of people rather than criminals, or ex-criminals that is usually in the Yakuza games. The first game, Judgment, have kind off a simple detective story with some Yakuza usual flair. Although I enjoyed it, I'll admit the antagonist kinda didn't do it for me. In Lost Judgment, I really like the story, the events that happen, and also the main villain.

Warning: This story is VERY DARK, dealing with bullying and suicide. Its not a one line or one event kinda thing. This dark element is the problem the game wants to deal with, exploring its issues and even exploring its consequences. I don't want to spoil too much but if you are open to the idea the game wants to discuss, I believe this game handled it very well and in a compelling way. Giving some of the better stories and also villains in a Yakuza game. 

As per Yakuza game, the main story, is only 26% of the whole game, atleast for me after reaching the credits. Sidecontent is half of the game and is one of the main reasons why the Yakuza are its own genre. There are loads of minigames you can play, each in a building that are unique and very fun. This also gives an immersive feel to the open world, where even with its small size, the things you can do, and the substories you encounter, gives the world more life than an average Ubisoft open world game. (Ahem, AC Odyssey, ahem)

Soundtrack is the firiest of fire I have ever fire. 

Overall, one of the best Yakuza game I've ever played.

If Judgment was the surprise that convinced me Ryu Ga Gotoku Studio could take chances with a brand new cast without reference to the old, then [b]Lost Judgment[/b] is the proven reality that taking chances has become this developer‚Äôs routine day at the office in the best way possible. I am consistently impressed with each newer title in this franchise (counting the Yakuza games obviously) by the audacity to keep pushing for quality and quantity at the same time. Part of what makes these games so special is the constant yearning for improvement from title to title, which is why I can‚Äôt help but wonder how someone without prior history playing these games would feel if they jumped into Lost Judgment without knowing sheer volume of details preserved and evolved since the first Yakuza and its nine-games series, discounting spin-offs.

I felt the need to bring this up, because if you are a reader who has not experienced these games, you [i]can[/i] start with Lost Judgment, but I feel like you will appreciate it more by experiencing Judgment, first. You will also likely have an emotional jaw-drop if you have also played the Yakuza games beforehand, because what causes me to nearly go off-tangent spewing paragraphs of metaphorical love-making for these games has been seeing just how far RGG has come in terms of honing and perfecting their art. 

Lost Judgment‚Äôs story revolves around modern-day bullying in Japan, and while I am not going to analyze the depth of this (as I am not well-versed in the history of this issue in that country), I will focus on the quality of how this story is presented. The characters introduced are strong and believable, and the journey Takayuki Yagami endures is one of extreme highs and lows, and while the highs are joyous, cathartic moments of glory, the lows in particular show a new display of bravery from a writer‚Äôs standpoint. Without spoiling details, I will say that the ending took a lot of balls, and I imagine opinions will be divided regarding the hero and antihero dilemma this story leaves you pondering; this is possibly the most bitter-sweet ending since Majima‚Äôs conclusion in Yakuza 0, and I feel that the antagonists of Lost Judgment might have been the best of this series as a result. No one was allowed to be one-dimensional, here, which is a fantastic achievement.

The title of the game ended up being the two defining words I thought of when the credits were rolling. That earns chef‚Äôs kisses, aplenty, for that.

Before I write about gameplay, I‚Äôd just like to make a special highlight for the heavy-hitter side-story saga, the School Stories. I always make it my priority to play the saga-driven side-stories in all these games, and this one is the best, in my opinion. There is a massive cast of memorable characters, and I couldn‚Äôt help but feel like some personal wish-fulfillment was unfolding for me, personally. I‚Äôm a huge fan of the 90s anime Great Teacher Onizuka (particularly the heart of it, despite the humor), and if you‚Äôve ever wanted to enjoy the feeling of playing that series‚Äô most rewarding moments, this saga will be a special treat for you. 

The gameplay improvements (mainly combat) are taken to a phenomenal extreme, here. I mentioned in my Judgment review that we had finally reached the best of both worlds, since I always felt that the newer-engine games lost that charm of combat-depth that 0 had achieved before the engine-shift. Well Lost Judgment took a look at what Judgment accomplished and said, ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre just getting started.‚Äù Something in particular I really enjoy is how Yagami feels strong, right out of the gate. In Judgment, it felt like we were developing a low-level combatant into a street-demon. Here, despite having to rebuild upgrades again, he doesn‚Äôt feel weaker at the start. My memory could be fuzzy, here, but I honestly felt like, despite stat reductions, his actual move-set mostly [i]felt[/i] like it was where we left-off at the end of Judgment, which makes his subsequent increases feel marvelously satisfying. I always disliked having to rebuild Kiryu‚Äôs kit from game to game (with the exception being 6, since I felt his slowness added charm to the aged-theme of that game), but it doesn‚Äôt feel like you are rebuilding Yagami as much as you are just improving him.

Beyond combat, gameplay is serviceable, and that‚Äôs fine. I‚Äôve seen complaints that the detective mechanics, stealth, tailing, lockpicking, and climbing are all lacking depth, but the way I see it: These mechanics served to sell me on the context of the character we were playing, and that‚Äôs all they needed to do to engage me. If I want an in-depth exploration of these mechanics, there are plenty of immersive sims to pick and play. Here, these mechanics are little sprinkles to break up the combat sections, and they never really overstay their welcome. If anything, they tend to be fun little pauses, which then leads to the inevitable hyped showdowns to be, well? HYPED!

Some little details: I felt that Judgment had a superior mood, giving strong noir vibes to it, which is sadly toned down in Lost Judgment. While I would have enjoyed more of that dripping atmosphere in the sequel, it was great to revisit Yokohama, post-Yakuza: Like a Dragon. Fans of that game will be pleased to see plenty of nostalgia-references slipped in with subtlety (shout-out to spotting Ichiban Confections!) without taking away from Lost Judgment‚Äôs focus. The soundtrack was excellent, and the mini-games introduced were superb (the best of which came from the School Stories).

Overall, it goes without saying that you deserve to experience Lost Judgment if you have made it this far in these games. If you are a potential player who has not experienced these games, while you are free to start here, I truly feel you will get more out of the experience if you have, at the very least, played Judgment. It‚Äôs unrealistic for me to advise you to play 9 [i]long[/i] games, back-to-back, just to enjoy the world-building and evolutions of the setting in this one, but I also feel that I don‚Äôt think I would feel as attached to these games without the build-up. The world of these games is so consistent that revisiting locations like Kamurocho and Yokohama always fills me with memories, like revisiting an old neighborhood where you grew-up. It‚Äôs special, and I can‚Äôt think of another franchise that puts me in that mindset like this one.

What. A. Game. 

Where the previous Judgement game (JUDGE EYES) is THE Yagami's case, this game is more of ONE of Yagami cases. The story in this game introduces a lot of moral grey areas, and the oversights of the law. Where the previous game is a victory lap to finish what's been started, this game is a grim, dark, and quiet affair. The "villain" of the story is insanely well-crafted and can be deeply empathised with. At the end of the game, I was sitting back in my chair going ".....dude this is so f*cked up man...". If you've been bullied before, this game will hit you. HARD.

The beat-em-up combat system in this game is the BEST out of ALL the Ryu Ga Gotoku studios games, period (and I've played them all). It's not even a contest. The different stances all complement each other, encouraging a lot of stance switching during combat. The heat moves are rewarding, flashy, and effective. Combat upgrades feel impactful, and actually upgrades gameplay. The upgrade points (SP) are given generously, but not too much to be considered "OP". The boss fights are seriously really well made. I haven't had this much fun in boss battles since Yakuza Kiwami 1. I played on Hard difficulty and was sweating so damn much in the final few boss fight scenes, but they feel very rewarding.

The sheer number of new mechanics and mini-games introduced in this game is also downright ridiculous. They expanded on the detective aspect of this game a LOT, and also the number of fun minigames are GREATLY increased. In the previous games, the extent of being a detective was quite limited. Tailing missions were done so much it kind of got boring. However, this game actually makes you feel like a PROPER detective. There's parkour, noise amplifiers, radio waves reader, using a dog to sniff out scents, etc. Some minigames they introduced are dancing (not the Yakuza 5 one, this one is better by a long shot), boxing, skateboarding, photography, and so so so many more I can't even name them. This game seriously feels like a damn theme park, I can't play them all!

Finally, the new characters in this game is very well done and well fleshed out. At first, some side characters rubbed me the wrong way, but character development kicked me in the heart, and I love them all. One very minor gripe is that I don't see one of the characters more [spoiler](Tesso)[/spoiler], I wish they could've expanded a little more on him. Hopefully we get to see him in the next Judgement game. 

I haven't played the Kaito Files DLC yet, but I've heard good things about it and I'm planning to play it soon. Overall, while the plot is slightly weaker compared to the previous game (but still great overall), the other aspects of the game are 10/10. Highly recommend this game with or without a sale.

Another Yakuza game down in the 100% books. While not as annoying to do as a Yakuza 5 this game was tedious in many completion regards like the 50 hour professor side case lmao. Anyway this review will be about the game itself and not as a completionist.

 Spoilers below

First of all, the story. 
- While not my favourite game due to repetitive tasks, this is my favourite plot line in the yakuza series so far, beating like a dragon, 0 and 2 for me. The continuous theme of bullying and suicide is something that yakuza usually doesn't tackle as its main focus is usually on bizarre evil yakuza plot twists or corrupted police. This game also has my new favourite yakuza villain in Kuwana as he is genuinely the most grey shaded antagonists in terms of motives and desires. The line of good and evil is so blurred that your main bro Kaito even says he doesn't know who is right at the start of the final battle and he leaves you to it. Not to mention that masterpiece of a tear jerker send off where everything he tried to protect falls apart and the characters around him apologise for making him keep such a dark secret for 13 years. Him crying out is heartwrenching as he just balls with tears post Yagami fight.
- Yagami is also here but his character development is not as deep as the previous title and kaito takes much more of a backseat as well, but i think this is what makes Kuwana shine the most. Another massive positive is how they dont do the bad guy turns good then dies trope at the end, bro doesnt even get arrested, he just walks off into the shadows, i loved it.
- Literal Only complaint with the story is how Soma has Yagami and Kaito dead as shit in the bar but he just leaves after the bar owner calls and there is just no good defence for that (yes i know its Kuwana dad).
- Also Soma goes on a mad killing spree. Gotta be the most deaths in any yakuza game including the Kaito files. I like it, feels like they took Saejimas advice to Kido from 4 and got their balls out

Content/Gameplay:
- While there is no karoke there are plenty of activities for you to partake in with yagami. A lot of the dumb detective trailing stuff is back but it was toned down from the first game. Some of the questionable observation gimmicks return like "turn on the lights" lol. In my opinion the school professor storyline, while fun, was not worth taking up 40ish hours as it ate up side quests. Of the 42 side quests 13 have to do with one illegal detective agency as well which was very boring. Some quests ended after literally 1 minute, no joke. School def ate development here. While i sound harsh here its because this is all my complaints, i got nothing else besides some of the tedious side content as a completionist and some boring side cases.
- Also, Snake style is the best style in the series, holy shit. so cool.

Kaito Files:
- Idk how much this dlc cost on release but for the sale bundle i got it was worth it as i enjoyed it more than the yakuza 2 majima story dlc. Nice to see old fighting styles return with kaito and i love how on stealth missions you can get caught and still knock the guy out unlike yamagi because you are a brute. Also, instead of running around crowds kaito pushed them away in chase missions XD. Made me laugh

Conclusion/Summary
- Game is excellent, my fav yakuza story and second fav overall yakuza game after 0. While not my top 3 protagonist, Yagami has the best side cast in the series hands down. I hope they will release a third game down the road or have these characters make a return in a mainline game. If you like judgement 1 this is a must buy since it has improved the formula in every regard.

I'll start this review off by saying I loved the first Judgment, and I had extremely high expectations going into Lost Judgment. It definitely didn't disappoint and excels at every aspect.

Firstly, the story and characters. The story in Judgment was extremely interesting, revolving around government conspiracies and medical trials. Lost Judgment definitely does not disappoint in that aspect, and revolves around the murders of former high school bullies. The best part about Lost Judgment is that, as the tagline says, nothing is black and white. Every character in the story has understandable motivations and goals, and no one is just evil for the sake of being evil. In addition to the story, you have the main cast of characters. Most of which return from the previous game. All of the main cast have amazing chemistry and they're all likable, (or hateable for some of the villains) at some points making you feel like you're a part of Yagami Detective Agency/Yokohama 99. 

Secondly, the setting and side content. The first Judgment was set exclusively in Kamurocho, the city which has been a part of the Yakuza series since its debut on the PS2 in 2005. That's not inherently a bad thing, however, but it definitely made the game feel a bit stale if you played through it after playing through Yakuza games where you've explored the ins and outs of Kamurocho already. Lost Judgment expands this to Isezaki Ijincho, Yokohama, which was introduced in Yakuza: Like a Dragon. Ijincho is roughly three times the size of Kamurocho, which gives more opportunities for interesting side cases story beats. Speaking of side cases, the side content in this game is insane. Not only do you have the side cases (or substories as they're referred to in Yakuza) and regular minigames we're used to in the Yakuza/Judgment series, you also have the school stories, which are a set of brand new minigames each with their own storyline attached to them, with an overarching story relating to the Mystery Research Club. 

Finally, the combat. I'll start off by saying Lost Judgment has the best combat seen in the Yakuza/Judgment series ever. I can't begin to describe how fluid and fun everything feels but it's definitely the best. Lost Judgment includes 3 main fighting styles, Crane, Tiger, and Snake, with a fourth boxing style which can be progressed through one of the school stories. Crane and Tiger return from Judgment, and they feel so much better in this game. In Judgment, the only upgradable style was Tiger, with any upgrades that weren't explicitly for Tiger applying to both styles. In Lost Judgment each style has its own skill tree and pros and cons for each situation. While you can just use one style for the whole game, the game encourages you to switch it up, with the Hidden Arts buffs and SP bonuses. The Hidden Arts buffs essentially encourage you to use every style in your battle, as they give you specific benefits when you perform specific actions in a style. For example, if you successfully evade your enemy's attack while in Crane style, and have a fully upgraded Hidden Arts skill, you can boost your attack speed for 12 seconds. This might not sound like a huge improvement, but if you switch styles and activate the Hidden Arts for that style, it resets that timer, plus giving you an extra buff. This is extremely helpful, especially in boss fights, and encourages you to switch up your playstyle. Also included are SP bonuses, which return from Yakuza 0, which were money bonuses. They essentially work the same way as they did in that game, giving you SP for performing specific actions in a battle, one of which being to defeat an enemy in each of the three styles, so to level up faster, you'll need to incorporate all 3 main styles into your playstyle.


Overall, Lost Judgment is without a doubt my favourite game in the Like a Dragon series, and I encourage anyone who is on the fence to check it out, as it is an amazing experience throughout the whole game.

( full review with screenshots: https://www.gaming-parrot.com/2023/04/lost-judgement-review-uneven-judgment.html )

Lost Judgment is the sequel to Judgment, and like that game is a Yakuza series spinoff focused on the private detective work of Yagami and friends. It primarily uses the same Ijincho map as Like a Dragon, but don't expect much in the way of references to that game. Outside of a very subtle cameo and a few nods to reused locations, there's almost nothing shared between the games and you can definitely get by here having only played Judgment. Almost all of the major characters are returning faces from that game, and while you might still be able to have a good time if you started here, you'd be missing out on both a great game and a ton of background. 

So, assuming you're already familiar with Judgment, what's different here? Far and away the biggest change, at least outside of the new map, is the focus on Seiryo High School. After a series of contrived and deeply awkward shenanigans a few hours into the game, Yagami ends up as a counselor at the school and will work with almost a dozen different clubs over the rest of the game if you want to complete the main side quest. Each club has its own minigame, which range wildly in content, depth, and quality. The eSports club is merely yet another way to access Virtua Fighter 5, for example, and the robotics club only looks deep until you realize how bad the AI is at it, but the boxing gym is a brand new 1v1 fighter with loads of different opponents and special moves. The good news is that the best of these are quite fun and most of the clubs have entertaining stories to go with the minigames. The bad news is that several of the clubs easily take 4-5 hours to complete and there's no choice but to do them unless you would rather give up on seeing the end of the entire school side story. It would've benefited greatly from having fewer minigames that got more dev time each, or from making the clubs just take less time. 

Speaking of systems that needed more time in the oven, the worst offender by far is the stealth. I am someone who loves stealth games and regularly plays them on the hardest settings, but the stealth in this game is so indefensibly awful that I started dropping the difficulty to "simple" every time it came up instead of bothering to engage with it. It's completely linear and provides zero player choice, so there's no satisfaction to overcoming a section, and worse than that it's insta-fail if you're ever spotted. Nevermind that the goons you're sneaking around can hardly scratch you in a normal fight, once you start sneaking they're suddenly capable of one hit KOs. These sections are at least only used a handful of times in a 60 hour game, but they are truly offensively bad. 

My other big problem is more subjective. Judgment mostly had you dealing with yakuza bosses and corrupt officials, so you never felt too bad about harassing them for your investigation. This time around, Yagami spends a lot of time being annoyingly persistent with teachers, teenagers, and other civilians who are a lot more sympathetic when they just want to be left alone. It can get uncomfortable. On top of that, while the story does end up somewhere satisfying, it suffers from some pacing issues in the middle and relies on one specific incident for Yagami's motivation so heavily and constantly that it starts to feel silly. This would've been on the edge of not earning a recommendation if it hadn't recovered in the last couple of chapters. 

All that out of the way, what you're left with is a lot of the same strengths as other games in this series. Combat is generally very satisfying, although it feels like the new Viper style completely outclasses the existing Tiger and Crane styles against a lot of the hardest enemies. It's full of quirky characters and silly moments that'll usually earn a laugh. The main antagonists, once you finally know who they are, create some great setpiece boss fights. The one strong point that's less familiar is the school stories, which mostly offer refreshingly lower stakes and more wholesome content than what you're probably used to. It's good to take a break from all the murders and conspiracies to just go coach a dance team for a bit.

Lost Judgment is a fantastic entry in the Judgment franchise, and probably RGG's magnum opus as of 2023. While not as tight as it's predecessor, Lost Judgment features a compelling mystery for Yagami and his friends to solve.

One thing that really stood out to me were the phenomenal performances of Takuya Kimura (Takayuki Yagami) and Koji Yamamoto (Jin Kuwana). I'm a longtime fan of Kimura-san, from SMAP to his record-breaking dramas, and I'm glad that he's very enthusiastic about continuing in the role of Yagami. RGG Studio really gave him a lot more to work with in this title, especially in regards to both the fully-voiced main story and the humorous side-cases. 

Koji Yamamoto also has the honor of portraying the best written antagonist in a RGG title. Kuwana is a deeply complex character that serves as an excellent foil to Yagami, and it's so fun to see these two go head-to-head with eachother. Also helps that he has a sick-ass theme.

While certain aspects like the reworked Detective Mode and Parkour could be improved, Lost Judgment has the best combat in any RGG title ever released, surpassing Yakuza Zero. Combat is fast, flashy, and fluid ‚Äì with Yagami's expanded moveset making the high encounter rate a joy to contend with.

If you‚Äôre a fan of thrilling adventures filled with dynamic twists and turns  ‚Äì look no further than picking up this game right away. Highly recommended for anyone ready for a great time.

I want to like Lost Judgment more than Judgment 1. I really do. But I don't.

The narrative in Lost Judgment is, in my opinion, much better than Judgment 1 because it doesn't try to make its stakes world-ending. Yes, there are high-level officials involved in Lost Judgment's plot, sure, but it starts off very grounded and generally stays that way. Yagami's story is very much Yagami's story and everything that he's involved in carries personal stakes first. And I am very much into that kind of story.

The combat is stellar too, basically improving on Judgment 1's in every measurable way. Now having three styles a la Like a Dragon instead of two does wonders for how you like to play. Likewise, the expanded "detective" segments serve the game well, with a lot of what would have been tailing and chase segments from Judgment 1 being replaced with stealth and Parkour segments.

But there are flaws, and they're pretty huge.

The first and most egregious of these is the locking of the main side story, the School Stories, behind minigame completion. To complete the School Stories investigations, you have to fully complete each of their respective minigames to their ends. This isn't too much of a problem with something like the Dance minigame, but it's insanely frustrating for the Robotics minigame. When I discovered I had to fully complete the minigames, I just gave up on the School Stories entirely.

Another flaw appears once the RK gang shows up. With every plot point that involves RK, the only fights you ever see are against hordes of RK members, that's it. The only two important characters within RK are the leaders, so there really isn't any variety in antagonists beyond those two and one other individual. One fight with RK in the middle of the game has you fighting the same RK leader boss three times in a row. Deplete their health bar, fight again. And then when you infiltrate a warehouse with them, you likely fight a hundred enemies in total over the course of the infiltration. It becomes incredibly boring.

Finally, the game does not play nice with automatic cutscene triggers. I ran into this at the very end, when the game explicitly told me to prepare before leaving. I set a waypoint for the item shop and proceeded to run there, only to realize that getting close to the cutscene trigger would, with no warning, send me into the final battle arc.

I still like Lost Judgment, and I'll be playing the Kaito Files at a later date. But I find Judgment 1 superior, mainly because it's less annoying.

[h1]First comes the pain, then the fear. You have to start with the pain. Fear won't work if you haven't given them a reason.[/h1]
[h1]introduction[/h1]
[b]Judgment[/b] left a big impression on me with everything that it presented to me. It had a fantastic story, awesome characters, stellar gameplay, lots of side content, and a great soundtrack to add to it all. [b]Lost Judgment[/b] improves on some of these aspects and is definitely a game that I heavily enjoyed.

[h1]Pros and Cons[/h1]
[b]Pros[/b]
[list]
[*]The story is really well done with great characters
[*]Fun and enjoyable gameplay, with improved combat
[*]Four combat styles to utilize
[*]Lots of sub-cases and mini-games to play
[*]Fantastic soundtrack that is amazing to listen to
[*]Beautiful graphics that make you immersed into Yokohama
[/list]

[b]Cons[/b]
[list]
[*]The side-cases were not entertaining
[/list]

[h1]Story[/h1]
The story starts out with [b]Saori Shirosaki[/b] and [b]Issei Hoshino[/b] who are defending a man by the name of [b]Akikhiro Ehara[/b] that was charged with indecently touching someone. [b]Takayuki Yagami[/b] and [b]Masaharu Kaito[/b] were called by [b]Fumiya Sugiura[/b] and [b]Makoto Tsukumo[/b] to help with [b]Seiryo High School‚Äôs[/b] bullying problem. However, [b]Shirosaki[/b] calls [b]Yagami[/b] and tells him that the case with [b]Ehara[/b] and [b]Seiryo High[/b], are somehow connected to each other. [b]Yagami[/b] has to figure out what is going on and get to the bottom of this case, while the secrets of the high school bleed out from underneath.

The story for [b]Lost Judgment[/b] may not be as good as the previous game's story but it was still an enjoyable experience overall. The characters are still likable and some of the plot twists were very well done overall. All of my favorite characters are back, and they are just as loveable as they were in the first game.

I don‚Äôt want to go too much into [b]Lost Judgment‚Äôs[/b] story as it‚Äôs really good and is one of the game's highlights in my opinion.

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
[b]Lost Judgment[/b] makes a huge improvement over the first game's gameplay, combat is vastly improved and feels more fluid. The [b]Dragon Engine[/b] once again makes its return in this game and still feels very nice. Combat does feel a bit different but that‚Äôs a good thing as it feels fresh, while still having some of the old mechanics to it. [b]Yagami[/b] does have his [b]Crane/Tiger Style[/b] available to him, but [b]Yagami[/b] does also have two new styles for him to utilize now, that being [b]Snake[/b] and [b]Boxing Style[/b].
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2941060835
[list]
[*][b]Crane Style[/b] allows [b]Yagami[/b] to deal with groups of enemies and is perfect for taking out weaker enemies when fighting bosses. [b]Crane Style[/b] is not really effective against bosses so it‚Äôs best to switch to [b]Tiger Style[/b] when dealing with them.

[*][b]Tiger Style[/b] has been nerfed a bit but is still my favorite style to use overall, you do have to finish enemies off with a charge attack, but it can break blocking. [b]Tiger Style[/b] is of course perfect for taking out bosses and is very useful in that regard.

[*][b]Snake Style[/b] is a new fighting style that [b]Yagami[/b] has access to that allows him to help deal with enemies that have weapons on them. [b]Yagami[/b] can counterattack and redirect them at foes, this style is more focused on countering than direct damage like the other two styles. When he is in [b]EX Boost Mode[/b], instead of knocking out scared enemies he will make them faint instead. Also, [b]Snake Style[/b] has a unique grab animation where [b]Yagami[/b] will put his opponent in an arm lock.

This fighting style is kind of similar to [b]Tanimura‚Äôs[/b] fighting style in [b]Yakuza 4[/b] but it does not require parrying to be the main feature.

[*][b]Boxing Style[/b] is a DLC-based fighting style and is also a unique style in that it‚Äôs the only one that does not have a grab-based attack. Rather, he will perform a hook attack, and holding the grab button will make him do a charged hook. To get upgrades for [b]Boxing Style[/b] you have to play to the [b]Boxing side case[/b] to unlock them, then you can buy them for 100 SP each.
[/list]
After each battle, you will be awarded [b]Special Points (SP)[/b] which you can use on your fighting styles to get extra moves, EX attacks, health, damage, etc. You can also get [b]SP[/b] by doing side-cases and doing objectives at the same time.

There is a lot to do in [b]Kamurocho[/b] and [b]Yokohama[/b], [b]Lost Judgment[/b] mainly takes place in [b]Yokohama[/b] but you can freely travel in both areas at any time if you so wish. You can do side-cases, play games like batting at the batting cages, card games, or play arcade games like [b]Sonic the Fighters[/b].

If you want some more of my thoughts and other stuff related to [b]Lost Judgment[/b], then I recommend watching my video on both games.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=wj850F5rX60&t=396s

Although despite there being a bunch of additional content in [b]Lost Judgment[/b], I personally did not find it interesting and worthwhile to do. I tried some of it but did not find any enjoyment as I did in the previous game. Some people did enjoy it so more power to them, there are some fun ones like teaching this dance club how to dance and such. So, they are not completely bare bones for all of them.

[h1]Soundtrack[/h1]
The soundtrack for [b]Lost Judgement[/b] is fantastic, every song that was shown was definitely worth listening to. My favorite one has to be [b]Green Vibes[/b] and [b]Hydra[/b], [b]Green Vibes[/b] is [b]Snake‚Äôs Styly‚Äôs[/b] theme and [b]Hydra[/b] really catches off an intense moment.

[h1]Graphics and Performance[/h1]
The graphics for [b]Lost Judgment[/b] are really beautiful, the world you are in feels like a natural city that you would explore with people chatting, cars moving, and more. I tested the game on an NVIDIA GeForce GTX 1060 3GB, AMD Ryzen 5 1500X Quad-Core Processor 3.50, and 16 GB of RAM. I did come across a few low-frame drops but I fixed them in the weirdest way possible and the game ran fine.
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2941060945
[h1]Final Verdict[/h1]
[b]Lost Judgement[/b] is a fantastic game that's, in my opinion, worth the full price. I recommend you get this game bundled with the first game as it comes with [b]The Kaito Files[/b] as well. While some things in [b]Lost Judgement[/b] were not as fantastic as in the previous one, it still holds up for a worthwhile purchase and is definitely a game worthy of praise by fans of the previous game.

Overall a great game but if I would compare it with the prequel then the prequel is honestly a much a better game. I'll try to compare both game and mention my biggest gripe, will also avoid talking about major spoilers for this game but I might spoil a little bit of the prequel (if that's a problem, you shouldn't be here anyway. Go buy/finish the first game).

Story:
Since we've learned everything there is to Yagami in the first game, the sequel brings another character that is the polar opposite of Yagami.
The story is not as grand as the first game and halfway point it feels forced because Yagami keep mentioning the part where the antagonist done again and again. It's not a bad story per se, but compared to Judgement the quality went down.

The actual story length:
In Judgement there's a perfect balance between the story and exploring (side cases, mini games, GF, etc), whenever I'm doing a story it feels like the game would indirectly give me a brief time to stop so I could explore the world. The story isn't too long but not too short-- rather each chapter you progress it feels like the story is getting longer.
In Lost Judgement there's barely a stopping point. Like I said, the story is not bad so it's easy to get hooked but the problem is each chapter is too short. I was at chapter 7 when I started to worry if the story is gonna spike up soon and starts bringing the main dish because I barely did anything and was already halfway through the game. 
There's also barely a stopping point unlike in the first game so I was blasting through the story quite fast. Well you think it's my fault for not exploring on my own right? Well I did that and guess what? The side cases you did is mostly going to be from school club activity which I'm unsatisfied with (more down below).
It's fine if you think this kinda game is meant to be enjoyed by exploring stuff, do mini games, side cases, etc, you can trust me on this, I am not exaggerating when I said it's really short.

Also side note, this game barely have the option to sleep on sofa which I sometimes need since some GF cases unlocks on certain time.

Side Case:
In the previous game you mostly get Side Cases from the board in your office (and some of them from world encounter). But in this game the side cases came mostly from the school activity club and there's barely cases sent to the detective agency.
I'm not saying that these cases are bad or anything, most of them are great story wise (while some of them I think it's there just because?) but there is no variety in terms of story, the quest you do, the people you met, etc like in Judgement where almost every cases is different / a follow up from the case you've done.

This isn't all of them but it is my biggest gripe, but nonetheless I still really enjoyed it. Also buy the DLC as it's a step up from the base game IMO.

Lost Judgment does everything better than Judgment. Right from the beginning , fighting feels faster and more responsive, and the change of scenery for Yokohama is more than welcome.   No more being stuck in the tiny and oppressive Kamurocho. 
Secondly, the game is split between the main story and the optional School story, so there's a good deal of content if you don't skip it.  

Before writing about the story, i want to mention some of the other changes, improvements and new things that have been added.  
_An entirely optional Story tied to the School that takes a bit of grinding 
_Plenty of new side quests, and several new gadget that are needed for them, like a signal detector.
_2 new fighting style, Snake and Boxing (included DLC ); Snake being so strong that i almost only used it past a certain point. 
_Lots of new minigames related to the School, some of them being good, some of them very tedious.
_Drone racing has been improved. The drone on the other hand has barely any use during the main story.
_Yokohama being much larger than Kamurocho, you can use a Skateboard to move around faster, with the ability to do some tricks.
_The Keyholder has been completely removed, and one the lockpiciking minigame too.
_There is humor from time to time, but this is still far from Yakuza.
_The events of Judgment are barely mentioned,  making it a lot more optional to play it prior.
_There's tons of minigames like in every other games from the same studio that are completely optional !

About the high school/main story ; 

_Despite being a bit grindy and tedious, the High School part of the game is what i liked the most ! Some of the clubs were engaging, some of the mini games where actually quite fun, some not and the whole plot surrounding this was enjoyable. I felt very attached to the students near the end, and the last part , to unravel the mystery was very heartwarming !

_The main story is better, but also has a pacing problem. Unlike in Judgment though, here, things are going too fast. Probably not to make a game too long i think, but i felt most of the chapters were very short !

From the beginning, with the informations you are given, you can very quickly find what the end goal for the whole situation is, so it is more about finding all the steps and means that served to create such situation, and there was some good surprises here, which is something the first game is missing a lot.

Near the end, the focus is once more about questioning the player about their perception of Justice.  This time though, several events in the game pushes you very hard on one side, which i found a bit disappointing.

The characters implicated in the events felt much move likable and relatable too.


Conclusion : I liked this game to the point i would recommend it without having played Judgment. The story is nice, a bit on the short side, but it is compensated by the optional storyline tied to the High School. Some clutter has been removed, some added, tons of side content and minigames, all that bundled in the quality that this studio is known for. A very good game !

My Judgment? Lost.

‚óò Before getting into either game I heard that Lost Judgment was just a strict upgrade to the first game. So, going into LJ, my expectations were really high. And while I can't say the game met those expectations, it wasn't bad by any stretch.

‚óò A lot of people herald it as having the best combat in the series, but my core gripe with that statement is the difficulty. Yes, the combat is deep, and cool, and flashy, and Yagami has a lot of tools to play with and it's very skill expressive. There's nothing in the game that can stand up to getting the Crane Hidden Art attack speed, and just spamming Tiger charged attacks, or going into Boxer EX Boost. Every enemy in the game except Amon just folds in the face of Yagami's most basic combat options, let alone the laundry list of more obscure mechanics he has as you delve deeper into the combat. Judgment on Legend was WAY harder T_T than Lost Judgment on the same difficulty. And to me, that's a huge disappointment.

‚óò In terms of the story, I struggle to articulate exactly how I'd compare the two, but at current the way I'll put it is something to the tune of; Judgment's story is more "solid", generally being higher quality from start to finish and being a great crime thriller, while Lost Judgment's story is more emotional, more compelling, and has a better villain/core ideological struggle. I wouldn't definitively say one is better than the other.

One of my bigger gripes with Lost Judgment outside of the combat is the side content. Some of the side content is really, really good, like the Boxing‚òª and Biking questlines (good but get to repetitive IMO). And some of it is really, really shit, like how 10 of the game's 42 Substories are devoted to the completely shit "Dastardly Detective" plotline. Actually deplorable that so many Substory slots are taken up by that. I haven't gone back and reviewed all of them to properly form a final opinion, but currently I think the Substory content in the game is very poor, while the School Story content ranged from excellent to okay-ish, depending on the club.

‚óò Overall for me this game is solid 7/10 (+1 because they added dating girl from the Judment series (‚ô•_‚ô•) )

If people say Yakuza 0 is the best Yakuza game, then this is the greatest game ever conceptualized by humanity. It's got everything.

Gameplay: Easily the best in the entire series. Lost Judgment's combat makes the rest of the series look like a goddamn tech demo. Each of Yagami's main 3 styles has more depth than any style in the series prior, and Boxer style is an awesome addition on top of them. On top of that, any enemy who has a presence in the story has a unique moveset this time around, unlike the first Judgment which suffered from a lot of copied movesets. The detective-esque minigames from the prior Judgment have also been improved as well, with tailing being actually somewhat enjoyable. The only part of the gameplay I don't like is the stealth missions. Fuck the stealth missions.

Plot: Without saying anything spoilery, the plot is bold. It focuses on actual issues in the real world and handles them with maturity. The characters are also all written extremely well and seem like actual people you could meet or hear about in the news.

Music and Sound: It's a Sega game. The soundtrack is not only phenomenal, but also extremely varied and has something for everyone. The sounds themselves are also great, with big hits having big impacts and small hits not deafening you. In addition, the English dub is incredibly well done and probably the best in the series as of now (though there's only 2 others to really compete with for now). I'd even say I prefer a good chunk of the English voices to the Japanese voices.

Side Content: Being a game in the Yakuza series, of course the game is loaded with tons of enjoyable side content. Though there are only 42 side cases listed in the completion list, this is only because there are 10 whole storylines through the introduction of School Stories, where Yagami becomes an advisor for clubs in the school and tries to solve the mystery of an anonymous individual called "the professor" who has been causing huge amounts of delinquency in Yokohama. Definitely some of the best side content I've ever played in a game, and probably the best in the Yakuza series.

The Kaito Files: An additional paid DLC that takes place after the main game, focusing mainly on Kaito and his past life. Even though it is much less serious and significantly shorter than the main story, it is still a very nice epilogue-esque addition to the game. His combat features two upgraded versions of Kiryu's Brawler and Beast styles that are both very fun to use. Though the DLC only adds 6 new tracks, each of them is just as good as any of the main game's music, if not even better. There is almost no side content with the Kaito Files outside of a superboss and some nice references. Also, Kaito's stealth is actually pretty okay. Still not that good, but it's not bad.

Final review:
Lost Judgment (Base game): 9.5/10, definitely worth the $60 if you're a fan of the Yakuza series. (Although you should play 7/Like a Dragon before this one, because Lost Judgment's plot has a lot to do with a significant event that occurs in it.)

Kaito Files DLC: 8/10, if you really liked the base game and don't want to wait for a sale, it's worth the full $30. However, for anyone else who just plays casually, I'd say wait for at least a 30% sale so you can get it for around $20 or less.

Perfection of the brawler-style combat that RGG Studio has been honing for years. With kung-fu, crane, Aikido, and now straight-up boxing, there's a flavor of bone-crushing or judo-flipping tailor-made for just about everyone's personal tastes. The main plot scales back a bit compared to Judgment in favor of the expansive sidestories, the School Stories. As someone else said about the first game, stop reading the reviews and play the game yourself! But if you're stubborn like I am, keep reading! If you've played any of the previous Yakuza games, you'll like this one. It's among my favourites already! If you haven't played the others, I'd still recommend it. Depends on how cautious you want to be regarding certain changes in the lore of the Yakuza series. Anyways, be warned of general side content spoilers, as well as an extremely vague overview of the story (no details whatsoever). 

Firstly, this game is awesome! Everything about it. If the first Judgment was the Dragon Engine's Kiwami, then in the reverse order of things; this is Dragon Engine's 0. In almost every way possible. From the four fighting styles, to the absurd amount of deep mini-games, to the endlessly entertaining side cases; this game has it all. Great graphics, beautiful music, an amazing presentation overall. You won't want to stop playing!

Secondly, it's a huge game. I have 107 hours at the time of this review. I've only completed around 60% of the game. That's including the main story and all the side cases, some general stuff too. There's so much more to do if you want to be a completionist. It's an addictive game! You can join a robotics club, a biker gang, a boxing gym, a dancing club, etc. There's photography, arcade games in arcades and at home, skateboarding, gambling, darts, batting, VR games, etc. You can even get four different girlfriends! In the game, probably not for real! My favourites are the side cases, dancing, boxing, and robotics. The side cases are a lot of fun. Hilarious, and almost always bigger than they initially seem. A lot of them are interconnected with each other, and are related to the various mini games. That's a trademark of this series, how everything you do is made bigger through the characters you play, and the ones you encounter. 

So let's talk of these characters. Overall, a similar cast. But with some remarkable additions that make the story more engaging. Yagami is cool as always, tries to be sensible, he's fairly believable though naive at times in terms of his beliefs. Kaito is hilarious, clumsy, and awesome. Made even better with his own story, the Kaito files were epic! Sugiura is still a nuisance, but he's part of the team. Tsukumo is the ultimate problem solver. Genda law office people are still there, and oh man Saori-san! The antagonists of the game will be made well known to you, and they're among the most memorable ones in the series. You'll just have to see for yourself.

The story itself covers a wide range of sensitive topics in a fair and balanced way. Those being sexual harassment, bullying, suicide, murder, justice, corruption, etc. They give way for nuance rather than sticking to stereotypes, which is what makes the story interesting. How they managed to connect so many different facets of life together in a believable and well put manner is beyond me. Some moments have becomes memes, however serious they may have been intended to be initially. The death of the author, look it up! 

How about the main gameplay loop? It's a bit different to the first game. The first one really hammered in the detective side of things, and that was something I enjoyed a lot. But in this game, it's more varied.

As usual, the game weaves together the gameplay with the main story, linking it to side content when it can. Tailing has improved, being much more free flow than it was in the first game. Which makes it more believable. Inspection mode has also been improved thanks to the new gadgets that add more layers to the experience. Makes a lot of sense for a modern detective!

Fighting is contender for the best in the series so far, rivalling 0 easily. Four fighting styles that are all distinct but can be switched between at will, leading to endless creative options for you to explore, with the most insane juggles the games have seen so far. It's ridiculous, in a good way. 

The best thing that they did here is they've made Crane useful! Man, it was a meme in the first game. Now it's actually insanely good! Mainly due to its own counter that allows you to combo the opponent. Each style has its own purpose, which I like. Snake allows you to parry everything and forever. Get those weapons outta here! But you can't move for shit. Tiger has tiger drop, of course. Flux tissure is tough, but still super good. Boxing allows for so many counters, charge moves, launching attacks, stun links, and the ability to sway in and out. Though it's fairly limited in terms of EX moves, and its movement is not as good as Crane or Tiger.

They've also added stealth and parkour, which feel like mechanics that could/should have been here before. Rather basic, but they do the job. A problem is how they're only used when they game wants you to use them, you have no choice of doing them freely. I'd prefer that they weren't so basic, since they appear more often than lockpicking does. Which has also been simplified, no more thumb turn bypasses. No lockpicking jobs either. A little strange.

Contender for best soundtrack. From the songs in each fighting style, to the main menu theme and how dynamic it is, to the boss themes, even the old substory music we've grown to love since ancient times. Man, the boss themes are epic. Viper, Unwavering Belief, Liumang's Chant, K.O.G, even the generic boss theme Vorarephilia is sick! Of course, the Kaito files has awesome stuff too! The Crimson Devil, A Duel for Love, epic stuff! Special mention to Amon's theme Lineage of Clan.

RGG know what they're doing. They know what we want, and they keep giving it to us. Is it perfect? No. But is it as close to that as they can do in almost every game? Pretty much. Still some work to be done to flesh out certain things that are too basic or simply outdated. Some of that is part of the charm, while the rest is a bit annoying. Overall, it's incredible how they managed to make so many good games in this series. And how this spin off feels right at home. As if this is the 10th Judgment game, and not the second one. Fantastic achievement on their part! I hope that there are no more problems, and that they can go ahead and make another one!

I usually start my reviews with some general statement about the game as a sort of digestible single-verse sentiment. My feelings towards Lost Judgment are so thoroughly entwined with adoration that this is the best I can come up with:

Lost Judgment isn't just RGG's finest game, or a landmark title for the genre, but a work of emotional maturity so engrossing that I would eagerly recommend it to anyone that plays video games.

There are your hallmarks for a RGG game- ridiculous side quests, an abundance of minigames, and a definite appreciate for tongue-in-cheek humor at the best of times- but the main story readily surpasses any and all praise I could heap upon those aspects, individual or collective. I won't act as though it's a high point for literature, but as far as video games go, there are few that hit me with such an emotional weight while still remaining thoroughly grounded in reality. 

Lost Judgment looks at the bitter and cruel side of humanity. It takes our aptitude for social violence and radical justification and drags it out into the spotlight, contrasting it harshly with a real commitment to truth, both arbitrary and otherwise, and weaves a beautifully dark story with those themes. I really liked Yagami in his debut game, but Lost Judgment made me love him, and I can say the same for pretty much every last character in this game, but none more so than the antagonist, who did absolutely not a single thing wrong. 

Though I skimmed over it earlier, Lost Judgment's main host of side content is tied into a school setting, with Yagami placed in a variety of clubs under the guise of a counselor; this partially acts as a reasoning for you to get involved with minigames, and partially as an umbrella under which many distinct substories are joined together in pursuit of a single culprit causing problems for the school and its students. I absolutely loved this design decision; as a Persona fan, it really scratched a similar itch that series managed to reach.

The combat, too, is RGG's absolute best to date. Taking four individual combat styles and allowing them to be swapped between with ease mid-combo takes things one step above Yakuza 0, and hit way closer to a real character action game than I ever could have expected. I do feel that the third, original new style, is a touch underpowered in comparison to the two from the first game and the DLC style, but I had similar gripes with the former in Judgment, and they've been tweaked to perfection here. 

I always try to remain balanced and fair in my reviews, but when I look back at my 130 hours in this game, I can't think of a single lasting fault. A few underbaked mechanics, an underwhelming side story here and there, but nothing that amounted to anything truly detrimental. 

I adored Yakuza 7, and to this day consider it to be one of my all-time favorite games. 

I'm shocked how much Lost Judgment blew it out of the water.

My highest possible recommendation.
