Lost Judgment is what a sequel should be. It brings a lot of improvements over the original Judgment and while it has some drawbacks, its strengths far outweighs its blemishes. Lost Judgment is one of RGG's best games to date.

The story and themes about bullying, the flaw in legal system and the act of vengeance when you take justice into your own hands are done expertly in Lost Judgment. You end up understanding and even rooting for the antagonist due to how believable their beliefs and motives. While the original Judgment is much more focused on neo-noir crime action drama, resulting in big climatic battle about what it actually means to sacrifice something for the greater good of society and a tale of redemption, Lost Judgment takes a different approach. It is much more grounded and arguably more low stakes than its predecessor, but it also strikes much more deeper in what it says about society, especially concerning bullying and legal system. This results in a much more emotionally-driven battles of ideologies where neither sides are fully in the right and wrong. Long after the credit rolls, Lost Judgment manages to make me think longer about its themes. Overall, great story told in a beautiful way with some of the best written characters RGG has ever made.

Combat is improved so much to the point that I can safely say that this is RGG's best brawler-type combat. The 4 fighting styles are all unique and balanced. You are encouraged to utilize all the styles' strengths in different scenarios therefore making the combat varied and always exciting to do. The bosses are all great, especially the major boss like Soma or Akutsu or Kuwana. These 3 are top-tier bosses with stellar dynamic intros and soundtrack themes. In short, Lost Judgment perfected Dragon Engine real time combat.

The environment, now the majority of time taking place in Ijincho from Yakuza 7/Like A Dragon, still looks beautiful as ever. With the added skateboard for traversal, making running from one side of the city to the other a breeze and enjoyable. Plus Yagami has a detective dog now which you can use to wander around town collecting items and even skillbooks scattered throughout the city. Activities in Ijincho also can be expanded further through the School Stories side story, ranging from Skateboard minigame, Biker, Casino, and the greatest new addition of all, The Seiryo High School. Built in such detail with every classes, club rooms, gymnasium, etc. Seiryo school is one of the best location RGG has made and it offers a variety of side cases and club activities. Kamurocho is also back, looking great as ever but due to the fewer side cases/things to do in Kamurocho, it ends up not comparable to how much Ijincho offers in terms of things to do. 

School Story is a major addition to Lost Judgment, tasking Yagami into Mystery Research Club in Seiryo High School. 10 school clubs, each with different minigames, most of them are addicting and really fun to do. The highlights are the Dance Club, Biker Gang, Skateboard and Boxing Gym. All of them have extensive stories with well-written characters in each of them. Stories about standing up to yourself, friendship, romance are all in School Story, making the lives of many Seiryo students so much more relatable. There are some frustrating moments, though, like in Robotics Club where the RNG in certain match is really bad, but it's just a small annoying thing in a sea of other great activities. Aside from this, side cases this time around have more recurring-type of cases where one cases lead to another, resulting in a series of cases about a certain individuals. I found this to be good and bad. The good part is that it sells the idea that it takes quite a bit of time to solve cases, and it has much more room to build up certain situations or relationship about certain NPC, the bad part is that it lacks variety in the overall side cases. But overall, the side cases are still as great as the previous entries, with some of the most hilarious, wholesome and exciting in the series. Plus some characters from the original Judgment makes comebacks in some of the side cases, and even The School Story which is always a great thing.

That said, there are some questionable changes and just downright worse changes in Lost Judgment over its predecessor. The item shortcut now only has 1 slot. There's only 1 button to change fighting styles even though Yagami has 4 styles to choose. Mortal Wounds are gone now (which is a good thing actually) but it does remove the danger of Mortal Attacks from bosses. The eating animation is gone and replaced by just text pop up and bust image. The friend system is gone, even though it makes the city much more lively with different vendor npc and their short stories. The side cases tied to Girlfriends are awful, the stories and characters in those side cases are actually good but the fact that you need to essentially do the Girlfriend activity to complete the side cases (plus with the added DLC, meaning you "have" to cheat multiple girlfriends) is worse compared to how Girlfriends worked in the original Judgment. You can't reject girlfriends' love confessions is just awful and really weird, considering you can in original Judgment. The message function in Yagami's phone is not used enough for the other activities, this also applies to some of the detective segments that are not used enough in the main story and side cases, like the lockpicking, tailing (though it is improved a lot better now), disguise and drone. In fact, there is no single moment where you need to use drone in any of the main story or side cases which is baffling, considering that drone played quite a big part in some missions in the original Judgment.

Overall though, these blemishes are nothing major. Lost Judgment is still one of the best RGG games to date. An improvement over its predecessor with a much more grounded story and much more grey area the theme goes to explore. RGG instant classic, with lots of things to do, more charms in almost every activities, stellar combat that is always exciting to do and deep complex story about bullying and flawed legal system.

Before I dive into why I gave this a negative review, I'd like to point out that this is my replay of the game. I played it first when it launched in 2021 and actually finished it in one sitting (17 hours) and I wasn't a fan of it then. When the game finally released on PC I thought to myself let's give it another shot and see how I feel. Once again, I felt the same but let me make it clear, there's only one reason I disliked LJ and that is it's writing.

Judgment (LJ's predecessor) was a masterpiece in it's writing, combat, incredible environments and movie-like cinematics. Pretty much just like any Yakuza/RGG game you've played. LJ on the other hand felt like such a huge downgrade in terms of it's writing and story. See I was prepared to accept the fact LJ wasn't going to top JE in it's writing due to how high of a bar the first game set, it was impossible to top it. I knew that, but I expected far better in LJ which to be honest, it wasn't. There was a lot going on, so much that at one point you don't understand what your main goal is, what your actually trying to achieve. It felt overbearing and just added specific parts into the game just for the shock factor. It feels much like Yakuza 5 where you have separate stories happening at one time and when you conjoin them it just feels messy and all over the place. Not to mention how some of the beloved characters from the first game barely get more than 10 minutes of screentime in this one which is such a shame.

I will praise the game for its biggest highlight for me and that is it's combat. Absolute peak combat that the series has seen, so fleshed out and hugely improved on from it's predecessor and not to forget the new styles added are amazing. Style switching is faster, more smooth and solid. It's perfection and it's one of the main reasons why I kept going the first time round and the same again. I really tried my hardest to like this game, to give it a fair second chance but alas my mind has not changed.

I have spent more time playing Yakuza titles in the last few years than any other game franchise or series by a longshot. Every time I finish one, I tell myself, "that's it, there's no way they can make the next game as good as this." With the way most studios end up burning their own beloved IP into the ground, you would expect it to happen for the Yakuza universe too. 

However, instead of becoming an abject failure of a studio like some, RGG somehow manages to publish yet another amazing game in Lost Judgement. A few impressions for those who have yet to invest:


Mechanics: the brawls are as chaotic and showy as ever, retaining and building on the highly enjoyable combat of previous titles. The mini games are more addicting than hard drugs. The character banter is witty, and the amount of explorable space and things to do is truly remarkable. I was just expecting Kamurocho plus maybe a small district to travel to, but they went all out and made it a lot of total playable space without running out of amusements and side tasks to fill it out. 


Story: the plot hits all the classic Yakuzaverse high notes--a strong protagonist with deep convictions about justice, and the importance in standing up for your personal code of honor. There's a lot of short, funny moments, juxtaposed against larger story themes that examine some of the really messed up shit in society. Without spoiling anything, one example that really got me was a depiction of some sociopathic kids that made a habit out of bullying someone. They didn't pull any punches in showing how life-ruining it can be to find yourself trapped in that situation with no one to turn to for help. The writers don't shy away from the harsh reality of it, which makes the story surprisingly emotional. 


General Vibe: One last thing I really enjoy--much as mainline Yakuza titles have overtones of the crime film genre, Lost Judgement is likewise wrapped in a veneer of film noir and classic detective movies. It gives the series its own distinct place in the RGG ecosystem and I like the alternate approaches both types of protagonists take to get to the same end result. 

Performance: For reference I'm using an RTX3070--at the launch of Yakuza: Like a Dragon it took a while to get the game playing smoothly on my setup  The team has really improved the games on PC--not sure about Lost Judgement at launch, but currently it runs flawlessly on my PC at 1440p. Have settings maxed, DLSS running and never see frame drops below 60FPS which is a big improvement over the somewhat variable performance I expected.

Get it now while it's on sale, it's worth every dime in my book.

Cheers and happy New Year, kyodais!

I have not played it's prequel Judgment but I have played Yakuza 0, Kiwami, Kiwami 2, and Like a Dragon. Overall, the game is okay. As for the story, usual Yakuza stuff where it just escalates into higher ups and police and top gangs and what not. Compared to other Yakuza stories, it was pretty low-tier. Maybe it was because Sawa-sensei was getting a shit ton of attention and focus despite being such a bitch.
 It was weird how some cutscenes allowed you to skip dialogue and some didn't, also it would bug out where you actually had to let them say a couple of words otherwise you don't get to skip the next line of dialogue. I think it was me but when the game introduces the character for the first time, it lasts for 20 seconds for me.

For most of the game, I played on Hard difficulty but the combat was still quite easy. I switched between Simple and Hard and the difference was that enemies had less health, hits you with a feather, and the AI uses combat moves for you such as activating skills and switching between stances. The extracts that you get are extremely overpowered but fits well for how difficult and annoying they are to acquire and store, I never had to use these extracts until the last couple of fights and legit swept them. The EX skills were quite annoying as they take a long time to finish animating. Combat is easily the strong point of this game and carries it pretty hard. The few side missions that I have done were interesting but nothing note-worthy in my opinion, they were better in Yakuza.

The annoying parts of the game:

The fucking school stories, I swear this section took up at least a third of my play time. It was extremely annoying just navigating through the school because you would do a mission for a club and then you have to return to the MCR to talk to the wanna-be detective hoe.

The Dance Club was actually pretty fun because it was just stepmania.

The Robotics Club was interesting but a fucking time sink if you actually play this above Simple difficulty because the enemy AI are nuts and you actually need to have materials to upgrade your robot parts so you have to play practice matches as well as buy mats at other places to win.

The Boxing Gym was cool but repetitive and also hard as fuck on Hard difficulty. I managed to get through most of the opponents on Hard by just spamming buttons but fucking Kenya is a beast who parries and blocks 95% of your shit and I had to tone it down to Simple.

The Biker Gang is probably the one I hate the most because it doesn't even feel like a race. You have to drive into and hit 10-20 other bikers before you actually get to race and when you're finally racing with the last guy, you can't outpace him, no matter what, he's a set distance away from you so if you happen to make a couple of mistakes at the end, you're done for. So you have around 4 boss races that you have to win and each boss has 3 lackies so you have to race for around 16 times to complete this garbage.

The Photography Club, you just take pictures.

The eSports Club, spam buttons in street fighter, win.

The Casino, you don't actually get to play for real, you auto lose and then auto win.

The Girls' Bar is another grind. You have to drink and talk to 4 girls and complete their side missions in order to complete this section. If you don't have the drunkenness limit, it'll take a long time since the only way to quickly get rid of being drunk is to go into a fight and use the EX drunk skill with 6+ drunk and get rid of the whole meter or drink a bunch of liquids.

That's all for the school stories which is a huge part of this game. I dislike the stealth, climbing, and chasing mechanics because it just feels like they waste time. There's no real skill, it's a pretty linear path for the direction that you're going in, all it does is waste your time.

A fantastic title from the Ryu Ga Gotoku. The sequel to Judgment is just as entertaining and fascinating as the first, and if you love Yakuza games, this is another one to add to your collection. As in the Yakuza games, the main protagonist is Takayuki Yagami, a former lawyer turned freelance detective who now finds himself in another job assignment that goes far deeper than he first thought and brings him closer to some people in the government than he suspected. The game encourages and rewards exploration, and while it is not an entirely open world, there is enough exploration in the city and beyond to keep you entertained. Along the way, you can do side missions for clients or help people in the City, as well as play a few side games ranging from Dancing, Boxing, and Drone Racing  

The school stories are a lot of fun, with interesting stories and characters, and I've found myself paying more attention to them than the main story, which isn't to say the main story is bad. The main plot is amazing. Once again, I found myself emotionally attached to the characters and eager to find out what happens next. There are parts that are shocking and parts that make me laugh. Overall, it's a Masterpiece game.

Not as good as the first Judgment, which I thought was excellent, but still a good sequel. I think the story overall was not well done, though it has plenty of great moments. It sort of has two halves to it.

The first half is better and closer to what I expected with the detective aspects and discovering all the elements surrounding the main case. I feel the mystery here is good and on par with the first game.

The latter half feels less natural, as if redeveloped afterwards where they couldn't figure out how to take the story further to make something longer and more climactic. There's some good stuff here, but my biggest issue with it is that it adds little new and very slowly compared to the first half. You're constantly location hopping just to hear the same conversations and names drop in attempts to get slightly new information. The mystery and detective elements feel dead where you're instead either beating around the bush or just pressuring others until someone finally gives you something new or some new event occurs.

Other stuff:
The evidence selection and questioning this time around feels more tacked on than something where you're needing to make meaningful, thought out choices. For me it tended to usually be either completely obvious what to pick where it's  the latest piece of evidence you just obtained moments ago (why is there even a choice here?), or sometimes confusingly ambiguous (many of these could technically apply).

The trailing, sneaking, and photography were minimally used as gameplay elements. The climbing stuff which I believe is new felt unwelcome a lot of times since they were long and slowed down the pacing.

The school setting was something new and neat, but I was disappointed with [spoiler]how little it's actually used overall in the main story.[/spoiler] 

The school stories, which is sort of a primary sidequest not connected to the main story, is way too long, unbalanced in how time is divided between the clubs, heavily padded with repetitive minigame requirements, and does not fit at all chronologically when doing them in the middle of the main story (where some of the activities are likely taking place over at least several weeks). Some of the minigames are pretty fun and had a lot of development put into them, but I was exhausted at the end due to how many times they make you do them to progress.

The game is, for me at least, unwelcomely more violent. Despite being rated M, Judgment and the Yakuza games (though I've only played 2 of all of them) were comparatively tame. It was something I appreciated going into any of them since I knew I'd get some good mature drama and action without anything too unsettling. Overall this was [spoiler]thankfully nearly at the same level, but there is a pretty graphic murder scene and a one time mild threat of sexual assault on a story character.[/spoiler]

Lost Judgment is the sequel to Judgment, and another spin off from the Yakuza series. While investigating accusations of student bullying at a high school, player character Takayuki Yagami is asked to look into a murder case which might also have links to the school.

[h1]Familiar gameplay[/h1]

‚Ä¢	Lost Judgment mostly takes place in the Ijincho area of Yokohama, which was the setting for the Like A Dragon game starring Ichiban Kasuga, but you‚Äôll get to spend some time back in Kamurocho as well.

‚Ä¢	Like the previous game, the third person melee combat is played in real time. There are now four different fighting styles (tiger, crane, snake and boxer), which are intended to be used in different situations, but honestly I just stuck with snake for most of the game, while playing on the hard difficulty. It feels kinda similar to the Arkham games, where pressing block at the correct time leaves enemies vulnerable to a counter attack. There‚Äôs also a very useful move where you can grab enemies who are wielding weapons to disarm them. And some special moves can be triggered on enemies who are scared of you, which causes Yagami to punch or kick the air beside their head to make them faint in terror, which looks really funny.

‚Ä¢	Main story, which focuses on bullying and flaws in the legal system, is well written, fully voiced, and voice acting is excellent. Yagami continues to be a very likeable protagonist, while his allies who return from the first game are also interesting characters.

‚Ä¢	In addition to the main story, there are lots of substories featuring PI cases and wacky situations, some of which involve hour long investigations, or have multiple parts.

‚Ä¢	Many of the entertainment minigames seen previously in the Yakuza series are included again such as golf, baseball, darts, VR dice game, House of the Dead style shooter, and various Sega arcade games. Plus there‚Äôs a new Geometry Wars style twin stick shooter, and Yagami has a Master System console in his office in Kamurocho where you can play 10+ old games.

‚Ä¢	I didn‚Äôt have any problems with bugs, crashes or framerate, and the controls work well most of the time on my xbox 360 gamepad.

[h1]School stories[/h1]

‚Ä¢	Lost Judgment also features a lot of content related to a secondary investigation, where Yagami is asked to join 10 different clubs that all have a connection to school students, and a criminal mastermind called the Professor. These clubs all have their own lengthy storylines and contain unique minigames.

‚Ä¢	This secondary storyline is significantly longer than the main story, but this isn‚Äôt necessarily a good thing. Most clubs take around 4-5 hours each to complete, which eventually made the game feel bloated, while also hurting the flow of the main story. In total it took me 83 hours to finish the game, and I haven‚Äôt started the Kaito Files DLC yet. 

‚Ä¢	For example, to complete the boxing club storyline you need to defeat more than 20 opponents. To complete the motorcycle club storyline you need to win 16 races. The dance, robotics and skateboard clubs all require you to do multiple practice matches before each round of their tournaments. In robotics you can customise your robots with various parts and you‚Äôll probably need to grind a few more practice matches to earn crafting components. Its really excessive and feels repetitive.

‚Ä¢	Some of the minigames are quite easy. Dance is a rhythm game similar to Haruka‚Äôs in Yakuza 5. In skateboarding you have to ride around a skate park and perform tricks to earn points. In Esports you‚Äôll play the Sega arcades version of Virtua Fighter 5 Showdown. Boxing (more challenging but thankfully I did win every fight on my first attempt) is like a 3D Street Fighter.

‚Ä¢	However, the robotics and motorcycle clubs both have poorly designed control schemes and feature difficult opponents. Robotics is a 3v3 battle where you have to collect and place tetris blocks to capture territory on a grid, and motorcycle involves death races where you have to knock several other riders off their bikes while they attack you with molotovs, baseball bats, etc, and then race a boss to the finish line. Any time I lost a match more than once I quickly started to feel frustrated, knowing that I was still quite far from completing the game.

‚Ä¢	Meanwhile, these school club storylines feature a lot of dialogue related to unnecessary subplots. Every club has multiple members, there‚Äôs usually a rival club which also has multiple members, every one of these characters has a tragic backstory, or an issue with a family member or a romantic interest or an internal club conflict, and in between every round of the minigames, yet another of these dozens of minor characters wants to spend several minutes discussing their feelings with you. I value story more than many gamers, but even for me these storylines started to lose my interest because of how much they dragged on with pointless conversations that didn‚Äôt connect in any way to my actual investigation of the Professor.
 
[h1]Recommendation[/h1]

Lost Judgment does have some good moments and I still recommend playing it if you‚Äôre a fan of the series, but if I had to rank all the Yakuza and Judgment games, I‚Äôd put Lost Judgment near the bottom of the list.

While the combat is fun and the variety of different activities is interesting for a while, the number of times you need to play and win each minigame eventually feels repetitive and grindy, while the number of hours it takes to do so has a negative impact on the pacing of the main story, which is usually a key strength of this franchise.

Haven't finished the game but I don't think I'm jumping the gun in saying this is one of my absolute favorite RGG games I think I've ever played. On top of the electrifying combat and improved styles from the base game, this installment brings not one, but TWO (if you bought it with DLC like any normal person should) new styles that drastically switch up the gameplay in more ways than I can describe. This game's ludicrous amount of fighting styles is reminiscent of Yakuza 0, and it possesses the same versatility in combat with the added touch of Judgment's many trademark moves (the counterattacks are SOOOO AWESOME!!!). Maybe it's just that LAD left me craving the olden days of Yakuza combat, but this was certainly something I was missing for a long while. Years, probably.

But there's more to love! And, surprisingly, it's the game's story! Having played through a total of 9 RGG titles with the same general setting, tone, and conspiracy plot, it's hard not to get a little disillusioned with every twist and turn they throw our way with every passing installment. I think the peak of my annoyance with the franchise's winding plots was Yakuza 4 (you all know what twist I mean), but the series gradually found ways to keep it fresh as it entered Ichiban's journey in Y7. Upon playing Judgment, a game lauded for its superior story to its sister franchise, I was a little unimpressed with its structure, finding it to have a pace comparable to that of a TV show, not a game. I went into Lost Judgment with lower expectations, considering how more people seemed to dislike this one's plot than the first. 

And yet, this game managed to blow those expectations away. A more focused narrative than the first, with every aspect of the main story mattering in uncovering a puzzle that's less concerned with the well-treaded ground of organized crime syndicates like the Yakuza, Jingweon, or Triads and more concerned with a simple, unifying topic: Bullying.

It seems a little stupid, at first. Yagami and the gang solve bullying! But, oddly enough, this game takes no hard stances and throws no softballs dealing with the subject, as well as the nature of culpability, guilt, and (obviously) justice. In many ways, that makes this game's main idea seem more thematically relevant than its predecessor, with a complex issue in the case of right or wrong that can't be watered down to a simple conclusion. Characters on both sides of this debate are sympathetic, and don't (SPOILERS FOR JUDGMENT 1) have their character motivations chalked up to desiring power or fame in the final stretch of the story. Essentially, it's almost groundbreaking how mature this game handles its subject matter, especially considering how childish RGG can seem with some other installments and their quandaries of philosophy and morality.

This game runs great on a LAPTOP too. What's not to love? I'll update my thoughts after finishing, but I have to say this is definitely up there.

I bought a PS4 just to play the Judgment games, and I was not disappointed whatsoever.

Purely cause of this one.

The story is one of the best in the Yakuza series (Even though it's a spin off) purely cause it's grounded and tackles a problem that relates to many common folk.

The combat is also the absolute best in the entire series.

There are 3 styles in total (4 with a DLC, but that seems to be automatically given when you buy the game)
Each of which are extremely useful in almost every situation (Compared to Judgment where Crane becomes obsolete halfway through the game).

Crane: centered towards evasion and crowd control, but it's speed allows it to even be useful against bosses.

Tiger: all about damage and heavy hitting strikes, nuff said.

Snake: Perfect for when you're surrounded or up against enemies with weapons, useful against bosses as well.

Boxer: The "DLC" style, think of it as a fleshed out far more unique and far more fun Rush style that Kiryu had.

All of these are always usable from the very start till the credits roll and combined with juggling and fast style switching allows you to pull off stylish combos and decimate foes.

It's clear that RGG saw what was popular and what was despised in Judgment, and decided to fix everything and all that was popular was doped up on enough cocaine to even make your average Miami citizen overdose.

Here's hoping RGG implement this amount of options in combat and uniqueness in their other games that follow the usual real time combat. And here's hoping Like A Dragon 8 turn based combat follows in the footsteps of the Judgment series, 7 being the seed, and 8 being grown to such a degree that even people that don't like such combat in games are able to like it.

Decided to play this and the original Judgment since I had a blast with the Yakuza games. A lot of things are fantastic with this game and I believe this is my favorite game that I've played in years. The story all the way through was a suspenseful iceberg that kept uncovering more and more pieces until it eventually turned the original plot on it's head. The gameplay was tight and highly responsive, especially compared to it's predecessor game while simultaneously introducing new styles and movesets to keep things fresh. The characters were developed very well and felt genuine with their beliefs and actions, especially the main antagonist who was a perfect capstone/key player to the story since you as the player can sympathize with their choices even if they aren't the most ethical. The music was downright full of bangers which made encounters more enjoyable and made the settings more ambient assuming you're into EDM. The side content is plentiful and mostly optional though some of it hits while other parts miss in terms of enjoyment. Overall, I'd highly recommend this game if you're a fan of beat em up's, rpgs, and/or story rich games as this one checks all of the above and won't disappoint.

[h1]Pros[/h1]
+ Great graphics
+ Fantastic new characters
+ Great story
+ Incredible combat; IMO the best in the series
+ 3 (+1 DLC) polished styles of combat; massive improvement from its predecessor
+ Say goodbye to the tedium of running; you can now call taxis from your smartphone and skateboard around town
+ Side/school stories are phenomenal
+ Wide array of side activities; robot wars, boxing, burnout bike racing, skateboarding, dancing, on top of the usual RGG ones
+ You get a [b]Detective Dog[/b]

[h1]Neutral[/h1]
+/- Great direction towards parkour and stealth mechanics, but said mechanics are somewhat unpolished and occasionally buggy
+/- Lack of upgradeable storage space; makes things more challenging, but also requires more trips to shops
+/- Dialogue gets a little tiresome at times. Take a drink every time Yagami mentions "Sawa"

[h1]Cons[/h1]
- Drone racing and VR Dice & Cube are downgrades from the previous game
- Ingredients for extracts are a tad tedious to farm

[h1]Review[/h1]
Lost Judgment is phenomenal and an upgrade from its predecessor in virtually every aspect. 

The combat system is exciting and buttery smooth. Dragon Engine combat was kinda rough in Y6 and YK2, with Judgment being a little boring. But combat in Lost Judgment hits all the sweet spots. You get 4 types of combat styles, and switching between them is seamless. While Crane Style was pretty bad in Judgment, this game makes it fantastic for dealing with crowds.

Story-wise, this game impressed me with how it managed to develop a quality story around school bullying. Some parts of the story are also considerably darker than the RGG norm, which was definitely an interesting change. Most say that Judgment's story is superior, but I actually prefer this one for tackling real world issues and the subject of morality.

But IMO, the best aspect of this game by far are the school stories. Yagami should give up being a detective and become a school guidance counselor instead. There are 10 different school stories (quest chains) in this, and a number of them have fantastic character development. I never thought I'd be so committed to overseeing the championship victory of a school's robotics club.
School stories also introduces a real star in Amasawa Kyoko, and I would be [b]really[/b] disappointed if she didn't return in a potential third game.

Performance-wise, the game ran perfectly and not once crashed in my entire playthrough.

[h1]TL;DR[/h1]
I loved every moment of this game. Easily one of the best games in the RGG franchise, and I doubt anyone would leave feeling disappointed.

Old Review: while i did do a full review for Judgment, this game is so god damn amazing that you should just buy the game right away.

Actual Review:
So continuing from the first game Judgment (Judge Eyes), they decided to absolutely hit the ball out of the park with Lost Judgment, with a location change from Kamurocho to Ijincho from Yakuza: Like A Dragon (Yakuza 7) as well!

Getting into gameplay, the Crane and Tiger Styles return from the first game, with some new improvements, Crane has gotten buffed to the point that it's actually now really good, and it actually has upgrades instead of being left out because of the other upgrades going to Tiger in the first game. Tiger also gets improved with some new skills and charged attacks being apart of the base style instead of a separate skill like the first game, however flux fissure isn't as broken as it was in the first game but still pretty good. The Snake Style is one of the new styles being added to the mix, which is basically Tanimura's style from Yakuza 4 but improved upon and more focused on parrying and the opening you can make with that, you can also disarm opponents that have weapons (unless they're a boss enemy) but sometimes I wished that if you failed it, you just grab them instead. The Boxer Style that was originally DLC in the Console Release is now an actual style that comes with the game, and it's really good for stunning your opponents and just laying waste on to them. but you can turn it off in the settings if you like having 3 styles instead. Each style has their own Secrets and Counters which is pretty nice, Crane has a counter that launches enemies into the air opening a juggle combo, and the secret allows you to dodge an attack and gain temporary boost in combo speed, Tiger has Crushing Tiger Fist which is definitely not Tiger Drop renamed and reanimated, and the secret allows you to do extra damage after a charged hit, Snake has the worst counter as you can only use it when your EX is empty, the secret makes you immune to being knockdowned after a parry, Boxer has THREE counters for jabs, hooks, and straights, which they all do their own ailments as well, the secret makes it so your EX meter charges more faster after a counter, oh and btw each secret can be used outside their styles, so you can use crane to dodge an attack then switch to tiger and do a charge attack and vice versa.

The story of Lost Judgment is fantastic, while most people will definitely enjoy Judgment's story more than this game's, this story shouldn't be slept on since its one of RGG's best stories out there at the moment, the school is interesting part of the story (you also get to beat up high school children) and yeah there is some pacing issues in the middle, and a certain someone getting mentioned by Yagami every 15 seconds in the finale, but the villains of the story are incredible, and the final boss goes REALLY HARD in terms of both characters, atmosphere, moral, and it's music.

The Side Content of Lost Judgment is definitely some of the best Side Content we have gotten as well, while there isn't as much Side Cases in Kamurocho since the game takes place mostly in Ijincho, the School Stories are a great addition to the bunch. Each School Story has it's own minigame that you can play to progress through them, and they all have their own respective characters as well, it's a really fun time, my favorite being the Boxing Story, and my least favorite being Robotics Story (i hate it alot). There are 42 Side Cases in Base Lost Judgment, but since the PC release includes all of the DLC (except Kaito Files) it goes up to 54, but you only need to do the base Side Cases and all School Stories to fight this game's secret boss, as the other 12 cases from the DLC are connected to Girlfriends.

So talking about detective stuff, they pretty much took out half of the gimmicks from Judgment, no more rotating lockpicking, there's only one Tailing Segment in the story, Active Search Mode is a lot more better, Chasing is more like Yakuza 4 and 5, with the draining health bar and comically large Staminan X on the streets. Overall most of the detective stuff has been improved in this game, and they also dialed down them in the main story, even improving Tailing Segments to have a nice new Act Natural button that you can hold, but they also made it so you can't make that many mistakes anymore, and then they pretty much threw every single one they made into the Side Content.

Now talking about the PC Port as I played this game on PS4 and then PS5, basically you get all of the DLC except kaito files, so you're getting the best experience of the game with no extra cost, and just like Judgment you also have pretty good optimization.

Overall, for those who have never played a yakuza game and returning fans of the series, I would 100% recommend this, however I recommend also to play Judgment first so you have a better understanding of the characters. also soundtrack is a banger

[h1]An overall improvement over the first Judgement, and a solid RGG game overall[/h1]

If you don't now what an "RGG game" is, it's short for Ryu Ga Gotoku, the name of the main franchise (also known as Yakuza) as well as the studio that makes it, RGG Studios.

These games are beat em up action RPGs with (relatively) small, but extremely dense open world environments, and most famous for managing to use mostly the same maps over multiple games with lots of asset re-use, but still manage to feel fresh and fun each time, though an excellent gameplay loop, tons of minigames and ridiculous sidequests, and corny but still fun action stories.

[b]I love these games as essentially the videogame equivalent of comfort food.[/b] Some are better or worse than others, but you broadly know what you are getting and can expect a consistent baseline of quality in each one.

[b]If you are new to these games, I do NOT think Lost Judgement should be your first.[/b] If you want to start with the Judgement spinoff franchise please start with the first Judgement, if you want a broader intro to RGG games I recommend Yakuza 0 instead as the ideal game for potential new fans. Both are on Steam!

I played with all DLC enabled, but I'm not reviewing The Kaito Files here, I haven't played it yet.

With that said, the rest of this review will be written for people already familiar with RGG games but wondering how Lost Judgement shapes up. These are my thoughts.

[h1]THE GOOD STUFF[/h1]

[list]
[*][b]The combat in this game is a JOY.[/b] Base Judgement was a bit iffy in terms of combat, Lost Judgement has improved on it in every single way. Crane and Tiger style have had new features added to make both more appealing and interesting, and the new Snake style is one of THE most fun combat styles RGG have ever done. It adds a timed, omnidirectional parry to your blocking, it allows you to end combos with throws, adds several new throw variations, lets you inflict status effects... It's SUCH a fun way to fight. The EX Surrender moves are also some of the funniest Heat Actions in the entire series. For the first time, every fighting style feels like its own FULLY fleshed out, uniquely fun way to fight enemies. DLC owners also have the Boxer style to look forward to, which is like a better iteration on the old Rush style. It has a ton of defensive and offensive power behind it, but deliberately lacks versatility.

[*][b]I really liked the story, and I feel some aspects of it are better than anything RGG have done in the past.[/b] I love the new, more socially relevant direction RGG have been taking their stories in, and in particular the final antagonist of this game has become one of the most interesting characters they've ever made IMO. I believe that a lot of people will take this story in vastly different ways depending on their own life experience, but I don't think that's necessarily a bad thing. [b]There are some people who get hung up on the ending, but IMO most of what they are saying is rooted in misunderstanding the plot. IF you have gotten the ending spoiled by people who don't like it, here's a quick context explanation that won't completely, absolutely, and utterly ruin the ride for you, but still AVOID if you don't already know the ending:[/b] [spoiler]In the end, Yagami lets the killer escape. He does NOT do this because he agrees with the killer, even though some of his ex-criminal friends actually do, but because he doesn't have serious evidence that would stick, the killer is going to be in absolutely no position to kill again in the future, and he knows there is corruption in the justice system that will have the killer executed in prison to hide the truth if he was ever arrested. Lost Judgement is a story about trying to do the right thing in a situation where there are only up, down and left things to choose from- You might end up disagreeing with Yagami's choice at the end of the game, but it doesn't make it a bad story[/spoiler]

[*][b]This is definitely a Yokohama game primarily, not a Kamurocho game.[/b] Kamurocho has the [i]usual[/i] activities but absolutely nothing beyond that. In fact, it's got less to do in it than base Judgement, because stuff like Dice & Cube or the Drone Racing League has moved out to Yokohama instead. Having two maps you travel between is definitely pretty cool!

[*][b]The various "detective activities" such as tailing, lockpicking, and observing have been refined, and minimised.[/b] Tailing, for example, got REALLY old fast in Judgement. In Lost Judgement, tailing feels more freeform, but is also MUCH less common and takes much less time, so you won't be bored out of your mind. Lockpicking has had thumb turn bypasses removed so you can be speedier on regular lockpicking. There are less Observation points in the story and there's now a hint function if you get stuck, but you can also go into Observation mode in the open world too, and there are actually some mini-puzzles to solve out there using it.

[*][b]There are new "modes" for detective work- Parkour, and stealth.[/b] These are both only for scripted story sequences- Kamurocho has not gone full Assassin's Creed. In my opinion, these aren't great. Parkour is harmless, but sadly doesn't add much to the game- I'd love it if it was usable in the open world for shortcuts or back alleys, but that isn't actually the case. Stealth is similar, it's [i]functional[/i] but adds nothing to the game as there really aren't multiple ways to approach situations with the highly limited level design.

[*][b]Even by RGG standards, this OST is a goddamn banger.[/b] Some of the best boss/combat themes in the series are in this game. A real highlight of the game.

[*][b]MORTAL WOUNDS ARE GONE![/b] The biggest issue with the original Judgement has been removed. Instead, you have Mortal Attacks, which are charged, highly telegraphed attacks enemies do that you can beat using a timed quickstep, then follow up with a Mortal Reversal that changes based on your equipped Style. It's a simple way to give enemies super attacks and let players respond in an interesting way.

[*][b]Minigames have been enhanced and expanded across the board.[/b] From simple things like Drone Racing being shorter 2 lap races instead of 3, to the massive School Stories sidequest chain that spans several different minigames, most completely new, and has its own campaign content related to it. RGG have pulled out all the stops to make up for Judgement not having karaoke, and have [i]mostly[/i] managed it.
[/list]

[h1]THE CONS[/h1]

[list]
[*][b]Much of the story won't work as well if you have not played the original Judgement.[/b] As per usual with RGG stories, info from previous games is not critically important to understand this one, and they avoid giving any serious spoilers for the first game, so this can be experienced standalone. However, there are a lot of characters that'll make you think "who?" you haven't played the first Judgement.

[*][b]The QTEs, while rare, have become a bit iffy now in terms of your inputs.[/b] You need to execute 3-4 different button inputs in a sequence, and boy, that's a BIT too much to ask players to do in a handful of seconds! They should go back to the regular old single inputs.

[*][b]Overall, I don't think Yagami is as good a protagonist as his predecessors.[/b] Unlike LiD's Ichiban, who is a very smartly composed character to become extremely likeable and endearing, Yagami feels like a remix of Kiryu without the eccentricities that made Kiryu likeable. He's not horrible but he feels unfortunately too much like a blank slate, sadly.
[/list]

[h1]TL:DR[/h1]

A very solid RGG game that has left me very excited for RGG 8 and the direction these games are taking. It's fantastic, muddy, cheesy drama and has put many grins on my face. Any RGG game fan should absolutely play this.

Besides the story, my experience with the substories is generally good and I found them engaging.

Now that the NVIDIA driver update error has been addressed in a recent announcement post, I can change this review to reflect the game that I can actually now play again. The dev recommendation worked.

Lost Judgment does suffer from a case of "more of the same" when it comes to comparisons to the series' last entry, but not in any sort of BAD way. It's the same dark detective mystery with brawler-action battles across the Yakuza/Like A Dragon staple cities of Kamurocho and Ijincho. The graphics and the gameplay have been tightened up making the game play and look better than the last - and never let it be said that there's any lack of content.

The main plot is compelling and sprawls the entire game, and the side-stories are numerous. I've played almost 60 hours myself so far and haven't actually *finished* the game.  The content here IS part of where Lost Judgement suffers somewhat. A large part of this game's story is a separate case surrounding cases of high school bullying around Ijincho, and nearly every single facet of that (8 in all) are tied up in a minigame or activity that is required to progress. This ends up taking what I felt to be *a lot* of time, and by the end of each one I was generally sick of whatever minigame I had been required to play to get through it. I dunno, maybe I'm just grumpy and old, but it felt like one great big distraction from the main plot. The payoff is... decent, but the journey is tedious.

I feel like if one ignores a lot of the side stories and secondary content, the game's runtime would be significantly shorter. Even if that was all there were to experience, though, the game would still be good enough to recommend, especially to fans of the Yakuza series.

Yagami Gaming

tl;dr: performance is not that bad but is not up to par with other installments, combat and general gameplay is vastly improved over its predecessor and resurrects some good ideas from other RGG games, plot is marginally more restrained than the typical RGG game and is better for it. there is a major spoiler for yakuza: like a dragon in the game's plot.

TECHNICAL:

I'm pretty sure the performance improved as I was playing the game by virtue of me buying the game on release and important patches being released within a few months while I was actively playing it. That being said the performance was fine but not good. You can obviously tell when a new area is being loaded because the game freezes for a couple seconds, and this was a thing until the very end of the game. Also, whenever you boot the game up, the first fight I would get into would have titanic frame drops. There were also a couple of crashes in the early and mid game but as said before this was probably because of things that were patched.

COMBAT:

The combat is way better than in Judgment. For one, Crane style has a reason to exist now due to various buffs and unique moves that Tiger doesn't have. Tiger was punched up a bit with some new moves, and a new style was added, Snake, which is throw and counter based, akin to how Tanimura would fight in Yakuza 4, except improved. Snake also has the bonus of having a set of "instant-kill" EX actions to compensate for its slower speed and middling damage output (compared to the other styles). This particular port comes with most (not all) DLC pre-packaged so you also get the Boxer style which I used maybe twice in the whole game.

Yagami can equip gear in this game, which is great. He still can't equip weapons or pick up guns, though, which is unfortunate. 

SIDE CONTENT/EXPLORING:

You get to go to Ijincho in this game. It's not significantly different than it was when it was first introduced. Same with Kamurocho. The new area is Seiryo High School, which is obviously not a city but a campus you can walk around.

The bulk of the side content is in the "School Stories" which are in Seiryo High. Unlike substories/side cases these have overarching plot lines and unique minigames akin to the side stories in Yakuza 5. They vary in depth and quality: the Robotics Club has a massive slate of parts you need to build and a bunch of robot battles, and the ESports Club is just you playing one of the arcade games against a weak AI.

Minigames mostly are the same. Kamuro of the Dead is now Hama of the Dead and is set in Ijincho, the Drone Race is easier, and Dice and Cube is now a race against an AI rival instead of you wandering around grabbing money until you run out of dice. 

The "Celios" in-universe franchise also returns after having been unseen since Yakuza 5. Aircelios is 90% not being able to see what is going on because enemies are indistinguishable for debris. Boxcelios and its spin-offs always were the arcade's weak points. 

OTHER GAMEPLAY:

There's some story stuff revolving around tailing, parkour, and stealth. Tailing has some mechanical changes but it is still very boring to follow someone around for a long time with nothing else happening. Parkour and stealth are new. Parkour is not particularly in depth and the sections don't last very long. I wouldn't call it bad but I wouldn't call it fun either. The stealth sections are very restrictive; you have to go to particular spots to hide and throw things in particular spots or else you can't progress. It lacks any degree of choice and feels more like pushing a cart down an aisle than playing a game.

PLOT:

Remarkably, this game does not have a lot of insane out-of-the-blue twists. It's quite grounded even when the conspiracy plot engines start revving up. The plot has school bullying as one of its themes, which is certainly closer to home for many than the majority of RGG games. It seems that Yakuza: Like a Dragon has started a sort of trend within the franchise of more directly discussing and centering around specific societal problems. 

Speaking of Yakuza: Like a Dragon, there is a major plot spoiler for that game within the first twenty minutes or so of this one, and mentioned several times after that twenty minute mark. It's an offhand remark but it reveals an integral twist. It's not avoidable, so if you want to dodge that spoiler you may have to hold off this game for a while. Some cameos and organizations also return from Yakuza: LAD but that's not a spoiler.

If you are planning to buy this then let me tell you [b] You shouldn't hesitate [/b]. As a sequel this is a [b] MASSIVE [/b] improvement in every aspect to Judgment. Combat feels more fluid, new minigames are great and soundtrack is full of bangers.

SPOILER ALERT

The game's major antagonist is a former school teacher who got fired after an incident of bullying in his class that led victim to attempted suicide. The teacher preserved video evidence of bullying (in which a bunch of pupils participated) and used it 8 years later to blackmail now adult pupils into massively abducting and murdering bullies over Japan (main case of the game is his 7th killing). Through the course of the game, many major characters voiced sympathy for him, and in the end of the game, the main character just lets the (unremorseful!) serial murderer go due to "lack of evidence".

This is totally beyond my comprehension. There was quite a lot of evidence to begin with, and even if there was not... I just can't accept how the serial murderer and his accomplices (e.g. parents of bullied kids who agreed to murdering bullies) are portrayed as... Kind of not so bad guys? And to think that many fans seem to agree with this notion of the serial killer being in the right. It just makes me quite depressed and sad :(

After loving Judgment so much, I went into Lost Judgment with very high expectations. Yet, despite being, on a technical level, a more or less straight improvement on everything the previous game had, I couldn‚Äôt help but feel disinterested in most of its contents. Luckily, it‚Äôs still a very solid entry in the Like a Dragon series, at least mechanically. And it still has some good storytelling.

Just like its direct predecessor, Lost Judgement is an attempt to slightly tweak the Like a Dragon formula of beat ‚Äôem up action adventure in an open world into something that feels more like an investigation game. It‚Äôs still clearly divided into the adventure and action elements, fights can still be challenging and combat with randomly spawning groups of enemies on the streets continues to play a big part. But the adventure parts have more detective-y things than the typical Like a Dragon game. And Lost Judgment improves on basically every mechanic from the previous game, while additionally introducing some new ones. For better and for worse.

For example, detective Yagami still occasionally uses disguises and tails people, but tailing has been made far more freeform in the way it plays. I know some people disliked how the mechanic was overused in the original title, so the developers made it far more fun. Same goes for the chase sequences, how much more improved the sections of looking around in first person view are‚Ä¶ You also get plenty new gadgets to play with in addition to the drone and even a dog that can be used to track smells. Oh and now we get stealth sequences too, which sound like something that fits the game perfectly‚Ä¶ but mechanically they are some of the worst stealth segments I‚Äôve played in the past 15 years, like they‚Äôre from the early 00s PS2 era of bad stealth titles. 

And unfortunately, the mechanical improvements that I‚Äôve listed often feel pointless. There are barely any tailing tasks in the entire game, for example, despite the great improvements, but you still have skills you can unlock for this almost unused feature. The drone is now almost never used by Yagami himself, despite the fact that instead of introducing new gadgets (and a dog) it would‚Äôve made far more sense to put all of those features into the drone and make it more interesting and integral to your arsenal. The Chatter that you used to talk to people all the time in the previous game is now used for 4 contacts in total, only one of them writes you often and you never have any choices or abilities to contact anyone yourself‚Ä¶ You can now do the word filtering process yourself, though, which was just a cutscene thing in the previous game. And it‚Äôs an amazing concept, yet, more often than not it‚Äôs so automated it feels like it‚Äôs underutilized. Oh and disguises are still almost never needed and when they are, it doesn‚Äôt matter what you use.

In general, Lost Judgment follows the same trend as a lot of Like a Dragon sequels in that it tries to do more of everything. You have more fighting styles, more locations, more mini-games, more skills, more stuff to do‚Ä¶ And as it usually is with this approach, a lot of what made the previous game so great gets muddied and lost in the process. For example ‚Äì the fantastic concept of Friends and getting to help the community from the first game, something that had a meaningful and awesome payoff in the end, is now entirely gone. Which ends up making the cities you explore almost irrelevant as locations. Apart from the school, all locations around Isezaki Ijincho (returning from Yakuza: Like a Dragon) and even Kamurocho have no meaningful interactions, form no emotional connections for the player. They‚Äôre just places to go to for stuff to happen. It doesn‚Äôt help that Isezaki Ijincho is a pretty plain location in itself, but if you didn‚Äôt play Yakuza: Like a Dragon previously, you‚Äôll probably never remember anything about it apart from 3-4 landmark locations and even those barely. 

The school interactions are seemingly introduced to replace the whole emotional core of the side content, but they feel so disjointed and so completely unrelated to Yagami as a character, that it‚Äôs hard to understand what the developers were going for here. To the point, where most of Lost Judgement, as far as the storytelling, the mood, the characters and especially side content goes, feels like a collection of 5 separate game ideas that were combined into one game with Yagami filling in the role of many unrelated characters. And as a result not feeling like he belongs to most of the game. Even for the main story until the last third of the game apart from several key narrative beats, it‚Äôs like you‚Äôre playing as a Main Character of a Video Game here to do what plot requires, not Yagami and his friends.

It does get better as far as the mood goes in the main story, but it still feels a bit too little, too late and somewhat bland at that. The topics that are brought up are impactful and there are good character moments and scenes. But again ‚Äì it feels like this would‚Äôve been better served as several unrelated games in Like a Dragon universe with separate focus and protagonists, rather than this one single title that ends up feeling shallow as a result. Because it cannot quite deliver on everything it opens up, while almost entirely losing all of the charm that the first game had.

The story DLC Kaito Files feels, in many ways, like a far better take on what original Judgment established and follows a simpler, but still surprising short story, where players get to play as Kaito. It does feel as a DLC, as it‚Äôs far simpler in many ways to the main game, but it has enough content of its own to feel really fun, it tweaks mechanics in ways that feel great. And in some aspects it even ‚Äúfixes‚Äù the problems that the main game created. 

Lost Judgment, despite being in many ways an improvement on the original game, is just so‚Ä¶ disappointing. And, as I mentioned, it ends up feeling shallow and lacking a lot of the charm that the original game had. It has great moments, it is somewhat easier to play and even friendlier to newcomers than the original. And Kaito Files is a really cool short story. But I cannot recommend it to anyone who is not absolutely in love with the series and/or the first game. And even there, I feel like you might be disappointed as I was, depending on what you expect from a Judgment game. Of course, getting the title just for a DLC is also a silly idea, it‚Äôs not really worth it, unless you want to play the main game too. So, I can only hope the series do continue, but next time the game focuses on what made the first Judgement charming, wholesome, investigative and memorable in the first place, instead of trying to turn it into a jack of all trades. Firstly, if you haven't played the original Judgement, you should go check out the reviews for that and decide if it's for you. Even if you've played every other game from Ryu Ga Gotoku Studio, I can't think of a single reason to recommend playing Lost Judgement first. These games are extremely story heavy and playing this first will give you a severely diminished experience, as context, relationships and callbacks will be totally lost on you.

That makes this review easy. Assuming you've played the original, this is more of that but even more refined. In gameplay terms at least I would say LJ along with Yakuza 0 is the pinnacle of the original style, real-time combat RGG games. The game is just extremely polished from a mechanical standpoint including its combat and vast array of minigames that range from throwaway to quite engaging (golf, gambling, arcades, VR, dating...you know the drill). You can even get about town on a skateboard, Deadly Premonition style, which makes town traversal a lot more fun. On top of that there's the usual boatload of side-quests, collectables and completionist objectives to dabble in (special mention to the School Stories side-quests which are great). The graphics are also very good, with nice models for the main characters and smooth animations. The towns themselves are fantastically detailed pieces of virtual tourism that get better with each instalment, I assume because the studio can focus on improving existing assets instead of creating new ones.

Ok, on to the game's bread and butter, the story. No spoilers here, the story takes places in your old stomping grounds of Kamurocho and, if you've played Like a Dragon, Isezaki Ijincho with a high school being one of the primary locations. Suffice to say LJ delivers an excellent detective mystery, with great writing and performances on par with the original in my opinion. Expect the usual lavish rendered cutscenes for the main story missions. One thing to be wary of; the story features some disturbing scenes and possibly upsetting subject matter (bullying, suicide).

The game took me about 55 hours to finish with a decent amount of optional content done but I would assume at least another potential 25 hours for full completion.

Overall, this is a fantastic entry in the RGG universe. Here's hoping SEGA can sort out their issues with the lead actor so we can get another sequel down the road!

[h1] SPOILER FREE REVIEW [/h1]

I like to think this game is like the Yakuza 5 of the Judgment games. It might not have 5 characters or 5 cities, but the sheer amount of fantastic content in this game packed on top of one of the best stories in across all the Ryu Ga Gotoku games makes me wholeheartedly say that this is the RGG's best game they've put out to date. I sung the praises of Judgment in my review of that, but Lost Judgment blows that out of the water somehow.

For starters, without any spoilers, the story. It's fantastic. If you liked Judgment you'll get more of the same in this. You have your usual detective work as Yagami Detective Agency working in tandem with Genda Law Office once more with another intricate plot that slowly gives you more pieces to the puzzle, finally letting you put it together in the end. At times it can feel like it's being too complex for the sake of dramatic effect, but it usually quickly pulled away from those moments by giving you a big piece of the puzzle after all that exposition.

The gameplay/combat is the best in the series bar none. The 3 (or 4 depending on your decisions) fighting styles complement each other so well. Although for reasons I won't say, snake was the clear-cut winner for me for a multitude of reasons. Having a skateboard to traverse around Ijincho and Kamurocho was a great addition, albeit kinda finicky with how you'd hop off it if you passed over a pedestrian area for more than a second. I do hope they'll keep it and open up more traversal options in future entries, like being able to do the parkour climbing freely instead of only in instances when it was required by the story/side missions.

As for the actual side content itself, that is where this game shines in ways the other games have failed to, or at least haven't done to this standard. As expected from the previous entry, Drone Races are still here and are more or less unchanged, but have a new set of maps for Ijincho. I was disappointed that I couldn't access the Kamurocho maps in this game, but that's a minor gripe at best. As for the rest of the content present in this game, you have a dance club (this game's karaoke like rhythm mode), A skateboard freestyle competition and races, motorcycle races, a very well fleshed out boxing mode (I think it's the best side content in any of the games so far), robot territory claiming battles, and of course all the returning city activities like darts, batting cages, shogi, blackjack and poker, the arcades, golf, and probably a few other one's I'm forgetting to mention.

In conclusion, play this game if you've ever mildly enjoyed a RGG game. And even if you haven't do yourself a favor and give this game an opportunity.  I truly think this is a 10/10 game, and I'll never get over the fact that this game didn't win game of the year for 2021

Another solid entry from RGG studios.  More of what you like, although the detective aspect seems to be less prevalent this time around.  Sure, you still tail people (which still sucks), go over evidence and such, but it's not nearly as often as it was in Judgement.  

Combat I'd have to say feels like it has improved.  It still has that classic Yakuza/Judgement feel, but this outing, Yagami feels like he packs more of a punch.  The addition of the Snake style really steals the show in my opinion and really feels like all you need honestly.  Crane and Tiger are still viable, but Snake seems to outclass them in every way.  The boxing style is ok, but It didn't bring a lot to the table other than really quick dodges and punches.  Effective? Sure.  Fun? Not really.  It gets old quickly, and you'll probably find yourself going back to Snake. 

The game is jam packed full of extra stuff to do as per usual.  Your favorite mini games are still there, with some new additions as well.  The school stories require you to partake in the mini games which aren't all that bad, but they get repetitive very quickly.  The robotics mini game  is really cool in concept and works OK, but if fleshed out a little bit more, it would have been way more enjoyable.  It quickly starts to feel like the school stories mini games feel like a chore to progress though which is a negative in my book.  However, you do end up learning some helpful skills from them.

The story is not one of the strongest outings from RGG.  Is it good? Not really.   It's not really bad either, though.  I'd say its about on par with Yakuza 3 or 4 as far as plot.  It isn't bad, but it doesn't stand out as special either.  

Familiar faces return which is always a welcome sight in these games.  While I don't mind Yagami, I don't find him to be nearly as interesting as a main character compared to the other characters we've been introduced to in the Yakuza universe.  He can hold his own in a fight, and has character development, but personally, I don't find him as likeable as Kaito.  

Speaking of Kaito, the DLC is pretty fun.  Again, not an amazing story, but it's decent enough.  There's 4 chapters to get though, and maybe adds an additional 6-8 hours of play time if you try to do all the extra stuff.  Kaito will bring you back to playing previous Yakuza titles, as he's essentially Kiryu with his brawler and beast styles.  Combat feels super fun as Kaito because you're once again a walking tank.  

Overall, I recommend.  If you're a fan of these games, you know what you're in for and you'll get your money's worth.  If you are on the fence, then wait for the sale.  I'm confident most people will enjoy the game, just don't expect it to be Yakuza 0 good.

TL;DR: Goes unbelievably hard, buy it and play it now

Having not beaten Lost Judgment on console so I could wait for it on PC, I'm very happy with my choice, as Lost Judgment improves on the gameplay presented in Judgment in almost every single way. 

Combat might be at its peak across the whole Yakuza/Like a Dragon/Judgment series, with four styles to choose from, fleshed out upgrades, and amazing animation it feels incredible. I've never looked out for fights as much in other games in the series like I do in Lost Judgment. You also spend a good amount of time early on beating up school kids (amazing). 

It's absolutely PACKED full with content, with most returning activities given extra polish and depth and a ton of new activities that are all fun and engaging. Side stories, clubs, school stories, mini games, you can even buy old Sega master system carts and play a variety of games in your office. 

Tons of quality of life features like the skateboard especially are very welcome. Alongside that, a lot of the stuff that received criticism from the first game for over staying their welcome like the Tailing missions are surprisingly improved and also a lot less frequent. 

The detective features in this game are much more fleshed out in comparison to Judgment. You can start investigation at any time even in the open world and in missions, and you have new tools including a sound amp, a noise detector, and a dog to carry out your detective work. 

Ijincho from Yakuza: Like a Dragon returns as the main city this time, however you have the ability to go back to Kamurocho at any time. Both of them are looking better than ever with updated lighting, effects, and density, making this the best looking game in the series bar none. 

Audio is great, with both quality English and Japanese voices. The soundtrack in this game is INSANE though, with some of the best music from the entire series. I've played every mainline game in the series to completion except for this one and this game's OST sets a high bar.

PC Port is great, but has some stability issues. Runs great and looks great but for some reason when I play the VR mini game, I've crashed 3 times alone just in that mode, and never crashed outside of that. There's also a weird black flickering only during night time that is rare but noticeable. Both can be easily patched soon I'm sure but just making it known.

The story is the only thing comparable in quality to the first Judgment game, which is a fairly solid bar to reach for. The first Judgment had a lot more moments that stand out as great set pieces with events unfolding through the entire game and constantly evolving until the very last second of the story even if it did have a lot of moments where it was taking a while to get going or it felt like they tried to pad out the story length. 

Lost Judgment's story on the other hand feels more emotionally intense. It grabs you from the get go and feels like the developers are making this game to say a lot of things that they truly feel strongly about, which is very refreshing to experience, even if the latter third of the game feels like it might run out of steam after all the secrets and plot points are revealed. I'd say it's very subjective as to which story is better, even if they are both great stories. But I prefer the faster pace, the character arcs, the themes, and the villains in Lost Judgment over the original myself. I wouldn't hold it against anyone for preferring the first though. 

I'm a humongous fan of the Yakuza/Like a Dragon/Judgment series, they're all great fun without an outright terrible entry to be found. However playing Lost Judgment makes the original Judgment look like a proof of concept demo in comparison, and even makes some of the other Yakuza games look like ancient relics. Cannot recommend this game enough.

On replaying, Lost Judgment's story smashed a lot of my pre-conceptions from its release a year ago. Unfortunately the rest of it is as I remember. The side content and especially the music is a step down from the original,

School Stories are very hit and miss and some take a while to open up, and they overshadow side cases/substories as the main side arcs on offer. But on the other hand again, it's the best iteration of combat in the entire series so far. Unlike in Yakuza 0 and Kiwami, the different styles actually have some overlap which means they aren't completely disjointed. Tiger and Snake to respectively take on singular or clusters of enemies is a much better and more practical idea than two balanced, a light but weak and a strong but heavy style. LJ also actively rewards you for switching up styles during encounters, and with the increased style switch speed and new Snake style for counter-offensive plays it makes for good fast-paced fun. Unfortunately the style themes are ungodly bland even without the comparison to JE's, but the rest of the soundtrack is about on par.

The game takes place primarily in Ijincho and under the shadow of (Yakuza 7) [spoiler]the disbandment of the yakuza[/spoiler], which is unfortunate given the game was announced with the promise that Yakuza and Judgment would be parallel. Instead, LJ has to pick apart the pieces Yakuza left behind while Yokoyama grasps at the bottom of the barrel for any excuse to quell his separation anxiety for Kazuma Kiryu and actually have the guts to say to the world "there was no way around him appearing in Yakuza 8. Honest." RGGS shot themselves in the feet with the Ijincho map; it's a confused map that's comprised of samples of districts and offers nothing of value. It's so big and lifeless and I guess they felt the need to justify the time and effort that went into making it by reusing it and... not actually improving it. In LJ you get a skateboard for quicker traversal, which would be great if either map were actually designed around this. Instead it's only really viable in a few long stretches of road in Ijincho, [i]if[/i] Yagami doesn't decide to just get off the board whenever he feels like.

Speaking of maps, Kamurocho returns but like in Yakuza 7, it's really only a formality. So little actually takes place in Kamurocho in this game that it may as well have been gutted, with taxi fares from Ijincho just directly taking you to Genda Law Office, given that it's the one place in Kamurocho you visit the most. Without Don Quijote, and given that many of the elements unique to Judgment like Paradise VR and Iyama's hermit den suspiciously all migrate to Ijincho, Yagami Detective Agency may as well up and move there already. RGGS are trying to move forward while desperately clinging onto the past and the end result is a sad Kamurocho with relatively nothing to do, in back to back games.

The story is pretty interesting. It starts off very disjointed though, back and forth between sexual harassment and groping, and... high school bullying. Once it starts to tie itself together it does so nicely, and I lament all the pre-release reviews complaining about the perfectly fine handling of its sensitive content just [i]because[/i] they're sensitive topics. I recall the story being far messier, but in actuality it wasn't as bad as I remembered. It's still messy in places, but I still enjoyed it more than any main series Yakuza stories.

Overall, it does things better, and it does things worse compared to its predecessor. It's relatively a solid entry though (when are RGGS games not messy and rushed?) and one I also prefer to anything in the main series. It says a lot that Furuta can still write a good story even while running damage control for Yokoyama's main series stunts. If he had written LJ, the reason behind that video would be [spoiler]Mirror Face. And nobody wants that. Again.[/spoiler] As someone speaking out of love for Yakuza (believe it or not) but also with an ability to call out the low points of the series without any rose tints, it honestly baffles, and worries, me about RGGS' future output with him in charge. I can only pray that future Judgment titles remain in Furuta's hands and continue to have as little to do with Yokoyama as possible.
