If you liked Like a Dragon you'll like this game. Probably.

There are a ton of similarities between the two games and that makes sense given that it's the same genre, studio, locations, etc. However, there are quite a few differences, and they're not always positive. So let's start with those.

Let me start by saying that in RGG games especially, connecting to the protagonist is important. In Like a Dragon you had Ichiban; a loveable goofball with a loud suit and a botched haircut that he eventually embraces (you can't change it in the game, ever). In other Yakuzas you had Kiryu; a stoic dreamer honor bound and allergic to smiling.

Yagami is somewhere in the middle. The boring, weird, stupid middle. He's a middle-aged man wearing teen idol fashion (skinny jeans, wallet chain) with a haircut that looks like a feathered bird's nest. His personality is bland and predictable; a generic good guy with few defining characteristics or interesting idiosyncrasies. I've never given less of a shit, basically. I don't care if he lives or dies, as long as I get my SP points so I can punch dudes harder. That's not a very immersive experience. I feel like I'm being forced to go on a really cool road trip with an excessively boring person going through a midlife crisis.

Now let's talk about one of the game's main features; the detection. Detecting? Detectiving? Anyways.

When you're "investigating" a scene you're just zoomed in a bit, and you move the cursor around until a button prompt and audio cue from Yagami ("oh!" "interesting!" etc) occurs. You hit the button and you receive more information on that object. Eventually you get a notification that you've found all the things and the investigation is complete.

When speaking to someone, you can question them, and/or choose multiple prompts. Usually the player's choice doesn't matter; you just go through all of the options until the dialogue is exhausted. When it does matter, it still doesn't because choosing the wrong option whether presenting evidence or asking a question just leads to "yeah maybe I shouldn't have chosen that" and then you try again. No consequences. No branching dialogue. The game just mocks your decision a little and you try one of the other few options.

You also have a handful of gadgets. One is a long range listening device that you use exactly the same way you investigate a scene but now you're looking for a sound source instead of evidence. Another is a device that finds signals coming from things like electronic bugs so you follow a beeping sound and why am I still talking about this. You also slowly and tediously tail suspects, wait for the right shot with your camera, and do other things I also don't care to get into.

If anything, the detecting just cripples the fun. The world is explosive, combat is violent, and the activities are an ADHD wonderland (or nightmare). But when you throw in a "walk behind this suspect for 10 minutes" moment that happens quite often, it impedes the pacing and makes you want to just get it over with. When you're pixel hunting for a stupid hot spot or shambling through a parking lot listening for beeps it feels like someone ripped the controller out of your hand and replaced it with a book.

And that's the end of the negatives. The cosmetics are subjective, and yeah I can be picky about my protagonist so take that with a grain of salt. As someone that plays protagonists as an extension of themselves (versus the puppet master mentality) I can't even play games like Ni No Kuni because I can't play as a 13 year old boy voiced by a 33 year old woman. I tried. It was weird.

The detective stuff might bring you some immersion or maybe it was simply mandatory to include those mechanics to really drive home the whole "I'm literally a detective" thing, but I don't know why they couldn't just leave it to the writers to make you feel like one without mini games who were (spoiler alert) the real killer all along.

Moving on.

The combat is solid. It's polished, predictable Yakuza combat with beautifully garish visuals, absurd animations, and flawless sound design. There's enough diversity between combat styles, moves, and stat boosts to keep you chasing upgrades and experimenting in fights. There's an incremental reward system for doing specific things in a fight which can yield more skill points too, so mixing things up and making things weird is rewarded.

The graphics are the Dragon Engine so obviously they're gorgeous. Environments are detailed, the lighting makes the city feel real and alive, and character models are detailed down to sewing patterns in their clothing and/or a subtle blemish on their cheek. But more importantly than any of that you can actually DISABLE AA so the game looks crisp, unlike the extremely popular forced TAA turning sharp, vibrant experiences into vaseline smeared fever dreams. I'm looking at you, Cyberpunk. And Playstation ports. Like, basically all of them.

The writing is... something. Something pretty good, most of the time. I mean, I know there's a cultural divide here, and things literally get lost in translation but the game's tone and writing constantly fluctuates between melodramatic soap and cringe-comedy for kids. 

Sometimes swearing is done very well in games and it conveys a real emotion or emphasizes a point with elegance and tact. And sometimes it's just a bunch of bad words thrown together at random in rapid succession by an uncensored Speak & Spell in the hands of a 12 year old with a learning disability. Lost Judgement does that a lot. Like, a lot. Like too much.

The main murder case is engaging and interesting with some unexpected twists and turns depending on whether or not you knew Bruce Willis was dead the whole time in that one movie with a young Keenan Feldspar.  It's not groundbreaking, but it's pretty damn good.

Minigames and side activities including side stories (quests) are varied and mostly entertaining. Some are intentionally shallow and goofy while others have real depth and strategy. There's a VR board game, fully functional Sega Master System, Battle Bot simulator, Boxing, Drone Racing, and all the other things that already exist in most Yakuza games.

Aside from that, the game is absolutely a recommend from someone that beat Like a Dragon three times but I'm told it doesn't count if you're just bored and drunk so take it from someone that beat Like a Dragon just one time this game will scratch the itch if you're reading reviews because you need that Yakuza itch scratched. The combat and RPG elements alone will keep you addicted, but maybe you'll stick around for the story. And maybe, just maybe, you'll find the detective mechanics kinda cool just kidding seriously they're terrible.

LOST JUDGMENT BEATS YAKUZA 0 GAMEPLAY.

THE END OF THE REVIEW. BUY THE GAME.

Haha... So anyway lets actually begin the review, though thats the biggest thing you need, other than dont worry, trailing missions were mostly removed, and actually made insanely better. They only appear like twice in the main story. However, stealth has now taken its place, but it only shows up like 3 or 4 times so, good job Lost Judgment.

So, the biggest first thing to address are these new gimmicks, along with other things that made Judgment, Judgment.

1. Investigation no longer is annoying and sucks. What did they change? Nothing. They just made it enjoyable by making it much more intuitve, unlike in Judgment, where you would be rubbing up against every wall and sliding your camera around annoyingly trying to find out what clue you are looking for, Lost Judgment one, makes this not happen every damn mission, and is much rarer, and ALSO always has direction in what you are looking for, this was just way better game design in its direction.

2. Uncharted wall climb/parkour Yeah, Yakuza got it now. Welcome to Lost Judgment, its about what you expect but it can be slow when its not a swing or a wall run. I REALLY wish they did more with this.

3. Lockpicking and the silly key ring thing was removed, and the trailing was made good, no longer having boxes to snap to you naturally in a very Assassins creed type way get behind any surface. VERY GOOD. Plus, you can now blend into the environement when under suspicion.

4. Stealth. The new trailing missions of Judgment. They suck, seriously they are really dumb. Throw a coin to break away attention then stealth take down. OR THROW A SMOKE BOMB AT THEM. Problem being its super linear and basically forces you to throw it. It basically almost plays itself just you interact with it. Its SUPER BORING. though like I said, it happens like 3 or 4 times. It isnt plagued with it like traling was in Judgment. In fact, ALL THIS STUFF IS RARER IN LOST JUDGEMENT. VERY NICE!

Lets cover stances, where Judgment in a way revived the concept after long wait since before DRAGON ENGINE, (0, K1)
Now, we have them back, and 3 of them this time in Lost Judgment, as well as a 4th you can obtain called Boxer.

Snake, and Boxer are two new stances. Snake is a defensive, quick, grapple style thats block parries enemies. Its smooth as butter and my favorite stance in the entire series. Boxer, similar to Rush from K1 and 0, but no grab and its all boxer rules. Its over powered because when upgraded allows you to basically make the enemy die for even daring to try to hurt you, its dodges and counters are absolutely insane. These two stances are the best in the series honestly, with how powerful they are, they are VERY VERY FUN.
THIS IS PEAK COMBAT FOR THE YAKUZA SERIES, EVEN CRANE AND TIGER FEEL BETTER HERE.

The side missons are amazing, and not just the files you get in Judgment. Since the story has links to a highschool, you get a lot of interaction with school clubs and school mysteries now that Yagami works part time there. These are super good and some of the deepest side quests EVER in the series. Some argue to feel like they could be main game. Another think I love is that Judgment had the audacity to do forced filler, which Lost Judgment got rid of. Beautiful once more Lost Judgment. You also are given tools like a listening tool, and a detection tool to locate situations in the world, this grows into all kinds of secrets and side content, on top of all of them the best "tool" or goodest boy.

[b] THE DOG. THIS IS THE BEST YAKUZA GAME, BECAUSE YOU CAN WALK THE DOG. [/b]
Beyond the point of [b] DOG [/b] you can take him for walks, he will detect trouble afoot, and bring you to some more new mysteries. Its actually incredible how you seemingly investigate some side content, not just "take a case" or "run into an event." I LOOOOVE THIS CONCEPT! KEEP DOING THIS RYU GA GOTOKU ITS SOOO GOOD!

There is also a skate board you are given to travel around, its basically the first vehicle in the series, its super fun even if a little jank, and I found it great for moments of getting somewhere that would be much necessary for a taxi, or just zooming around faster or EVEN doing tricks which were fun. there are even coins to collect that are all around as you ride around that can be grabbed for rewards.

The only other thing I can pick at is that the skill tree still isn't as good as past games. Seriously, can we also please stop hiding EX's in the skill tree Ryu Ga Gotoku? It makes the game ooze less coolness when everyone will want to go for meta or abilities that make the game more fun, give more power, strategy, or abilities. Keep all of the EX moves open from the start.

This game is an ABSOLUTELY STELLAR GAME IN THE SERIES, MY GOD.

The only down side? Somewhat the story....
Its REALLY good, don't get me wrong, but it feels like it under delivered compared to Judgment a little. Ill never forget Judgments finally and all its segments to get there.
 (Especially the shit ton of annoying investigation, and trailing missions...)
Overall, Lost Judgment OOZES with perfection in every field, I still loved the story, even if it was a bit of a mess in my opinion, it undershot Judgment. 

9.7/10 - Lost Judgment, is my third favorite in the series. I have found it to grow to be special to me, its the best combat the series has ever had, its what Yakuza 6 wanted to be, with the quality of Yakuza 0. It is the master class dream, its only downside being a story that could have been better. Beyond this, the game is nearly in most departments the peak of the series, absolutely do not miss Lost Judgment. If you didn't like Judgment, try this game still. Judgment, you stick around for the story among the annoyances in design with good combat. For Lost Judgment, you stick around for it all. RGG does it again, they took the already excellent entry title, Judgment, and improved upon it in this sequel in just about every way. For one, the annoying Mortal Wounds from the first game have been removed and you can now perform a counter-attack (unique to each style) against Deadly Attacks called a Mortal Reversal, allowing Yagami to stay on the offensive with a well-timed quickstep. Crane and Tiger have been rebalanced to better compliment each other while the new Snake stance is a wet dream for those who love landing parries and grapples. The OP DLC-exclusive Boxer style combines power and evasion that will decimate bosses with a flurry of punches for those who prefer to literally throw hands. Neither style is objectively better than the other and the game encourages you to cycle through them frequently for their various movesets hence keeping the combat very dynamic and fluid.

The story is, at the very least, on par with Judgment's. Once again Yagami is investigating yet another murder but this time, there's a very heavy dose of bullying centered around it so a good majority of the game's content features the new Seiryo High. I will say, it is immensely cathartic taking down school bullies, especially as someone who was once a victim to it. Returning side characters have been given more screen time to flesh them out more as individuals, particularly Sugiura and Tsukumo, while the newer ones are given strong introductions to make them instantly memorable. Even if the gameplay isn't to your liking, at least you get a compelling Japanese crime-thriller to experience.

My only real complaints are some of the new school club minigames being somewhat wonky to play (looking at you Robo lab and Motorcycle club) and the mandatory scripted stealth segments. On Hard difficulty, enemies will be alerted near instantaneously and you must sit through a 5-10 second animation of Yagami being caught and knocked out with zero ways to escape--it's frustrating when this is the same guy who could walk into a club and comfortably take on a dozen street punks (this is thankfully fixed in the Kaito Files expansion).

As a PC port, Lost Judgment runs buttery smooth with very little technical issues on my end. It seems RGG Studio has progressively gotten better with each new release on Steam and I hope they maintain this level of quality. It is a no-brainer $60 title and if you already have it on PlayStation, buy it again just for increased frames because it plays like an entirely new game.

What makes a Yakuza game a Yakuza game?

To me, it's three things: the heart-wrenching story, the silly mini-games, and the general sense of hopefulness and goodness in humanity. This game has it all and even more.

Yakuza's main story has always have had serious tones, and this game is no different. The main theme of the game is bullying and how the law fails to protect and save the people it is designed to do so. You will feel despair, you will feel happiness, Yakuza games have never been shy from killing off both one-shot villains and characters that are important to the protagonist's growth.  [spoiler]At the end of chapter 7, there is a huge misdirection that will completely break you: you think Sawa will be killed since the villain has captured her, the villain literally tells you that Sawa is not important to them so she will be left alone, but no she will die by their hand when you find out in an extremely emotional scene. This scene hits me hard; I had to actually stopped playing for the remaining night, and when I picked up the game again, I just went into mini-games to kind of move on. It is a bit of a fridging in my opinion; her death's main purpose is to provide an ideal for the protagonist to cling on further into his story.[/spoiler]

Yakuza has always have had "good endings" for most of its side stories (you can also make the case that most main stories also have a good ending). This is what I mean by "a general sense of hopefulness and goodness in humanity," in that the side stories make you feel good and hopeful, if not often laugh out loud at the silliness of it. I like a good story and if the story calls for a sad ending, I understand if that is the logical conclusion for that story, but at the end of the day we play games to escape reality, and isn't it better to escape into a reality that makes us feel happy?

The best thing this game did right are the School Stories: they have a satisfying conclusion that ties in all the individual steps made in-between, and they allow to live through that high-school experience one more time; for many folks, high school was the best time of their lives so I can see the appeal. I thought the advisor mechanism is a pretty smart story framing device in this respect.  [spoiler]In Judgment, there is a Friend system but it is extremely limited: your friends can help you in open-city combat if they happen to spawn nearby, but that's the extent of it. In Lost Judgment, you probably won't finish all the School Stories until you finish the main story (i.e. Premium Adventure, which is a downer), but the conclusion is a grand reunion of all the students you have met and changed their lives for the better, which makes all the efforts you've spent into the sub-stories pay off. And the conclusion falls into the "good ending" category that I mentioned earlier, so even a bigger plus![/spoiler]

Talking about finishing all sub-School Stories, the Robotics Club sub-story is extremely unbalanced; you will want a guide in order to finish it. Essentially, the strategy I went with was to ignore everything else and went straight for putting a block into opponent's home base. I got lucky with the final battle and finished it in only one try; for some of the previous battles, I had to try multiple times and got extremely angry when my own robots would block my path (I learnt to work around it), or when the opponents simply kept destroying my robot so I couldn't anything. Generally, when the game design takes the agency out of your hand due to RNG, it's not very fun.

The Boxing Club sub-story is a blast. It is challenging but not unbalanced (like the Robotics Club), and I don't think you can cheese this very much. There is no difficulty level in this sub-story, unlike the Dance Club sub-story that replaces the dancing mini-games Yakuza games are famous for. If you're not good with rhythm games, you will still be able to make progress.

Lost Judgment is a fine sequel to Judgment, both being spin-offs of the Yakuza franchise. It has all the familiar elements of the previous game with a few changes here and there. Like the tailing missions for example. There are much lesser of them now and the mechanics themselves are more polished. Yagami also gets a brand new fighting style, the snake style, which is very fun to use. The two old styles have changes as well that make them more distinct. The detective part of the gameplay is also more fleshed out and is more engaging than in its predecessor. And thank god that annoying mortal wound feature is not in Lost Judgment.

However, some mechanics from Judgment that were removed here, like the shortcut paths, expanding inventory, certain abilities, etc. I feel should've been kept in. I keep finding myself trying to do something then remembering it's not possible in this one.

The story deals with a much heavier and much more real topic than the rest of the series, ie. school bullying and suicides. This works as a double edged blade because while the story is definitely more hard hitting, the typical Yakuza series nonsensical plot elements are still there and those are made more jarring by the more serious theme. However, it is still a very good story and it shouldn't be skipped.

On the other hand, the school stories side storyline could've been way better. I didn't get through it because it gets very repetitive, especially the robotics club. Fuck that one in particular.

I have done the Kaito Files campaign as well but I'll review that on the DLC page instead.

Near the peak of RGG. Great setting, lots of side content, solid characters and an in-depth story. The only criticism I have is the main plot isn't as compelling as the first Judgment. Unlike the first, this one is more of a philosophical exploration of justice and its consequences. So it's toned down from the usual RGG thriller motif. The hand holding in this one was almost as bad as the first which I find to be mildly irritating. There's no room for allowing the mystery or story beats to settle on the player, everything is explained, re-explained, examined and explored in detail with chapter recaps as the cherry on top. Yagami is motivated in much the same way as Kiryu but motivated by the truth at all costs rather than a bushido morality. This becomes a fairly strange handicap for the story in Lost Judgment because more than once I found myself disagreeing with Yagami and not being persuaded by his arguments or actions. I think I enjoyed that aspect and it played well within the story even if it was a little strange but they tied it up neatly at the end. 

The highschool setting was great though and it had a lot of fun side activities to go along with it. Definitely much stronger being in Ijincho than Kamurocho like the first game. Although some things do play out in Kamurocho and having a 2nd city is a benefit to the story and gameplay. and thankfully, unlike some past titles in the Yakuza series, there's unique stuff in both cities so they didn't get lazy (or w/e the reason) like they did in Y7 (LAD) or Y6. Highly recommend for hours of fun and a much more chill Yakuza/LAD experience.

First: Don't mind my low playtime, I've played this game basically every single day since it came out a year and change ago on my Xbox One.

Second: I'm going to be using the Japanese names for the fighting styles in this review: Waltz is Crane, Flash is Tiger, and Flow is Snake.

Now with that out of the way, the actual review: It's about goddamn time. Lost Judgment is the best work RGG Studio has produced in a long time (and, given that Ichiban remains the main protagonist of Yakuza and Kiryu returning for Yakuza 8, that "long time" is starting to look an awful lot like "ever".) The music is top notch, likewise the fight choreography. The combat is the best in the studio's entire catalog. The writing is top-notch, bucking long-standing RGG trends that I'd always found insufferable. The minigames are fun with the high school they're linked to being about as fun as you can get a high school to be and an equally fun narrative surrounding its students. Lost Judgment is a complete package that's earned my 2021 GOTY spot and, thanks to both this Steam release and the Kaitou Files expansion releasing earlier this year, has very handily usurped Sifu and Midnight Fight Express for my 2022 GOTY. But... why? Why do I hold it in such high regard? Let's get into that!

First of all: Yagami. This isn't his first outing, but it is the first I've been able to join him on and I love the guy; his dynamic with his buddies (whether it's the original crew from Judge Eyes or newcomer Kyouko Amasawa) is wildly enjoyable. Whether he's cheering up a bullied child and encouraging her not to give up on her dreams or being repeatedly thrown for a loop by Amasawa's, well, loopiness, Yagami's interactions are always a blast. He has the "Just Some Guy" charm of Kiryu-era Yakuza bosses down pat. His fighting styles are all graceful and well-designed with additions like vaulting and wall-jumping to shake up the combat and his choreography benefits greatly from the fact that Yagami has to actually avoid and defend against attacks.

However, the biggest reason I like Yagami so much is that for once in their career, RGG Studio have managed to create a protagonist that isn't patently insufferable. Kazuma Kiryu [i]very[/i] quickly establishes himself as a sanctimonious hypocrite who prefers to run away from his problems until someone close to him gets hurt or killed and is wholly uninterested in committing to his platitudes about confronting the past and who he is, while Ichiban Kasuga is essentially the Japanese Wade Watts: a loser with no personality beyond "lol video game references xD!" who drags the entire game down into Satan's wine cellar and whose status as hero and protagonist is facilitated purely by the creators violating the narrative to jack him off at every opportunity.

Yagami, on the other hand, has [b]NONE OF THAT SHIT.[/b] His ideals are consistent and he has no qualms with committing to them; joined Seiryo High's Mystery Research Club as guidance counselor so he can investigate the main case freely? He will gladly see that job to completion. Strongly disagrees with the main villain on the nature of the law? He will just as lief throw hands for his ideals.

Likewise, while he's certainly more relaxed than Kiryu, he's not childish like Ichiban: He'll kill time at the arcade or on the Mega Drive he's got at his office, but when he's kidnapped and strapped to a chair the man with the chainsaw who's about to vivisect him doesn't abruptly transform into some lol so random xd enemy design with a terrible pun for a name. When one of his coworkers has their house besieged by gangsters, the building doesn't abruptly turn into a dungeon with turnbased enemy encounters because "OMG DAE it's just like Dragon Quest!!!1!1!"

Next up, combat: With RGG Studio deciding that LAD's braindead ungabunga which number biggest "combat" is going to be the future of Yakuza, it's up to Lost Judgment to continue the tradition of beat 'em up combat that is very easy to learn and hard to master, and it does so with gusto. But, not content to simply reiterate on what Kiryu had or what Judge Eyes gave Yagami, Lost Judgment decides to take that combat and make it [i]more[/i] so. Both Yakuza and Judge Eyes have always had had light RPG and fighting game elements, but they've always been just that--light. Lost Judgment leans much more heavily on both by introducing status effects and allowing you to cancel attacks outside of super mode and the results are [i]delightful[/i]. Juggling enemies is incredibly satisfying, and status effects are balanced just right to spice up the gameplay while keeping it intrinsic.

Additionally, the fighting styles themselves are a blast: Waltz, your crowd-control style, is loaded with graceful kicks and sweeping multi-hit attacks that make it as effective against a single enemy as against a crowd. Flash, the dedicated "strike first, strike hard, no mercy" single-target style has elements of bajiquan and a hold-to-charge mechanic that succeeds at making you feel the oomph of the charged attacks, while also providing you with a potent counter in the form of the franchise's mainstay Tiger Drop. Flow, the new style introduced with LJ that focuses on defensive prowess and throwing enemies, has a parry mechanic and strong options against armed enemies, as well as drawing very heavy inspiration from Wing Chun.

Boss battles are also some of the best in the franchise because they're where everything comes together, backed by some stellar boss design; a recurring boss in the game has a number of the same options Yagami does, bringing his fights as close to Yakuza PvP as we're likely ever gonna get. However, there's also some other neat tricks: Mortal Reversals, and QTE design.

Judge Eyes' controversial Deadly Attacks return here, but they don't lock your health bar anymore and dodging out of the way and hitting 3 (B/Circle for you non-Tekken folks) at the right time performs a Mortal Reversal which does a massive amount of damage to the boss. On top of this, LJ breaks away from RGG's single-input QTE design to occasionally introduce multi-step QTEs often designed to evoke actions you can perform in gameplay that resemble what Yagami does if you succeed.

And then there's the writing. Lost Judgment has what I consider to be the best writing of any game RGG has released so far. With the Tojo and Omi disbanded as part of LAD's campaign to make its protagonist as special as possible, LJ doesn't have the benefit of established lore; it has to build everything from scratch and it does so [i]wonderfully.[/i] The game moves with surprising speed given how much work it has to do in comparison to its predecessors, and the antagonist factions it introduces leverage that atrocious decision excellently. The mystery in the game is legitimately compelling, and the game's climax is one of the best I've ever seen; it gets the "TV legal thriller J-drama" thing it's going for absolutely DOWN, and that makes it all the more badass when Yagami clinches a court case in the coolest manner imaginable. The high schoolers and their stories are all intriguing and do an excellent job of getting you [i]way[/i] more invested than you probably should be. The antagonists are absolute gigachads who break two of RGG's main molds: One is a genuinely morally gray antagonist who has just as much of a point as the protagonist and manages to break the pattern of RGG villains getting capped literally the second they show anything that vaguely looks like doubt and the other is an unapologetic villain who has zero interest in redemption and stays evil until the end--and, much like Lost Judgment as a whole, they are very much a breath of fresh air.

In conclusion: Absolutely buy this game. It's RGG's best work yet and its mere presence on Steam alongside Judge Eyes is a good sign that there's more Yagami in our future--and I'll drink to that. [i]Karii![/i]

This might be the darkest of the RGG/Yakuza games yet, to the point where it gets somewhat uncomfortable to ignore the main story and go about doing wacky side quests  
The main mystery is incredibly intriguing however, and the main side activity, the school stories, adds an extra layer of mystery, which works very well for this game  
Other than that, it's classic Yakuza, just in a grand scale  
Out of the realtime combat Yakuza games, this is easily the biggest, and is chock full of things to do all over the two towns of Kamurocho and Isezaki Ijincho (A criticism I made on the previous Judgment is that being limited to Kamurocho hampered the game, but this game counters that very well)  
The all new Seiryo High School increases this a bit further  
As of the time of writing this review, I haven't finished either story yet, but looking forward to finishing sometime soon  
  
Editing after completing main story, school stories, and 28/42 side quests:  
  
The main mystery was incredibly compelling and comes to a believable resolution, but once the core points of the mystery are solved, the main story falters.  
  
Yagami's obsession over [spoiler]BUT WHAT ABOUT SAWA-SENSEI?![/spoiler] turns him into a bona fide hypocrite who criticizes others for trying to invoke their own justice at the cost of others' sacrifices while he himself does the same thing. Ultimately, nothing is really settled, and Yagami's solution is to fall back on the very same broken system that caused everything to happen in the first place, with an assurance that he'll protect those who fall through the cracks, which is downright laughable.  
  
The school stories storyline is the other major story content in this game, and is something fresh in the context of RGG Studio games. This storyline tries to tread the fine line between the craziness of the side stories and the seriousness of the main story, and the results of this are rather mixed. The climax has an anime-ish SEISHUN! POWER OF FRIENDSHIP! type of feel to it, and I'm not sure if that really works. Still, the mystery of it all is very compelling, and made me want to see it through to the end, playing through all the minigames to get to it. Dancing, robotics, street racing, boxing, it all adds up to a massive amount of variety, giving you so much to do in the course of this storyline.  
  
Some of the minigames did feel boring, however, such as the Girls Bite minigame, and it felt like it had to be done too many times to get to the end of that particular questline. Still, it's a minor blemish, and you come across several rather colourful and entertaining characters through it all. It's a shame most of this story is unvoiced. Would've loved to hear Amasawa Kyoko talk a bit more.  
  
Oh, and I missed something important when I first wrote this review: TAILING MISSIONS. This was a huge annoyance in the first game, and luckily, the gameplay itself has been improved slightly, but more than anything, the number and frequency of tailing missions have been reduced drastically. If there was criticism about this from players back then by any chance, the devs clearly listened.  
  
In the end, Yakuza 7/LaD remains the best Yakuza/RGG Studio game to date in my mind.  
Lost Judgment does quite a few things right and is an overall improvement over Judgment and older Yakuza games in general, but the main story falters in the end, and the characters of 7 are more entertaining in general, giving 7 an edge over it

Well, RGG, you've done it. You've actually developed a game to surpass my favourite game of all time, and that was also by you, in the form of Yakuza 0.

Lost Judgment is the long-awaited sequel to Judgment, two games that I and probably many others thought would never see on Steam. But here they are and damn are they worth the wait. As good as Judgment is, it is a rough-around-the-edges mess with a good story and (in my opinion) an even better story hidden within in the form of School Stories. What do I mean by rough-around-the-edges? A lot of new 'features' from Judgment that makes the story borderline annoying to play through. Tailing missions have improved for the better in theory, allowing you to blend in at any time when your target looks back at you, and you can finally take cover anywhere. However, it is still tedious. Other new features include what I would call basic platform jumping and climbing segments, where you have a stamina meter. Oh, and the stealth missions, which I normally suck at and hate, but the game holds your hand a little too much, forcing you to take cover at certain areas and even where to throw distractions. All these half-baked ideas are mashed together and somehow... work? I can't really explain it, but every moment you have to do these is somehow understandable as to why and never feel like an uneccesary chore.

Combat is, well, like an RGG game that isn't Like a Dragon 7. And there are three battle styles (+1 through dlc) and each feel fantastic, with the kind of crunch you expect from an RGG game. Absolutely terrific.

As for the story, this is probably the best one I've played through. Despite an early warning that it would involve suicide and bullying, two things that went through my head in my teens, turning me off to the story  from the start, I was eventually drawn in to the intrigue and plot twists, and my favourite antagonist to date. Trust me, I won't spoil anything because the main story is great.

The best part however, is the School Stories, as you investigate shenanigans involving the high school in Ijincho. Each part unlocks different minigames, and events, as well as a well-written if a bit sappy story.

And now, the negatives, and none of them relate to the game itself.

- Denuvo. Just because I play games with that piece of anticonsumer garbage in them doesn't mean I like it. And I will ALWAYS call out SEGA as long as they continue putting this garbage in their games.

- DLC. Yes the master race gets all bar the Kaito Files with the base game, but it's still ridiculous that items that make minigames pathetically easy as well as locking THREE OF THE FOUR girlfriends behind a paywall for PS4/5 versions is insulting. And if you think PC's getting away with it remember that Ishin is coming out at the same time as consoles. It's coming.

- Price. Come on SEGA, no way both games should cost over $100 SGD. And making the Kaito Files 'free' when it definitely isn't worth forty bucks with the bundle is still stupid.

Still though, I absolutely recommend Lost Judgment. I enjoyed every minute of it and will continue to enjoy it a lot more.

Lost Judgement is a very dramatic take on the standard Yakuza series.  It tackles questions that may or may not hit home for a lot of people, very good social commentary.

This may be on my end, as I have a 165hz monitor that I play on (tried to troubleshoot with graphics driver/borderless/etc), which segways into my next point...

So, I've played the majority of the Yakuza games, plus Judgement (which I finished recently). Judgement was really good in its story, but I got bored of the combat after awhile. What was there was good, but Yakuza lives and dies off its combat. Delighted to say that Lost Judgement has remedied this amazingly . The combat is amazing, a lot of moves, and different styles, the snake style being an instant favorite. SP gain is also vastly improved from Judgement, especially if you get the skills early on that increase the SP you get from fights, because let's face it, it's a yakuza game, you're gonna get attacked every ten feet. You might as well get good points from it. 

 Currently on chapter 5 and I'll keep the spoilers down.

The main plot is a murder case, because of course it is. Yet, I've honestly been more pre-occupied with the school activities. Yagami becomes an advisor for the various school clubs, starting with dancing. The good thing is that if you're not good at rhythm games, you can put it on extra easy and press one button. The other clubs are incredibly fun, you get to play battle bots with the robotics club, which it can seem difficult at first but you can win pretty easily. Then there's the boxing gym to channel your Hajime No Ippo fantasies. There's also a casino if you're more into good ol' gambling.

All of this and more while helping the Mystery Club, headed by a clever girl that nearly lands your ass in prison. It's great. Also, you get to beat the shit out of high school assholes, and honestly, that's good enough reason to get the game there. 

Besides that, you got your usual side-cases, there's a lot of cats too, so if you love cats, you're in for a treat. One of which sees the return of Ninja Ryan. You'll see quite a few familiar faces if you played Judgement, which honestly you should. You also get a skateboard, which can be a bit finnicky, but it makes getting around fun and fast.


The tailing and chase system are also improved, still one of the weaker parts of both games, but a lot better.

In conclusion, Lost Judgement improves on pretty much every aspect of the previous game in spades. I'm only thirteen hours in, so I have a lot more to go but I have no regrets whatsoever at paying full price of $65 USD for LJ. It's been a blast and if you're a fan of Yakuza or its spin offs, definitely buy this one, I don't think you'll be disappointed, even at full price.

This game is basically a typical 10-episode-per-season Japanese TV drama turned into a videogame. Played with Japanese audio. This review may change as I keep playing more

+Nice graphics... when it's realtime. From environments to character models. There are perks though...
+Sound's standard. Acceptable music, sound effects, and good acting
+Story is good. It's not groundbreaking, but once you start, you'll be hooked on it until it's over like a Japanese housewife on a weekday afternoon
+Gameplay's OK. Nothing groundbreaking here too, but one doesn't have to fix what ain't broke. 
+Playable content is huge. Playable area isn't, but the small areas are loaded with stuff to do.

-...I don't understand why at least a quarter of story scenes have to be prerendered on video when it's perfectly able to do so in realtime, such as the first courtroom scene, which was partially prerendered and a good chunk of it later in realtime. Devs used to do this when the specific scenes are too heavy to render in realtime, but that courtroom scene has no business at all being partially prerendered when the graphical load is the same. You better get used to these jarring transitions between prerendered 30fps cutscenes and realtime 60fps scenes, unless you're a pleb plays on 30fps for 'cinematic experience'

I have always suggested the Judgement series to everyone, but I always get a bit sad how not everyone has access to them due to them being PS exclusive at the time. Now that they're finally on PC, the long-awaited dream of me suggesting this game to literally everyone has finally come. 

I have accumulated over 150+ hours on both Judgement(2 playthroughs) and Lost Judgement(4 playthroughs) on the PS5 in just 2 months of getting them, and now another playthrough of LJ on PC! I can never say this enough, but the gameplay and story of both games are simply fantastic. Not to mention the super stylish moves you can pull off(and of course juggling lol).

A few complaints I do have for the PC port are that pre-rendered cutscenes are locked at 30 FPS and playing anything above 60 FPS will make certain things janky/weird. An example of that would be the Snake Style parry. It works normally on 60 FPS, but starts being weird at 120 (however still playable). Another issue that has plagued other Dragon Engine games would be how charged finishers(Tiger Style and maybe Snake Style specifically for LJ) would freeze the character in place if played at an uncapped framerate. So if you're having that problem, I suggest limiting your framerate to 120. 

Those issues aside, amazing game and story-writing. All around lovable and very well-written characters. Would definitely recommend to everyone and especially to people who enjoy stylish brawler combat set in the RGG world.

[h1]The Game Itself:[/h1]


Detective Takayuki Yagami is back in the gripping sequel to Judgment. Lost Judgment drops you into another gripping tale from the developers behind Yakuza. After a police officer mentions the murder of a student teacher who bullied his son to suicide, Yagami must go undercover as a high school club advisor to uncover the truth behind the vicious cycle of bullying and the worrying increase in victims. Now with 3 fighting styles and the ability to join the Dance Club, it is up to you to end this horrible repeat of events.


[h1]Steam Deck Performance:[/h1]


Lost Judgment runs around the same as its predecessor, being able to hit 40 FPS 95% of the time with drops occurring when loading in the environment quickly. It feels really smooth most of the time though and looks fantastic on the screen. The temps generally stay below 70c and can get around 3 - 3.5 hours of battery life thanks to a mix of medium/low settings, FSR 2.0, and a TDP set to 8.

The one big difference with Lost Judgment is the FSR 2.0 blur is a bit more noticeable. It wasn't enough to deter my enjoyment of the game, but it was something to note. In some scenes, when you were far away from a person in a cutscene, the face looked a little bit blurry. But the worst was pausing when a cutscene was going and every person who was moving would look smudged. Unpausing immediately returned everything to normal though.

Even with all of this, I genuinely am enjoying the experience so far. The 40 FPS sacrifices are completely worth it thanks to how smooth the game feels. I will be testing out a new build to counteract the blurring, though it will eat more battery, and try implementing FSR 2.1 files to see if they help. I have the PS4 version of the game and actually beaten the game there. But i won't spoil story things here.

But first things first, thank you SEGA for casting whatever black magic to convince the certain agency that held this game and Judgment from appearing in PC.

How's the game?
If you don't really like Yakuza 6/Kiwami 2 (which i am not a big fan of) combat, this game IMPROVES upon that combat a lot, as they added more fighting style in the game. In previous game, there's two combat styles, which is Tiger and Crane, both are different but unfortunately Tiger have a move that is pretty broken. But now in this game, both Tiger and Crane are pretty balanced, as they both even gained more options, also there are 2 new fighting style for this entry, a snake that have major focus on countering, and boxing which personally i haven't use a lot but from what i've seen, it is pretty broken as you can easily juggle some enemies with it. (and its originally a DLC style)

Graphic wise, its Dragon Engine. The quality of Yakuza games honestly can be a hit or miss (like K2 green filter is very questionable) and personally? Lost Judgment is a hit for me.

For content, this game is VERY PACKED with it. A lot of mini games and the school stories stuff, combined with side cases. Not to mention that you not only visit Kamurocho, you also get to Yokohama (as majority of game takes place there)

As for story, some people actually prefer the previous entry more, but for me, I think that I prefered this plot more as I found the premise of the plot pretty grounded, and relatable.

Also do i need to say somehting about the music? Well it's still a banger. Like give some of the soundtrack a listen, you'll know why. It just still have that quality that the main Yakuza/Like a Dragon games have.

This game was my GOTY in 2021. And I think it will be my GOTY for this year as well (sorry Elden Ring. You're still a great game)

PS: It ran well in steam deck. Finally Lost Judgment/Judgment on the go.
